ENTC 2615.description: The student undertakes a project designed to utilize principle methods studied in previous courses. The subject of the project is determined jointly by the student and instructor and developed formally by the student. The course is normally taken during the final stages of the student's program.
ENTC 2615.name: Design Project

ENTC 3799.description: This course provides students with cooperative education experiences in various engineering technology disciplines. To receive credit for the course, the student is expected to work at the assignment a minimum of 400 hours, submit a report of activities, and obtain approval of the department Professional Practice Committee. Course may be repeated up to a maximum of 3 s.h. toward the BSAS. Students are considered full-time even though only 1 s.h. is given for each course. Grading: PR, CR, NC.
ENTC 3799.name: Professional Practice in Engineering Technology

ENTC 1501.description: Understanding what engineering technology is, exploring careers for engineering technicians, time management and adjusting to the college environments, basic Excel functions and uses, performing labs and writing lab reports, writing class reports/term papers.
ENTC 1501.name: Introduction to Engineering Technology

ENTC 1500.description: A course designed to develop the technical, analytical and problem solving skills of students planning to enter an engineering or technical course of study. Three (3) hours of lecture and three (3) hours lab per week. Grading is A, B, C, NC.Prereq. or concurrent: MATH 1501.
ENTC 1500.name: Technical Skills Development

ENTC 1505.description: The role of the technician, technologist, engineer and scientist in the technology team; a study of basic mathematical, scientific, and communicative techniques as applied to the work of engineering technologists; ethical, global, and societal issues facing the engineering technology professional. Three hours lecture, three hours lab per week. Grading is A, B, C, NC. Corequistite MATH 1513.
ENTC 1505.prereq: grade of "B" in both ENTC 1500 and MATH 1507.
ENTC 1505.name: Engineering Technology Concepts

ENTC 4895.description: Individual study under direction of a faculty member. Written and oral report required. May be repeated for a maximum of 4 s.h.
ENTC 4895.prereq: Junior standing, consent of instructor, and prior approval of the project by the IETP committee of engineering technology faculty.
ENTC 4895.name: Independent Engineering Technology Project

ECON 3720.description: An examination of the recent world-wide trend toward free market economy, giving particular attention to basic processes such as resource allocation and product distribution. Frequent references are made to the failure of Socialism in the USSR and the new approach in Russia, Eastern Europe and China toward market economies.
ECON 3720.name: Comparative Economic Systems

ECON 6915.description: A theoretical and empirical analysis of the health care sector. Topics include the demand for health care and health insurance, the perverse incentives of health insurance, moral hazard, physician and hospital behavior, and the role of competitive markets in the delivery of health care. Special emphasis is placed on the analysis of public policy, including financing and regulating the health care industry.
ECON 6915.prereq: admission into the MA in Economics or MA in Financial Economics programs or permission of instructor.
ECON 6915.name: Health Policy

ECON 6945.description: Study of the role of the government in the economy. The topics covered will include expenditure analysis, theories of taxation, provision of public goods, fiscal federalism, and public choice theory.
ECON 6945.name: Public Finance

ECON 6988.description: A study of modeling and evaluation of derivatives and bonds and risk management using derivatives.  Topics cover various models in asset evaluation, such as bond price models, the Black-Sholes model, diffusion processes, and risk management.  Also listed as STAT 6988.
ECON 6988.name: Modeling in Financial Economics

ECON 3724.description: Study of the politics, theories, and techniques of public budgeting. Includes the process of budget preparation, adoption and execution. Topics include debt management and capital budgets. (This course is cross-listed with POL 3724.).
ECON 3724.name: Public Budgeting

ECON 6941.description: Study of the empirical analysis using multivariate time series methods, including the topics of distributed lag models, selection of the appropriate lag structures, causation versus correlation, and cointegration.
ECON 6941.prereq: ECON 6922 or permission of the instructor.
ECON 6941.name: Monetary Economics

ECON 6940.description: Study of various topics, including risk and the selection of the optimal monetary control tool, politics and monetary control, the financial firm as an optimizing institution, and portfolio theory.
ECON 6940.prereq: ECON 6939 or permission of the instructor.
ECON 6940.name: Financial Economics

ECON 3702.description: The development and present status of public finance; federal, state and local expenditures and taxation; theories of tax incidence, axioms of taxation, theories in justification and government spending; tax reform. Study of the techniques of fiscal policy with emphasis on its role as a determinant of the level of national income.
ECON 3702.name: Public Finance

ECON 3703.description: Uses insights from economics and psychology to explain why normally rational people make poor choices in their lives, be it in terms of money, health, education or long-term happiness. This introductory course explores the sources of poor economic choices and examines ways to improve them.
ECON 3703.name: Behavioral Economics

ECON 6981.description: Study of the foreign exchange market; the business and economic consequences of changes in domestic and foreign banking; central banking; and financial market policies. The development of various exchange rate standards, foreign currency markets, and the Eurocurrency and Eurobond markets.
ECON 6981.prereq: admission into the MA in Economics or MA in Financial Economics programs or permission of instructor.
ECON 6981.name: International Finance

ECON 3701.description: Organization and operation of commercial banking in the United States; central banking under the Federal Reserve System; basic theory. Monetary policy as a determinant of national income.
ECON 3701.name: Money and Banking

ECON 6970.description: The practical application of economic knowledge and statistical skills in the workplace. Students assist participating professionals in various kinds of industrial, financial, and public service organizations. By permit only.
ECON 6970.name: Economics Internship

ECON 6985.description: Study of the determination of a country's exports and imports, the social welfare consequence of trade, free trade versus restricted trade, preferential trading agreements, and the current composition and direction of U.S. trade.
ECON 6985.prereq: admission into the MA in Economics or MA in Financial Economics programs or permission of instructor.
ECON 6985.name: International Trade and Development

ECON 3705.description: Application of economic theory to environmental problems, analysis of policy alternatives for pollution abatement, and the conservation of exhaustible resources. Determination of efficient management of local and national pollution levels, including air, water, and toxic substances. Possible economic consequences associated with global warming.
ECON 3705.name: Environmental and Resource Economics

ECON 6976.description: Study of the fundamentals of econometric techniques that are useful for estimating causal economic relationships. The objectives include (1) analysis of the effects of exogenous factors on the variable whose behavior we seek to explain, (2) testing of hypotheses about new and existing economic theories, and (3) forecasting estimated economic relationships beyond the sample period for the purpose of planning and control. The course will focus on the practice of econometrics with extensive applications to a variety of real-world problems in many areas of economics.
ECON 6976.name: Econometrics

ECON 2630H.description: Studies of growth, inflation, and unemployment at the national level and the performance of the U.S. economy in the global setting. The impacts of national economic policies on individual and social welfare. An extensive discussion and evaluation of the U.S. banking system and its effects on individuals and businesses.
ECON 2630H.name: Honors Principles 2: Macroeconomics

ECON 4855.description: Application of basic principles to the study of the health care industry. Topics include the supply and demand of medical care, the effects of private and public insurance on the health care industry, trends in health care costs, public policies to equalize access to medical care and the dilemma caused by the improvement in life-sustaining technology.
ECON 4855.name: Health Economics

ECON 4898.description: For undergraduates taking courses in the MA in Economics program for credit towards an undergraduate degree. Credit earned cannot be later applied to a graduate degree. The student must meet the criteria for undergraduate students taking graduate coursework listed in the Graduate Bulletin. May be repeated with different graduate courses.
ECON 4898.prereq: A minimum of 20 hours of coursework in economics at the 2600 level and above, permission of the chair, junior standing.
ECON 4898.name: Graduate Study in Selected Economic Topics

ECON 5856.description: Application of different tools of mathematical economics, computational economics, and econometrics in conjunction with economic theory to model economic problems of firms, consumers, financial institutions, and public sectors. Specific content of the course will vary with the instructor. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ECON 5856.name: Topics in Quantitative Economics

ECON 4870.description: The practical application of economic knowledge and statistical skills in the workplace. Students assist professionals in various kinds of industrial, financial, and public service organizations.
ECON 4870.name: Economics Internship

ECON 1503H.description: . Workplace. Examines how labor markets determine the distribution of income and the dramatic changes in the composition of the American labor force. Explores such issues as the widening gap between low and upper income groups, the characteristics of the poor, affirmative action, the glass ceiling, the mommy track, and family-friendly working environments. Not applicable towards a major or minor in economics.Gen Ed: Domestic Diversity, Social Science, Social and Personal Awareness.
ECON 1503H.name: Honors Rich and Poor: Diversity and Disparity in the U.S. Workplace

ECON 5853.description: The practice of econometrics with emphasis on model construction, estimation, and interpretation of results. Applications in the private and public sectors involve the use of computers and economic software.
ECON 5853.name: Applied Econometrics

ECON 2610H.description: Introduction to the theory of markets, including the behavior of consumers and the conduct of private and public business enterprise. Effects of monopoly and competition on private and social welfare. The role of government in promoting the economic welfare of consumers, workers, and minorities.
ECON 2610H.prereq: MATH 1501, or a level 20 or higher on the math placement exam.Gen Ed: Social Science.
ECON 2610H.name: Honors Principles 1: Microeconomics

ECON 5811.description: Theories of international trade and specialization; free trade vs. protectionism; tariff and non-tariff barriers to international trade; international balance of payments and its components; the role of multinational enterprises in contemporary trade pattern; regional economic integrations and world trade; U.S. commercial policies.
ECON 5811.name: International Trade

ECON 5812.description: Theories of foreign exchange and capital movements, international payments, analysis of spot and forward foreign exchange markets, foreign exchange market arbitrage, speculation, and risk hedging. The Bretton Woods agreement and the contemporary international monetary system. The rise of international organizations and multinational enterprises in the international economy.
ECON 5812.name: International Finance

ECON 1501.description: An introduction to the United States' economic system and institutions through the examination of current economic problems. Not applicable for a major or minor in economics. Credit will not be given for 1501 if a student has already received credit for ECON 2610 or its equivalent.Gen Ed: Social Science.
ECON 1501.name: Economics in Action

ECON 4810.description: An application of economic analysis to business problems. Emphasis upon executive decisions for the allocation of resources.
ECON 4810.name: Managerial Economics

ECON 3790.description: Introduction to statistical methods in data analysis and forecasting. Topics include descriptive statistics, probability, hypothesis testing, regression analysis, ANOVA and time series analysis. Practical application of statistical procedures is incorporated into regularly scheduled computer workshops.
ECON 3790.name: Statistics for Business and Economics

ECON 5831.description: Economic theory and analysis of labor as an input in the resource market; principles, labor problems, public policy; theories of the development of the labor movement; economic objectives of trade unions; problems in public control.
ECON 5831.name: Labor Markets and the Economics of Unions

ECON 4899.description: Individual study of a topic, area, or problem requiring in-depth reading, and a written project. May be repeated once with a different topic, area, or problem.
ECON 4899.prereq: Junior or senior standing, by permit only.
ECON 4899.name: Individual Study in Economics

ECON 6912.description: Study of demand and supply, consumer theory, the theory of the firm, various market structures, and Pareto efficiency.
ECON 6912.name: Microeconomic Theory

ECON 6939.description: Study of the institutions, instruments, and markets that facilitate the distribution of financial resources throughout the economy. The course discusses the money, capital, and commodity markets. Also, the topics of accessing default risk and hedging against market risk are discussed.
ECON 6939.prereq: admission into the MA in Economics or MA in Financial Economics programs or permission of instructor.
ECON 6939.name: The Economics of Financial Markets and Institutions

ECON 6952.description: A study of poverty and the effectiveness of antipoverty programs. Topics include defining and measuring poverty, trends in the rate of poverty and the distribution of income, causes of poverty, models of discrimination, effectiveness of government training programs, transfer programs and their effect on labor supply, and the financial stability of the Social Security retirement program.
ECON 6952.prereq: admission into the MA in Economics or MA in Financial Economics programs or permission of instructor.
ECON 6952.name: Transfer Programs and Poverty

ECON 6955.description: Study of the pivotal court decisions that have determined the direction of antitrust law. Concentration is on the economic analysis of court decisions and the impact of the courts' decision on market structure. Topics covered include price fixing, mergers, monopolization, and exclusion practices.
ECON 6955.prereq: admission into the MA in Economics or MA in Financial Economics programs or permission of instructor.
ECON 6955.name: Antitrust and Market Structure

ECON 2631.description: Measurement of the national economy's performance (growth, inflation, and unemployment), the banking system, the impact of government on macroeconomic performance, and international macroeconomics. Principles of personal finance, including budgeting, the use of credit, and financial planning are also discussed. Open only to education majors. Credit will not be given for both ECON 2630 and ECON 2631.
ECON 2631.name: Introductory Macroeconomics for Education Majors

ECON 2630.description: Studies of growth, inflation, and unemployment at the national level and the performance of the U.S. economy in the global setting. The impacts of national economic policies on individual and social welfare. An extensive discussion and evaluation of the U.S. banking system and its effects on individuals and businesses.
ECON 2630.name: Principles 2: Macroeconomics

ECON 1504.description: An introduction to the economic consequences of an aging population and the economic status of the aged. Topics include income adequacy in old age, retirement decisions, retirement income planning, social security income, employer-sponsored pensions, and financing health care. Not applicable toward a major or minor in economics.
ECON 1504.name: Economics of Aging

ECON 1502.description: Examines the crises and successes of the American economy since 1929, and how the economic policies of different presidential administrations affected the lives of U.S. citizens. Not applicable towards a major or minor in economics.Gen Ed: Social Science.
ECON 1502.name: Panic and Prosperity, United States Economic Policy Since the Great Depression

ECON 1503.description: Examines how labor markets determine the distribution of income and the dramatic changes in the composition of the American labor force. Explores such issues as the widening gap between low and upper income groups, the characteristics of the poor, affirmative action, the glass ceiling, the mommy track, and family-friendly working environments. Not applicable towards a major or minor in economics.Gen Ed: Domestic Diversity, Social Science, Social and Personal Awareness.
ECON 1503.name: Rich and Poor: Diversity and Disparity in the United States Workplace

ECON 6999.description: A research project under the supervision of a member of the department on the graduate faculty. The project typically extends the student's research in ECON 6998.
ECON 6999.prereq: a grade of "A" or "B" in ECON 6998 and a thesis proposal accepted by departmental committee.
ECON 6999.name: Master's Thesis

ECON 2610.description: Introduction to the theory of markets, including the behavior of consumers and the conduct of private and public business enterprise. Effects of monopoly and competition on private and social welfare. The role of government in promoting the economic welfare of consumers, workers, and minorities.
ECON 2610.prereq: MATH 1501, or a level 20 or higher on the math placement exam.Gen Ed: Social Science.
ECON 2610.name: Principles 1: Microeconomics

ECON 4880.description: The application and extension of the student's skills in economic analysis and statistical techniques to economic issues. The course covers sources of data, exploratory data techniques, matching of data and statistical tests, interpretation and presentation of the results. Students demonstrate their command of research techniques by the completion of a research paper and its oral presentation. Topics to be determined.
ECON 4880.prereq: ECON 3710, ECON 3712, and either ECON 3790.Gen Ed: Capstone.
ECON 4880.name: Analysis of Economic Problems

ECON 3710.description: A systematic analysis of the theory of demand and the theory of the firm: production input and output choices, and some basic concepts of linear programming. An intensive analysis of the theory of the firm: competitive pricing, monopoly pricing, pricing in imperfect competition; and the theory of rent, profits, interest and wages.
ECON 3710.prereq: ECON 2610, and either MATH 1552, MATH 1570, or MATH 1571.
ECON 3710.name: Intermediate Microeconomic Theory

ECON 3712.description: The construction of national income and production accounts and the basic determinant of income, output, and employment. Determination of the level of employment, interest, and money through the classical versus Keynesian aggregate economics.
ECON 3712.prereq: ECON 2630 and either MATH 1552, MATH 1570, or MATH 1571.
ECON 3712.name: Intermediate Macroeconomic Theory

ECON 6990.description: Special interest topics selected by the staff in the following areas: economic education, economic theory, and applied economics analysis. May be repeated for a maximum of six hours toward a graduate degree.
ECON 6990.name: Special Topics in Economics

ECON 6998.description: Applied quantitative research techniques will be discussed. Students are required to undertake an original quantitative research project in a field of economics and write a paper summarizing their results. Course may be taken concurrently with ECON 6976.
ECON 6998.name: Research Seminar

ECON 6946.description: Study of the special problems of financing subnational governments. Topics include the optimal level of local government spending, public choice through voting, public choice through migration, the combination of taxes used by state and local governments, the theory of tax incidence, the effect of intergovernmental grants, and expenditure patterns of local governments. Special attention will be given to local governmental grants and expenditure patterns of local governments, as well as local governments' role in financing education and transfer payments.
ECON 6946.prereq: admission into the MA in Economics or MA in Financial Economics programs or permission of instructor.
ECON 6946.name: State and Local Public Finance

ECON 6900.description: A survey of the fundamental statistical techniques used in business with special emphasis on interpreting the results generated by statistical software. Techniques covered: hypothesis tests of means and proportions, estimation, chi-square tests, analysis of variance, correlation, and regression. Not applicable toward the M.A. in economics.
ECON 6900.name: Statistical Problems

ECON 4843.description: Causes of poverty and income inequality and the analysis of the policy options for reducing poverty. Quantification of the dimensions of poverty, the evaluation of the effectiveness of training programs, the effects of antipoverty programs on the behavior of recipients, and the affirmative action debate.
ECON 4843.name: Economics of Poverty, Discrimination and Transfer Programs

ECON 4860.description: Advanced study of selected topics in economic analysis and issues in economic policy. May be repeated once with different topic.
ECON 4860.name: Selected Topics in Economics

ECON 5806.description: Designed to provide students with an understanding of the development of economic ideas to include: Mercantilism, Physiocrats, the English Classical School, Utilitarianism, early Social Thought, Karl Marx, the German Historical School, Institutionalists and the Keynesian School.
ECON 5806.name: History of Economic Thought

ECON 5822.description: Economic analysis of the problems of urbanized areas and the causes of the growth or decline in economic activity in small-area economics. Topics include benefit-cost analysis, economic base analysis, input-output applications, and the theory of location and agglomeration.
ECON 5822.name: Urban and Regional Economics

ECON 5824.description: An in-depth analysis of time series models and their applications to problems in economics and business. Emphasis on forecasting. Extensive use of standard computer programs.
ECON 5824.prereq: ECON 2610 and either ECON 3790 or STAT 4817.
ECON 5824.name: Applied Time Series Analysis of Economic and Business Data

ECON 5801.description: A systematic analysis of the structure, conduct, and performance of American industry. A quantitative analysis plus a comprehensive review of theoretical models of the market, firm behavior, and performance.
ECON 5801.name: Economics of Industrial Organization

ECON 6904.description: A course designed to provide graduate students in economics with an opportunity to acquire the necessary skills in using the quantitative methods that are required to complete graduate-level economic theory and econometrics courses successfully. The course introduces the basic concepts and procedures of differential and integral calculus that are used in economic analysis, as well as the fundamental probability and statistics which are needed in the study of econometrics.
ECON 6904.name: Quantitative Methods for Economics

ECON 3788.description: Introduction to statistical methods in data analysis and forecasting. Topics include descriptive statistics, probability, sampling and sampling distributions, and hypothesis testing. Practical application of statistical procedures is incorporated into regularly scheduled computer workshops. Credit will not be given for ECON 3788 if a student has already received credit for ECON 3790 or its equivalent.
ECON 3788.name: Statistics for Business and Economics 1

ECON 3789.description: This course builds on concepts introduced in ECON 3788. Specific topics include hypothesis testing, regression analysis, ANOVA and time series analysis. Practical application of statistical procedures is incorporated into regularly scheduled computer workshops. Credit will not be given for ECON 3789 if a student has already received credit for ECON 3790 or its equivalent. 3 s.h.
ECON 3789.name: Statistics for Business and Economics 2

ECON 6921.description: Participants will learn to analyze and understand the impact economic factors (e.g., information, consumer behavior, supply and demand) have on shaping markets and industries.  Using this knowledge, participants will be capable of assessing the different types of economic strategies (e.g., product differentiation, pricing, advertising and signaling) an organization can employ to gain market power to realize economic profits.
ECON 6921.name: Economic Analysis of Markets and Industries

ECON 5809.description: The financial market system, including money and capital markets. Current problems associated with trends in theory and practice. Theories of the interest rate and monetarism.
ECON 5809.name: Current Problems in Money, Banking, and Financial Markets

ECON 6922.description: Examines models used to determine the value of various aggregate economic variables, such as the price level, national income, employment, interest rates, and wage rates.
ECON 6922.name: Macroeconomic Theory

VOIC 4806.description: Private Music Lessons.Gen Ed: Capstone, Capstone.
VOIC 4806.name: Voice

VOIC 4804.description: Private Music Lessons.Gen Ed: Capstone, Capstone.
VOIC 4804.name: Voice

VOIC 4802.description: Private Music Lessons.Gen Ed: Capstone, Capstone.
VOIC 4802.name: Voice

FNUT 4860L.description: Selected clinical experience providing opportunities for application of nutritional care process to individuals exhibiting special nutritional needs. Twelve hours lab, one hour lecture per week. Restricted to Coordinated Program in Dietetics.
FNUT 4860L.name: Medical Nutrition Therapy 3 Lab

FNUT 4872L.description: Selected clinical experiences providing opportunities for application of nutritional care process to maternal and child population. Four hours clinical experience, one hour lecture per week. Restricted to Coordinated Program in Dietetics.Concurrent with: FNUT 4872.
FNUT 4872L.name: Maternal and Child Nutrition Laboratory

FNUT 2609L.description: Observation of food service facility organization and management function; participation in the operations of a clinical food service facility. Six hours clinical experience per week, one hour seminar per week.
FNUT 2609L.prereq: ACCT 1503, FNUT 2612 or concurrent, FNUT 2610 or concurrent.
FNUT 2609L.name: Food Systems: Supervised Practice

FNUT 2613L.description: Application of the nutrition care process in a medical setting for the dietetic technician. Includes a two hour on-campus seminar, and six hours of supervised clinical experience per week.
FNUT 2613L.name: Medical Nutrition Therapy Supervised Practice

FNUT 2612.description: The fundamentals of food service operations including menu planning, purchasing of foods and equipment, care of foods and equipment, efficient work methods, budget and cost control. Also standard principles, techniques in quantity food production, management, and service.
FNUT 2612.name: Food Systems: Operation, Production, and Service

FNUT 1512.description: Safe food handling and sanitation practices for students desiring to be employed in the food service industry. Upon successfully completing the ServSafe exam, the student will be awarded the ServSafe Certification and the Ohio Department of Health Food Protection Certification.
FNUT 1512.name: Food Safety and Sanitation

FNUT 1551.description: The fundamentals of normal nutrition as they apply to health; nutritional needs during various stages of the life cycle; dietary guides and their application to the selection of adequate diets; problems of nutritional deficiencies and excesses.
FNUT 1551.prereq: CHEM 1500 or high school equivalent.Gen Ed: Well Being, Social and Personal Awareness.
FNUT 1551.name: Normal Nutrition

FNUT 1553.description: Scientific principles and methods used in selecting, purchasing, and preparing food. Consideration given to nutritional, aesthetic, and socioeconomic factors in meal planning.
FNUT 1553.name: Food Science and Management Principles

FNUT 4873L.description: Supervised practice experiences providing opportunities for application of the dietetic process in the extended care setting. One hour lecture, 12 hours clinical experience per week.
FNUT 4873L.prereq: FNUT 4873 or concurrent and restricted to Coordinated Program in Dietetics.
FNUT 4873L.name: Nutrition and Aging Laboratory

FNUT 2652L.description: Procedures and techniques in anthropometric, biochemical, clinical and dietary assessment of nutritional status in healthy and at-risk populations. Three hours lab per week.
FNUT 2652L.name: Nutrition Assessment Laboratory

FNUT 2603L.description: Application of basic principles of medical nutrition therapy; nutritional assessment; diet calculations. Three hours lab per week.Concurrent with: FNUT 2603.
FNUT 2603L.name: Medical Nutrition Therapy 1 Lab

FNUT 4874.description: Public health nutrition and wellness programs and their services to the community. Emphasis on program funding, cultural competence and needs of the underserved and elderly.
FNUT 4874.name: Community Nutrition and Wellness

FNUT 4858.description: Advanced food service systems management principles and processes as they relate to resources and operating subsystems. Focus on subsystem interrelationships.
FNUT 4858.name: Food Service Systems Management

FNUT 4873.description: Nutritional needs of the elderly as influenced by the aging process and disease states; factors affecting the food availability, food intake, and nutritional status of the elderly; nutritional services for the elderly.
FNUT 4873.name: Nutrition and Aging

FNUT 4872.description: Principles of the nutritional care process as it relates to the maternal and pediatric population.
FNUT 4872.name: Maternal and Child Nutrition

FNUT 3759.description: Integrated approach to nutrition and health, emphasizing metabolism and functions of nutrients at the cellular level; nutritional needs for optimal health; problems of over nutrition and under nutrition.
FNUT 3759.name: Advanced Nutrition

FNUT 4810.description: Advanced study of food science and technology; methodology of food research including evaluation by sensory and objective methods.
FNUT 4810.name: Experimental Foods

FNUT 5862L.description: Three hours lab per week. Permit required.Concurrent with: FNUT 5862.
FNUT 5862L.name: Food and Cultures Laboratory

FNUT 3735.description: Designed for nutrition majors, covers the basic concepts of classification, structure, and function of biological molecules, major metabolic pathways, heredity and immune function, with emphasis on the understanding of the metabolism and function of nutrients.
FNUT 3735.name: Nutritional Biochemistry

FNUT 4895.description: Application of dietetics principles learned in the classroom to situations in clinical, food service-management, and community settings. Provides opportunities for communication with diverse groups, critical thinking, and problem solving. Emphasis on case-study presentations of current issues and trends in the field. One (1) hour lecture and six (6) hours of laboratory per week.
FNUT 4895.prereq: FNUT 4858, FNUT 4860, FNUT 4874 or concurrent, and HMEC 4890 or concurrent.Gen Ed: Capstone.
FNUT 4895.name: DPD Capstone

FNUT 3760L.description: Orientation to the dietetic profession. Select clinical experiences providing opportunities for developing an understanding and working knowledge of the nutrition care process and its application to individuals exhibiting special nutritional needs. Six hours lab. Restricted course.Concurrent with: FNUT 3760 and FNUT 3760R.
FNUT 3760L.name: Medical Nutrition Therapy 2 Laboratory

FNUT 2628.description: Experience in supervision of food production; assessment, documentation, and teaching of the individual patient or client groups; community nutrition. The role of the dietetic technician in the health care delivery system; overview of current opportunities in the food service field; standards of professional responsibility, practice, and self development. Fifteen discussion hours and 210 hours of clinical experience. Overall GPA of 2.5 required.
FNUT 2628.name: Practicum in Dietetic Technology

FNUT 2603.description: Principles and methods of diet modifications for common diseases; planning and evaluation of modified diets; application of computers for diet analysis. Must be taken concurrently with FNUT 2603L.
FNUT 2603.name: Medical Nutrition Therapy 1

FNUT 5862.description: Food practices of selected world cultures. Evaluation of these practices in meeting dietary needs with consideration of the existing social, economic, and environmental conditions.
FNUT 5862.name: Food and Culture

FNUT 5825.description: Readings and critical appraisal of research literature in nutrition.
FNUT 5825.name: Current Nutrition Concepts

FNUT 2612L.description: Application of the fundamentals of food systems operations, management, and service. Six hours lab per week.
FNUT 2612L.name: Food Systems: Operations, Production, and Service Laboratory

FNUT 4810L.description: Application of scientific principles and experimental procedures to cooking processes. Three hours lab per week. Permit required.Concurrent with: FNUT 4810.
FNUT 4810L.name: Experimental Foods Laboratory

FNUT 1543.description: Basic normal nutrition adaptable to individual lifestyles throughout the lifespan. Emphasis on valid nutrition information, wellness, and healthful food choices. Not applicable to the food and nutrition major.
FNUT 1543.name: Personal Nutrition

FNUT 1553L.description: Application of principles from FNUT 1553. Three hours lab per week.
FNUT 1553L.name: Food Science and Management Principles Laboratory

FNUT 4802.description: Overview of research methodology, statistics and applications in the field of nutrition and dietetics.
FNUT 4802.prereq: MATH 2623 or MATH 2625 and junior standing.
FNUT 4802.name: Research Methods in Dietetics

FNUT 2610.description: Concepts of organization and management related to hospitality/health care; selecting, training, developing, and supervising for the advancement of personnel. Emphasis on labor-management relations and legal aspects of the management-guest relationship with particular attention to personal and property liability.
FNUT 2610.name: Organization and Management

FNUT 4860.description: The nature and etiology of selected disease conditions with focus on solving dietetic problems accompanying them.
FNUT 4860.name: Medical Nutrition Therapy 3

FNUT 3760R.description: Orientation to the dietetic profession. Lecture to further students' understanding and working knowledge of the nutrition care process and its application to individuals exhibiting special nutritional needs. Restricted course.Concurrent with: FNUT 3760 and FNUT 3760L.
FNUT 3760R.name: Medical Nutrition Therapy 2 Laboratory Recitation

FNUT 3760.description: The nature and etiology of diseases and the relationship of diet to good health and to disease processes; the special dietary needs of abnormal conditions.
FNUT 3760.name: Medical Nutrition Therapy 2

FNUT 3761.description: Advanced study of concepts related to the integration of nutrition and physical activity in athletic as well as normal and diseased populations. Emphasis on substrate utilization and modification, and nutrient/ergogenic supplementation and crash diets.
FNUT 3761.name: Science of Nutrition in Exercise

FNUT 3720.description: Current knowledge of nutrition as it relates to overall health and human aging. Needs of the elderly in normal and diseased conditions. Nutritional needs/concerns of the elderly in the contexts of their physiological, social, and psychological dilemmas.
FNUT 3720.name: Nutrition, Health, and Aging

FNUT 4858L.description: Application of the management process to institutional food service systems. Thirteen hours supervised practice, one hour lecture per week.
FNUT 4858L.prereq: Restricted to Coordinated Program in Dietetics.
FNUT 4858L.name: Food Systems Management Laboratory

FNUT 4885.description: Supervised practice providing opportunities to integrate application and management of medical nutrition therapy into professional practice. Fifteen lecture hours and 280 clinical experience hours. Restricted to Coordinated Program in Dietetics.
FNUT 4885.name: Practicum in Dietetics

FNUT 4874L.description: Selected clinical experiences providing opportunities for application of the nutrition care process and wellness education to individuals and groups in the community setting. Sixteen hours clinical experiences, one hour lecture per week.
FNUT 4874L.prereq: Restricted to Coordinated Program in Dietetics.
FNUT 4874L.name: Community Nutrition and Wellness Laboratory

FNUT 4802L.description: Application of basic concepts of research methodology and statistics to dietetic practice. Three hours lab per week. Permit required.
FNUT 4802L.name: Research Methods in Dietetics Laboratory

TRUM 4804.description: Private Music Lessons.Gen Ed: Capstone, Capstone.
TRUM 4804.name: Trumpet

TRUM 4802.description: Private Music Lessons.Gen Ed: Capstone, Capstone.
TRUM 4802.name: Trumpet

TRUM 4806.description: Private Music Lessons.Gen Ed: Capstone, Capstone.
TRUM 4806.name: Trumpet

CHEN 6990.description: Research selected and supervised by departmental advisor. May be repeated for a maximum of nine semester hours.
CHEN 6990.name: Thesis

CHEN 4882L.description: Experimental studies in process dynamics and control. Treatment of experimental data with correlation and comparison with theory. Oral presentations and preparation of technical reports. Three hours of laboratory.
CHEN 4882L.name: Process Dynamics Laboratory

CHEN 2630.description: Physics, chemistry, and calculus applications to problems in general engineering with focus on EIT/FE exam questions, strength and properties of materials. Topics include: mechanics, dynamics, kinematics, conservation equations. Three-hour computational lab.
CHEN 2630.name: Applied Engineering 1

CHEN 5830.description: Neutron interactions and scattering; moderation ratio, the steady state reactor core and four factor equation, the diffusion equation for various reactor geometries and the reflected reactor core.
CHEN 5830.name: Nuclear Reactors

CHEN 5850.description: A fundamental approach to the design of industrial chemical processes. Emphasis upon flow-charting, chemical reactions, separations involved, thermodynamics, and economic considerations. Food and pharmaceutical processing is a major focus.
CHEN 5850.name: Industrial Processes

CHEN 4822.description: Survey of raw materials, manufacturing methods, and design of products utilizing reinforcing materials combined with an elastomer or polymer binder.
CHEN 4822.name: Reinforced Polymer Structures

CHEN 4881.description: Chemical reaction equilibria. Theoretical developments and methods of interpreting experimental data pertaining to chemical kinetics. General design principles and construction features of reactors with application of these principles to the design of specific reactors.
CHEN 4881.name: Chemical Reactor Design 2

CHEN 4880.description: Chemical reaction equilibria. Theoretical developments and methods of interpreting experimental data pertaining to chemical kinetics. General design principles and construction features of reactors with application of these principles to the design of specific reactors.
CHEN 4880.name: Chemical Reactor Design 1

CHEN 5835.description: Fusion reactors; the kinetics of fusion reactions. Plasma confinement technology.
CHEN 5835.name: Introduction to Nuclear Fusion

CHEN 4882.description: Introduction to automatic control and control loop concepts. Laplace transform techniques. Linear open-loop and closed-loop systems. Root-locus and frequency response methods. Design of control systems.
CHEN 4882.name: Process Dynamics

CHEN 4887.description: An examination of engineering economic analysis to include: cost estimation, profitability, optimum design, principles of fixed and operating costs, materials and site selection, and general and specialized design techniques.
CHEN 4887.prereq: CHEN 3787 and unrecalculated GPA of 2.0 or better in major courses.
CHEN 4887.name: Process and Plant Design 1

CHEN 2684.description: Cascade theory and design of staged separation processes. Concepts of reflux, algebraic solutions for linear systems and graphical methods of analysis. Design of distillation columns and stagewise separations. Continuation of topics discussed in CHEN 2683.
CHEN 2684.name: Chemical Engineering Principles 2

CHEN 4888.description: The application of chemical engineering and cost principles to the component design and selection of process equipment. The application of chemical engineering and cost principles to the design of chemical plants and processes including societal aesthetic, environmental, and safety considerations.
CHEN 4888.name: Process and Plant Design 2

CHEN 4845.description: Modeling of processes from unit operations, transport phenomena, and thermodynamics. Topics include the determination of limiting and generalized operating conditions, estimations of operating variables, and process balance of energy, mass, and momentum transfer.
CHEN 4845.name: Chemical Engineering Analysis

CHEN 4840.description: Design of biological reactors, bioremediation schemes, methods for the purification and mass production of chemical species from living organisms or cultures, extraction, and fermentation. Technologies and processing of recombinant DNA, antibiotics, antibodies, vitamins, steroids, and methane are included. Essentials of microbiology, biochemistry, and genetics will precede industrial applications.
CHEN 4840.name: Biochemical Engineering Fundamentals

CHEN 4801.description: Chemical engineering projects under the guidance of a faculty member. Literature search, design and construction of apparatus, experimentation and preparation of a comprehensive report.
CHEN 4801.name: Chemical Engineering Projects

CHEN 4803.description: Chemical engineering projects under the guidance of a faculty member. Literature search, design and construction of apparatus, experimentation and preparation of a comprehensive report.
CHEN 4803.name: Chemical Engineering Projects

CHEN 4802.description: Chemical engineering projects under the guidance of a faculty member. Literature search, design and construction of apparatus, experimentation and preparation of a comprehensive report.
CHEN 4802.name: Chemical Engineering Projects

CHEN 3718.description: An overview of the role women have played in scientific and technological advances. Problems unique to women entering scientific professions will be addressed, information about scientific and technical careers and job opportunities and contacts with professionals in the community will be provided.
CHEN 3718.name: Women, Science, and Technology

CHEN 2631.description: Physics, chemistry, and calculus applications to problems in general engineering with focus on EIT/FE exam questions, strength and properties of materials. Topics include: wave phenomena (light, sound), electricity (circuits), magnetism, materials, strength of materials. Three-hour computational lab.
CHEN 2631.name: Applied Engineering 2

CHEN 3772.description: Development of the concepts and formalisms of thermodynamics and their applications to chemical engineering systems. Real and ideal behavior of single and multicomponent systems. Introduction to the thermodynamics of phase equilibria. Analysis and design of thermal systems. Additional topics include applications in transport phenomena and plant design.
CHEN 3772.name: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics 2

CHEN 3771.description: Development of the concepts and formalisms of thermodynamics and their applications to chemical engineering systems. Real and ideal behavior of single and multicomponent systems. Introduction to the thermodynamics of phase equilibria. Analysis and design of thermal systems. Additional topics include applications in transport phenomena and plant design.
CHEN 3771.name: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics 1

CHEN 5854.description: Introduction to causes and forms of corrosion, corrosion rate calculations, electrode potentials, electro-chemistry, corrosion testing, and effects of corrosion on mechanical properties. Theory and use of corrosion inhibition methods.
CHEN 5854.prereq: Junior or Senior Standing or Approval of the Instructor.
CHEN 5854.name: Corrosion Engineering

CHEN 2650.description: Application of computational software packages and spreadsheets to solve chemical engineering problems. Utilization of process simulation packages. Real-time computing applications in laboratory automation.
CHEN 2650.prereq: ENGR 1560, ENGR 1560H or consent of instructor.
CHEN 2650.name: Computer Methods in Chemical Engineering

CHEN 6985.description: Thermodynamics of batteries, and electric and fuel cells. Power from nuclear isotopes. Features common to rotating electromagnetic fields. Analysis and design of electromechanical power components.
CHEN 6985.name: Electromechanical Motion Devices

CHEN 6983.description: Analytical and descriptive study of modern power plants. Combustion and environmental problems with fossil-fueled power plants. Electromagnetic circuits and devices with emphasis on the principles of electromechanical energy conversions.
CHEN 6983.name: Modern Power Sources

CHEN 6981.description: Advances topics in chemical reaction engineering including non-elementary reaction kinetics, reactor design for autocatalytic reactions, temperature and energy effects in chemical reactions, heterogeneous catalysis, catalyst preparation, fabrication and activation.
CHEN 6981.name: Advanced Chemical Reaction Engineering

CHEN 5820.description: Types, sources and effects of industrial and hazardous waste; principles of industrial and hazardous waste control; discussion and design of biological, physical, and chemical treatment processes.
CHEN 5820.name: Industrial Pollution Control

CHEN 5821.description: The survey of polymerization mechanisms, polymer structure-property relationships, transport properties, flammability-related plasticizers and solvents as well as design applications.
CHEN 5821.name: Fundamentals of Polymer Science

CHEN 5845.description: Introduction to causes and forms of corrosion, corrosion rate calculations, electrode potentials, electrochemistry, corrosion testing, and effects of corrosion on mechanical properties. Theory and use of corrosion inhibition methods.
CHEN 5845.name: Corrosion Engineering

CHEN 5800.description: Special topics and new developments in chemical engineering. Subject matter, credit hours, and special prerequisites to be announced in advance of each offering.
CHEN 5800.name: Special Topics

CHEN 3785L.description: Experimental studies of transport properties and momentum, energy and mass transfer using industrial type equipment. Correlation of data and comparison with theory. Oral presentations and preparation of technical reports. Three hours laboratory.
CHEN 3785L.name: Transport Phenomena Laboratory

CHEN 2688.description: Concept of energy assessment. Technology of energy production that includes coal gasification, liquefaction, magnetohydrodynamics, utilization of shale oil, solar, geothermal, and chemical energy. Nuclear energy utilization. Fuel from wastes. Energy resource distribution and future supply and demand. Simple calculations relating to fuel saving, production, and consumption. Primarily for non-engineering students.
CHEN 2688.name: Energy Assessment

CHEN 5805.description: Application of engineering principles and methods of analysis to processes in the human body. Rheological, physical and chemical properties of body fluids. Dynamics of the circulatory system. The human thermal system. Transport through cell membranes. Analysis and design of artificial organs.
CHEN 5805.name: Principles of Biomedical Engineering

CHEN 3787L.description: Experiments in absorption, cascade operations, reaction kinetics, mixing and other chemical engineering operations employing industrial and pilot plant size equipment and instrumentation. Treatment of experimental data, correlations and comparison with theory. Oral presentations and preparation of technical reports. Three hour laboratory.
CHEN 3787L.name: Unit Operations Laboratory 1

CHEN 2681.description: To aid the non-chemical engineer to organize, analyze, and effectively utilize the information inherent in chemically stoichiometric relationships, as they apply to actual plant situations.
CHEN 2681.name: Industrial Stoichiometry

CHEN 6984.description: Energy available from fission and fusion nuclear reactions, on setting and maintaining chain reaction. Mechanical and electromagnetic confinement techniques. Reactor design, heat removal, and safety problems.
CHEN 6984.name: Nuclear Fission and Fusion Power Sources

CHEN 2683.description: Engineering units and dimensions. Methods of analysis and measurement. Perfect gas and real gas relationships. Material and energy balances for both non-flow and flow systems.
CHEN 2683.name: Chemical Engineering Principles 1

CHEN 5811.description: Development of basic differential balance equations for mass, momentum and energy. Analytical and approximate solutions to the equation of change with application to the analysis of common engineering problems.
CHEN 5811.name: Advanced Transport Phenomena

CHEN 3700.description: Computer application in real-time data acquisition and laboratory data processing. Measurements of physical and chemical properties. Oral presentations and preparation of technical reports.
CHEN 3700.name: Measurement Laboratory

CHEN 5810.description: Industrial processing facilities, and the engineers and business people that run them. Decision-making perspectives and the technical and communication skills of each group are compared. Focus is on quality control, R&D, and efficiency.
CHEN 5810.name: The Business of Engineering

CHEN 5883.description: The applications of advanced mathematics to the solution of chemical engineering problems. Topics covered include treatment and interpretation of engineering data, modeling of chemical engineering systems and formulation of ordinary and partial differential equations governing chemical engineering operations and their solutions by use of numerical and analytical techniques.
CHEN 5883.name: Mathematical Methods in Chemical Engineering

CHEN 3726.description: Basic engineering science to serve as background material for nuclear reactor design. Nuclear fission as an energy source. Reactor use and classification. Comprehensive discussion of reactor design problems such as neutron distribution in the core, type of moderator, heat removal, and radiation protection.
CHEN 3726.name: Elementary Nuclear Reactor Engineering

CHEN 3721.description: Preparation, characterization, manufacture, properties and applications of commercial polymers.
CHEN 3721.prereq: CHEN 2684 and CHEM 3719; or consent of instructor.
CHEN 3721.name: Engineering Plastics

CHEN 4815.description: Gas absorption and desorption, interphase mass transfer processes, liquid extraction and leaching. Physical separation processes including filtration, settling, and size reduction. Derivation of the design equations for the above processes, and applications of the design equations to equipment design.
CHEN 4815.name: Unit Operations 2

CHEN 4815L.description: Experiments in absorption, cascade operations, reaction kinetics, mixing and other chemical engineering operations employing industrial and pilot plant size equipment and instrumentation. Treatment of experimental data, correlations and comparison with theory. Oral presentations and preparation of technical reports. Three hour laboratory.
CHEN 4815L.name: Unit Operations Laboratory 2

CHEN 3787.description: Mass transfer processes. Diffusional operations and separation processes with emphasis on evaporation, humidification and drying. Derivation of design equations from mass and energy balances, and application to equipment design. Solution of simultaneous differential equations of mass, momentum, and energy.
CHEN 3787.name: Transport Phenomena 2/Unit Operations 1

CHEN 3786.description: Mathematical formulation of conversion laws. Dimensional analysis. Mechanism and fundamentals of momentum and energy transfer with selected applications to analysis and design of chemical engineering equipment. Three hours lecture and three hours computational lab per week.
CHEN 3786.name: Transport Phenomena 1

CHEN 5886.description: The steady state reactor core; four-factor equation, resonance escape probability, neutron flux distribution in various geometrics, two-group and multigroup theories. Transient reactor behavior and control; effect of delayed neutrons, fission product poisoning, nuclear fuels, nuclear heat transfer and burnout problems, reactor economy; fuel burnup and power cost. Thermal breeder and fast reactors. Neutron flux distribution measurements. Radiation detection and monitoring.
CHEN 5886.name: Nuclear Reactor Design

ESOL 1522.description: Designed for students who have minimal exposure to listening in English and who do not yet have the skills necessary for enrollment in Intermediate English Listening courses. Does not count toward a degree. 2 s.h.
ESOL 1522.name: Basic English Listening 1

ESOL 1523.description: Designed for students who have had a small amount of exposure to listening in English and who do not yet have the skills necessary for enrollment in Intermediate English Listening courses. Does not count toward a degree.2 s.h.

ESOL 1533.description: Designed for students who have had a small amount of exposure to spoken English. They are usually able to understand the general meaning and some details of conversations on familiar subjects and make themselves understood by most people, but do not yet have the skills for enrollment in Intermediate English Speaking courses. Does not count toward a degree.
ESOL 1533.name: Basic English Speaking 2

ESOL 1532.description: Designed for students who have had minimal exposure to spoken English, but are able to understand the general meaning of conversations and make themselves understood by most people. ESOL 1532.name: Basic English Speaking 1

ESOL 1535.description: Designed for students who have had moderate exposure to spoken English. They are able to manage most communicative tasks and social situations, but do not yet have the skills necessary for enrollment in High Intermediate English Speaking courses. Does not count toward a degree.

ESOL 1534.description: Designed for students who have had moderate exposure to spoken English. They are able to manage most communicative tasks and social situations, but do not yet have the skills necessary for enrollment in High Intermediate English Speaking courses. ESOL 1544.description: Designed for students who have had moderate exposure to English grammar. Students at this level should demonstrate an understanding of and appropriate usage of the grammatical structures and the proficiencies of Basic English Grammar 2. Students build on and develop a better grasp of more complex grammatical forms and syntax. Focus begins to center on developing grammar skills necessary for an academic environment. (Some topics comprise a review.) Students do not yet have the skills to advance to Intermediate English Grammar 2. Does not count toward a degree.
ESOL 1544.name: Intermediate English Grammar 1

ESOL 1537.description: Designed for students who have had significant exposure to spoken English. They are able to sustain speech in everyday activities and routine school situations. Native speakers have little difficulty in understanding them, but they do not yet have the skills necessary for enrollment in Advanced English Speaking courses. Does not count toward a degree.

ESOL 1545.description: Designed for students who have had moderate exposure to English grammar. Students at this level should demonstrate an understanding of and appropriate usage of the grammatical structures and the proficiencies of Intermediate Grammar 1. Students build on and develop a better grasp of more complex grammatical forms and syntax. Focus begins to center on developing grammar skills necessary for an academic environment. (Some topics comprise a review.) Students in Intermediate English Grammar 2 do not yet have the skills to advance to High Intermediate English Grammar 1. Does not count toward a degree.

ESOL 1530.description: Designed for students who have had very limited exposure to spoken English, have difficulty with pronunciation and oral response, and do not yet have the skills to necessary for enrollment in Basic English Speaking courses. Does not count toward a degree.

ESOL 1531.description: Designed for students who have had limited exposure to spoken English, have difficulty with pronunciation and oral response, and do not yet have the skills to necessary for enrollment in Basic English Speaking courses. Does not count toward a degree.

ESOL 1548.description: Designed for students who have had modest exposure to English grammar. Students should demonstrate an understanding of and appropriate usage of the grammatical structures and the proficiencies of High Intermediate Grammar 2. Focus in centered on the further development of grammar and syntax skills proficiencies necessary for success in an academic setting. Students in Advanced English Grammar 1 do not yet have the skills to advance to Advanced English Grammar 2. Does not count toward a degree.

Students at this level should demonstrate an understanding of and appropriate usage of grammatical structures and proficiencies. They do not yet have the skills to advance to Introductory English Grammar 2. Does not count toward a degree.

Students in Introductory Grammar 2 do not yet have the skills to advance to Basic English Grammar 1. Does not count toward a degree.

Students in Basic English Grammar 1 do not yet have the skills to advance to Basic Grammar 2. Does not count toward a degree.

CHEM 6969.description: A laboratory course that stresses individual effort in solving chemical problems. Recommended for high school chemistry teachers. Not applicable to the M.S. degree in chemistry. May be repeated up to six semester hours.
CHEM 6969.name: Laboratory Problems

CHEM 3740.description: Principles and applications of quantum mechanic and statistical thermodynamics to chemical systems. Three hours lecture, three hours lab-discussion.
CHEM 3740.name: Physical Chemistry 2

CHEM 4891.description: Topics selected by the faculty from fields of current research interest or of special emphasis. May be repeated with different topics.
CHEM 4891.name: Special Topics

CHEM 6921.prereq: CHEM 3720, or concurrently with CHEM 3737 or CHEM 3739.
CHEM 6921.name: Advanced Biochemistry 1

CHEM 4850.description: Research planning, design, and execution including literature survey techniques, proposal writing, and critical scientific analysis. The student gives an oral presentation of a research proposal for CHEM 4850L, or on another topic as approved by the instructor.
CHEM 4850.prereq: CHEM 2604 or CHEM 3719 and approval of department chairperson.Gen Ed: Capstone.
CHEM 4850.name: Chemistry Research

CHEM 3785L.description: Analysis and separation techniques of biochemistry. Three hours lab-discussion.Prereq. or concurrent: CHEM 3785.
CHEM 3785L.name: Biochemistry Laboratory

CHEM 6933.description: The determination of molecular-level structures of biological, organic, and inorganic compounds in the gas phase, solution, and solid state by diffraction and spectroscopic methods, especially X-ray crystallography and NMR spectroscopy. Three hours lecture.
CHEM 6933.prereq: CHEM 5822, CHEM 5832, or permission of instructor.
CHEM 6933.name: Physical Methods in Structure Determination

CHEM 6972.description: Principles of chemistry education research. Issues of problem design, data collection, and data analysis are considered from both quantitative and qualitative frameworks. Methodologies include surveys and questionnaires, think-along protocols, interviews, observations, and action research. Also includes examination of these issues as related to biology.
CHEM 6972.name: Methods of Chemistry Education Research

CHEM 6989.description: Topics selected by the faculty from fields of current research, pedagogical interest, or special emphasis. S/U grading option. May be repeated with different topics.
CHEM 6989.name: Special Topics in Chemistry Practicum

CHEM 1506R.description: Discussion and problem solving exercises to complement and enhance study in CHEM 1506.Concurrent with: CHEM 1506.
CHEM 1506R.name: Recitation for Allied Health Chemistry 2

CHEM 5876.description: Advanced biochemistry laboratory focusing on the methods of enzyme purification and characterization. One hour lecture, two hours lab.
CHEM 5876.prereq: CHEM 3785 or equivalent and CHEM 3785L or equivalent.
CHEM 5876.name: Enzyme Analysis

CHEM 3720R.description: An introduction to the preparation and analysis of organic compounds. Discussion of CHEM 3720 material and approaches to problem solving. Required for chemistry majors.Concurrent with: CHEM 3720.
CHEM 3720R.name: Organic Chemistry Recitation 2

CHEM 1516.description: A continuation of the study of the principles of chemistry, including solution properties; acids and bases; chemical equilibrium; thermodynamics; reaction kinetics; and electrochemistry. Intended for majors in the natural sciences and engineering. Three hours lecture, three hours lab-discussion.
CHEM 1516.prereq: "C" or better in CHEM 1515; Concurrent: CHEM 1516L; CHEM 1516R if major or repeating CHEM 1516.Gen Ed: Science Substitute.
CHEM 1516.name: General Chemistry 2

CHEM 5832.description: The determination of structures of biological, organic, and inorganic materials in the solid state. Introduction to the crystalline state, defects, diffraction of waves, powder and single crystal diffraction methods of neutron and x-ray analysis, electron microscopy, and solid state NMR. Two hours lecture, three hours lab.
CHEM 5832.name: Solid State Structural Methods

CHEM 1506.description: Fundamentals of organic and biological chemistry including applications to the human organism. Two hours lecture, three hours lab-discussion.
CHEM 1506.name: Allied Health Chemistry 2

CHEM 5830.description: Reactions and descriptive chemistry of transition metal, organometallic, and main-group compounds.
CHEM 5830.name: Intermediate Inorganic Chemistry

CHEM 2650.description: Introduction to the methods of chemical research under the direction of a faculty member. May include literature search and analysis, instructional laboratory development, and/or original basic or applied research. May be repeated to a maximum of 4 s.h.Prereq. or concurrent: CHEM 1516 and approval of department chairperson.
CHEM 2650.name: Introduction to Undergraduate Research

CHEM 5836.description: Basic principles of quantum chemistry, with applications to problems in molecular structure, spectroscopy and thermodynamics.
CHEM 5836.name: Quantum Chemistry

CHEM 6911.description: Theory and applications of spectroscopy and theory of chemical separation methods.
CHEM 6911.name: Advanced Analytical Chemistry 1

CHEM 6912.description: Applications of chemical separation methods and theory and applications of electrochemistry and electrochemical techniques.
CHEM 6912.name: Advanced Analytical Chemistry 2

CHEM 6973.description: Implications of national standards for modifying high school chemistry instruction in a variety of classroom situations. Topics include inquiry learning, science and technology literacy, the history and nature of science, preservice science teacher education, assessment, and the impact of standards on advanced placement chemistry.
CHEM 6973.name: Chemistry and National Science Education Standards

CHEM 6952.description: Molecular basis of thermodynamics and kinetics.
CHEM 6952.name: Advanced Physical Chemistry 2

CHEM 6932.description: Transtition metal organometallic chemistry emphasizing molecular structure, bonding methods, characterization, and functional group reactivity. The properties, chemical reactivity, and trends of the elements.
CHEM 6932.prereq: CHEM 5830, CHEM 6931, or permission of instructor.
CHEM 6932.name: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry 2

CHEM 5862.description: Polymer rheology, processing methods, and materials characterization. The effects of additives and the major classes of thermoplastic, thermoset, elastomeric, and composite materials. Two hours lecture, three hours lab.
CHEM 5862.prereq: CHEM 5861 or consent of the chairperson.
CHEM 5862.name: Polymer Science 2: Polymer Rheology, Processing, and Composites

CHEM 6931.description: Current theories and types of bonding. Modern structural principles with applications in main-group molecular compounds, coordination compounds, and inorganic solids.
CHEM 6931.name: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry 1

CHEM 3719.description: Organic compounds, reactions and theories. Typical preparations and procedures of analysis. Three hours lecture, three hours lab-discussion.
CHEM 3719.name: Organic Chemistry 1

CHEM 1505.description: Introduction to the principles of chemistry including atomic structure, bonding, nomenclature, chemical calculations, chemical reactions, gas laws, solutions, acids and bases, and equilibrium. Intended for majors in allied health and other applied sciences. Two hours lecture, three hours lab-discussion.
CHEM 1505.prereq: CHEM 1501 or equivalent, MATH 1505 or MATH 1507 or equivalent.Concurrent CHEM 1505L.Gen Ed: Science Substitute.
CHEM 1505.name: Allied Health Chemistry 1

CHEM 3719R.description: An introduction to the preparation and analysis of organic compounds. Discussion of CHEM 3719 material and approaches to problem solving. Required for chemistry majors.Concurrent with: CHEM 3719.
CHEM 3719R.name: Organic Chemistry Recitation 1

CHEM 6976.description: Teaching strategies in the General Chemistry laboratory. Students will meet with General Chemistry course instructors and must demonstrate proficiency in the material to be presented in CHEM 1515 General Chemistry 1 and CHEM 1516 General Chemistry 2 laboratories. Grading for CHEM 6976 is S/U. May be repeated for a total of six semester hours for CHEM 6976, CHEM 6977, CHEM 6978, and CHEM 6979.Prereq. or concurrent: CHEM 6975.
CHEM 6976.name: Teaching Practicum in General Chemistry

CHEM 6977.description: Teaching strategies in the Allied Health Chemistry laboratory. Students will meet with Allied Health Chemistry course instructors and must demonstrate proficiency in the material to be presented in CHEM 1505 Allied Health Chemistry 1 and CHEM 1506 Allied Health Chemistry 2 laboratories. Grading for CHEM 6977 is S/U. CHEM 6977, CHEM 6978, and CHEM 6979. May be repeated for a total of six semester hours for CHEM 6976.Prereq. or concurrent: CHEM 6975.
CHEM 6977.name: Teaching Practicum in Allied Health Chemistry

CHEM 1500.description: Introduction to basic chemical concepts, the scientific method, and the impact of chemistry on human life and society. Examples may include water treatment, air quality, plastics, drugs, cosmetics, energy resources, food, and the chemical basis of life. Not intended for Chemistry majors.Gen Ed: Natural Science.
CHEM 1500.name: Chemistry in Modern Living

CHEM 1501.description: Metric units, dimensional analysis, chemical nomenclature, the mole concept, chemical stoichiometry. Emphasis on problem solving and the mathematics required for success in the study of chemistry. For students without high school chemistry and others needing preparation for CHEM 1505 or CHEM 1515. Three hours lecture, no laboratory.
CHEM 1501.prereq: MATH 1505 or MATH 1507 or one unit each of high school algebra and geometry.
CHEM 1501.name: An Introduction to Chemistry

CHEM 6978.description: Teaching strategies in the organic chemistry laboratory. Students will meet with organic chemistry course instructors and must demonstrate proficiency in the material to be presented in CHEM 3719 Organic Chemistry 1 and CHEM 3720 Organic Chemistry 2 laboratories. Grading for CHEM 6978 is S/U. May be repeated for a total of six semester hours for CHEM 6976, CHEM 6977, CHEM 6978, and CHEM 6979.Prereq. or concurrent: CHEM 6975.
CHEM 6978.name: Teaching Practicum in Organic Chemistry

CHEM 1500L.description: Introduction to basic laboratory techniques designed to supplement CHEM 1500. Three hours per week.Concurrent with: CHEM 1500.
CHEM 1500L.name: Chemistry in Modern Living Laboratory

CHEM 6971.description: An introduction to the current literature and research problems in the teaching and learning of chemistry. Topics include theories of teaching, learning styles, assessment, problem solving, misconceptions, and the role of laboratories, recitations, and demonstrations in learning chemistry. Also includes examination of these issues as related to teaching biology.
CHEM 6971.name: The Teaching and Learning of Chemistry

CHEM 6991.description: Topics selected by the faculty from fields of current research interest or of special emphasis. May be repeated with different topics.
CHEM 6991.name: Special Topics

CHEM 4850L.description: Research participation under the direction of a faculty member. The student prepares an acceptable written report on the completed project. May be repeated to a maximum of 5 s.h.Prereq. or concurrent : CHEM 4850 and approval of department chairperson.Gen Ed: Capstone.
CHEM 4850L.name: Chemistry Research Laboratory

CHEM 6982.description: Oral presentation and defense of thesis. Hours arranged.
CHEM 6982.prereq: CHEM 6981 and permission of the thesis advisor, or concurrently with six semester hours of CHEM 6990.
CHEM 6982.name: Seminar 2

CHEM 5862L.description: Polymer Science 2: Polymer Rheology, Processing, and Composites Laboratory.
CHEM 5862L.name: Polymer Science 2: Polymer Rheology, Processing, and Composites Laboratory

CHEM 1516R.description: Discussion and problem solving based on current material in CHEM 1516.Concurrent with: CHEM 1516.
CHEM 1516R.name: Recitation for General Chemistry 2

CHEM 3790.description: Students participate in departmental seminars and present a seminar to the class. May be repeated once.Prereq. or concurrent: CHEM 2604 and CHEM 3720.
CHEM 3790.name: Undergraduate Seminar

CHEM 6975.description: A course to prepare graduate students to serve as teaching assistants in both chemistry laboratories and recitations. Topics include laboratory safety (governmental regulations, ACS guidelines, hazardous materials, waste disposal) and practical matters of teaching (active learning, leading discussions, grading, cheating, etc.). Required of all graduate students serving as first-year teaching assistants.
CHEM 6975.name: An Introduction to Teaching Chemistry

CHEM 3739.description: Principles and applications of thermodynamics and kinetics to chemical systems. Three hours lecture, three hours lab-discussion.
CHEM 3739.prereq: "C" or better in CHEM 3720, PHYS 2611, PHYS 2611L, MATH 1572.
CHEM 3739.name: Physical Chemistry 1

CHEM 5831.description: Preparation of typical inorganic compounds and their characterization. Six hours lab-discussion.Prereq. or concurrent: CHEM 3729 and CHEM 3739.
CHEM 5831.name: Inorganic Chemistry Laboratory

CHEM 3720.description: Organic compounds, reactions and theories. Typical preparations and procedures of analysis. Three hours lecture, three hours lab-discussion.
CHEM 3720.name: Organic Chemistry 2

CHEM 5804.description: The theoretical foundations of instrumental procedures and the use of instruments in analytical work. Two hours lecture, six hours lab.
CHEM 5804.name: Chemical Instrumentation

CHEM 4860.description: Roles and responsibilities of industrial chemists. Industrial hygiene and safety. Industrial chemical processes, their waste products, their environmental effects, and the treatment of pollutants. Governmental regulations relating to waste disposal, product safety, occupational safety, resource conservation, environmental protection, and problems of awareness and compliance.
CHEM 4860.name: Regulatory Aspects of Industrial Chemistry

CHEM 5861L.description: Polymer Science 1: Polymer Chemistry and Plastics Laboratory.
CHEM 5861L.name: Polymer Science 1: Polymer Chemistry and Plastics Laboratory

CHEM 5861.description: Preparation, characterization, structure-property relationships, morphology, and uses of the major commercial polymers. Two hours lecture, three hours lab.
CHEM 5861.name: Polymer Science 1: Polymer Chemistry and Plastics

CHEM 5822.description: An advanced approach to the applications of organic chemistry in the laboratory. Synthesis and purification of organic molecules using modern techniques, structure elucidation using spectroscopic techniques. Lecture discussion includes use of instrumentation, planning of practical syntheses, use of the primary chemical literature and safety in the laboratory. Two hours lecture, six hours lab.
CHEM 5822.name: Advanced Organic Laboratory

CHEM 5821.description: An intermediate treatment of organic chemistry building on the principles introduced at the sophomore level. Emphasis on curved arrow notation in mechanism and the planning of organic syntheses. Structural analysis of organic compounds using NMR, IR and MS and the application of structural knowledge to questions of mechanism.
CHEM 5821.name: Intermediate Organic Chemistry

CHEM 3786.description: Intermediary metabolism and biochemical information pathways.
CHEM 3786.name: Biochemistry 2

CHEM 6941.description: Principles of chemical bonding and structure in organic molecules, physical organic chemistry, structure of reactive intermediates, stereochemistry, and detailed descriptions of reaction mechanisms.
CHEM 6941.prereq: CHEM 3721 Genetics and CHEM 3740 Physical Chemistry 2.
CHEM 6941.name: Advanced Organic Chemistry 1

CHEM 6979.description: Teaching strategies in the Chemistry in Modern Living Laboratory. Students will meet with course coordinator and must demonstrate proficiency in the material to be presented in CHEM 1500L. Grading for CHEM 6979 is S/U. May be repeated for a total of six semester hours for CHEM 6976, CHEM 6977, CHEM 6978, and CHEM 6979.Prereq. or concurrent: CHEM 6975.
CHEM 6979.name: Teaching Practicum for Chemistry in Modern Living Lab

CHEM 2602.description: Introduction to basic science concepts, the scientific method, and the impact of chemistry as a central science on society. Examples include works of African-American scientists.
CHEM 2602.name: African and African-American Contributions to Science

CHEM 3785.description: Structure and properties of biomolecules, including proteins, lipids, carbohydrates and nucleic acids. Introduction to glycolysis metabolic pathway.
CHEM 3785.name: Biochemistry 1

CHEM 2604.description: Chemical equilibrium, stoichiometry, theory of errors, and volumetric and gravimetric procedures as applied to quantitative determinations. Introduction to electroanalytical, chromatographic and spectrophotometric methods. Emphasis on development of technique. Three hours lecture, six hours lab.
CHEM 2604.name: Quantitative Analysis

CHEM 6980.description: Principles of chemical research planning, design, execution, and reporting. Includes research proposals, record keeping, written reports, oral presentations, the reviewing process, and professional standards. The application of the principles of chemical research to the student's M.S. research project. Required of all first-year students in the M.S. program in chemistry.
CHEM 6980.name: Introduction to Chemical Research

CHEM 6922.description: A study of metabolic pathways and other biochemical systems at the molecular level.
CHEM 6922.name: Advanced Biochemistry 2

CHEM 1515.description: An introduction to the fundamental principles of chemistry, including measurement and calculation; chemical stoichiometry; the properties of gases; atomic and molecular structure; bonding; thermochemistry; and periodic properties. Intended for majors in the natural sciences and engineering. Three hours lecture, three hours lab-discussion.
CHEM 1515.prereq: CHEM 1501 or equivalent; MATH 1513 or equivalent.Concurrent: CHEM 1515L; CHEM 1515R if major or repeating CHEM 1515.Gen Ed: Science Substitute.
CHEM 1515.name: General Chemistry 1

CHEM 3764.description: Introduction to the clinical, forensic, industrial, and environmental aspects of chemical toxicology. Therapeutic and toxic limits of drugs. Actions, controls and treatment of poisons and environmental agents.
CHEM 3764.name: Chemical Toxicology

CHEM 6963.description: Advanced methods of polymer synthesis and characterization, high performance polymers, polymerization kinetics and mechanisms, polymer processing, materials optimization, and high performance applications. Three hours lecture.
CHEM 6963.prereq: CHEM 3740 and CHEM 5861, or permission of the instructor.
CHEM 6963.name: Advanced Polymer Science

CHEM 1515R.description: Discussion and problem solving based on current material in CHEM 1515.Concurrent with: CHEM 1515.
CHEM 1515R.name: Recitation for General Chemistry 1

CHEM 6942.description: Detailed study of functional group transformations in organic synthesis as applied to the preparation of complex molecules. Carbon-carbon bond forming reactions, organometallic reagants in organic synthesis, oxidation-reduction chemistry, and multi-step synthesis.
CHEM 6942.name: Advanced Organic Chemistry 2

CHEM 1505R.description: Discussion and problem solving exercises to complement and enhance study in CHEM 1505.Concurrent with: CHEM 1505.
CHEM 1505R.name: Recitation for Allied Health Chemistry 1

CHEM 6951.description: Principles of quantum chemistry and spectroscopy with applications.
CHEM 6951.name: Advanced Physical Chemistry 1

CHEM 3729.description: Fundamental principles underlying the structure, bonding, and properties of the elements and molecular, solid state, and coordination compounds.Prereq. or concurrent: CHEM 3739.
CHEM 3729.name: Inorganic Chemistry

CHEM 6981.description: Preparation of a formal written research proposal and oral presentation of the proposal. Under the guidance of a research supervisor, the student will investigate the background literature and rationale for a project. Required of all first-year students in the M.S. program in chemistry. Hours arranged.
CHEM 6981.prereq: CHEM 6980 and permission of the Chemistry chair.
CHEM 6981.name: Seminar 1
