EET 4845.name: Microprocessor Systems 3

EET 2653.description: Light propagation in fiber; connections, attenuation, and signal distortion; splicing and analysis of coupling losses; optical transmitters and receivers for analog and digital signals. Two hours lecture, three hours lab per week.
EET 2653.prereq: "C" or better in EET 1502 and EET 1502L and EET 2605 and EET 2605L and MATH 1570.
EET 2653.name: Fiber Optics

EET 1502L.description: Measure effective values of AC currents and voltages, observe waveforms with oscilloscopes, verify impedance concepts and phasor diagrams for AC series/parallel networks and resonant circuits. Computer circuit analysis with PSPICE. Three hours per week.Concurrent with: EET 1502.
EET 1502L.name: Circuit Theory 2 Lab

EET 3780.description: Audio signals, noise, untuned and RF amplifiers, amplitude, frequency, pulse modulation, transmission lines, antennas, and multiplexing of communication channels.
EET 3780.prereq: "C" or better in the following: EET 1502, EET 1502L, EET 3706, EET 3706L, EET 3700, and MATH 2670.Concurrent with: EET 3780L.
EET 3780.name: Communication Systems

EET 2671.description: Use of personal computers as a data acquisition and control device in industrial processes. Specification, installation, troubleshooting or various I/O cards. Development of PC-based data acquisition and control system using commercially available software. Three hours lecture, three hours lab per week.
EET 2671.name: Computer Instrumentation and Control

EET 2670.description: Introduction to the principles and practice of measurement and control of temperature, pressure, flow, level, and other process variables commonly encountered in industrial systems. Includes characteristics, installation, and troubleshooting of process transducers, sensors, and detectors. Three hours lecture, three hours lab per week.Prereq. or concurrent: EET 2605, EET 2605L.
EET 2670.name: Process Instrumentation

EET 4850.description: Introduction to integrated circuits technology and typical application.
EET 4850.prereq: "C" or better in EET 3706 and EET 3706L and EET 1502 and EET 1502L and MATH 2670.Concurrent with: EET 4850L.
EET 4850.name: Integrated Circuit Applications

EET 2605L.description: Use of meters, oscilloscope, transistor curve tracer for experiments on diode characteristics, rectifier circuits, clippers, clampers, Zener regulators, BJT and FET characteristics, BJT bias circuits and amplifiers. Computer circuit analysis with PSPICE. Three hours per week.Concurrent with: EET 2605.
EET 2605L.name: Electronics 1 Laboratory

EET 4890.description: Special topics/new developments in electrical engineering technology. Subject matter, special prerequisites, and credit hours to be announced in advance of each offering. May be repeated with different subject matter to a maximum of 8 s.h.
EET 4890.prereq: Senior standing in EET or consent of the instructor.
EET 4890.name: Special Topics in EET

EET 1501.description: Theoretical analysis of DC electrical circuits including units conversions, current voltage, power, Ohms Law, Kirchhoffs Laws, network theorems, capacitance, magnetic circuits, inductance and transient analysis of RL and RC circuits. Prerequisite or concurrent: ENTC 1505, MATH 1513 or MATH 1510 and MATH 1511; concurrent with EET 1501L. 3 s.h.
EET 1501.name: Circuit Theory 1

EET 1502.description: Study of AC sinusoidal waveforms, phasor representations, phasor algebra and phasor diagrams. Solution of steady state single phase series/parallel networks including network theorems, power and power factor, resonant circuits, filters, mutual inductance, transformers and balanced three-phase systems.
EET 1502.prereq: "C" or better in EET 1501 and EET 1501L and MATH 1513, or MATH 1510 and MATH 1511, and ENTC 1505.Concurrent with: EET 1502L.
EET 1502.name: Circuit Theory 2

EET 3725.description: AC/DC circuit analysis techniques including network theorems, MultiSim computer circuit analysis with applications to AC/DC machinery, electronics, digital circuits and control systems. Three hours lecture per week.
EET 3725.prereq: C or better in MATH 1570 and ENTC 1505.Concurrent with: EET 3725L.
EET 3725.name: Electromechanical Systems

EET 3706.description: Field effect transistor (FET) bias circuits and amplifiers, thyristor circuits, frequency effects (Bode plots), differential amplifiers, linear and non-linear op amp circuits, active filters, oscillators and regulated power supplies.
EET 3706.prereq: "C" or better in EET 1502 and EET 1502L and EET 2605 and EET 2605L and MATH 1570.Concurrent with: EET 3706L.
EET 3706.name: Electronics 2

EET 4870.description: Application of Laplace transform solution of differential equations to system transfer functions. Development of control system transfer functions, control system components and analysis of linear control systems.
EET 4870.prereq: "C" or better in EET 1502 and EET 1502L and EET 3706 and EET 3706L and EET 3780 and EET 3780L and MATH 2670.
EET 4870.name: Process Control Technology

EET 3700.description: Review of circuit analysis techniques using phasor algebra; mesh and nodal analysis; Thevenin and Norton equivalents; superposition theorem; three phase circuits; circuit solutions using matrix methods; and Fourier analysis of periodic waveforms with applications to circuit analysis. Two hours lecture and three hours computational lab per week.  Taken concurrently with MATH 2670.
EET 3700.name: Methods in Circuit Analysis

EET 3701.description: Introduction to LaPlace transforms and the use of LaPlace transforms in circuit analysis, transfer functions, frequency response of networks, poles and zeroes, stability, Bode plots.  Two hours lecture and three hours of computational lab per week.
EET 3701.prereq: MATH 2670 and EET 3700 with a grade of "C" or better.
EET 3701.name: Transform Circuit Analysis

EET 3745.description: Continuation of EET 2645 with emphasis on advanced programming techniques, memory mapping, I/O ports, and basic I/O interfacing.
EET 3745.prereq: "C" or better in EET 3735 and EET 3735L and EET 1502 and EET 1502L and MATH 1513.Concurrent with: EET 3745L.
EET 3745.name: Microprocessor Systems 2

EET 3760.description: Introduction to electronic speed control of direct and alternating current motors. Power conversion and waveform modulation techniques, drive sizing, harmonics, and motor performance.
EET 3760.prereq: "C" or better in EET 3710 and EET 3710L and EET 3706 and EET 3706L, EET 3700, and MATH 2670.Concurrent with: EET 3760L.
EET 3760.name: Variable Speed Drives

EET 4820L.description: Establishing communications, programming, and testing of various microprocessor based power system protective relays, including time-overcurrent, bus, differential, motor, distributed generation, and transformer relays. Three hours lab per week.
EET 4820L.prereq: "C" or better in EET 3710 and EET 3710L and EET 3712 and EET 3712L.Concurrent with: EET 4820.
EET 4820L.name: Power System Protection and Control Lab

EET 3760L.description: Exercises in variable speed drive applications, demonstrating the concepts developed in EET 3760.Concurrent with: EET 3760.
EET 3760L.name: Variable Speed Drives Lab

EET 1501L.description: Use of electrical components to construct circuits and use of electrical instrumentation including meters and oscilloscopes to analyze DC resistive series/parallel networks and basic RC & RL transient circuits. Computer circuit analysis with PSPICE. Three hours per week.Concurrent with: EET 1501.
EET 1501L.name: Circuit Theory 1 Lab

EET 3706L.description: Experiments involving field effect transistors (FETs), integrated circuits (ICs), operational amplifiers, frequency effects on gain, oscillator circuits and regulated power supplies. Computer circuit analysis with PSPICE. Three hours per week.Concurrent with: EET 3706.
EET 3706L.name: Electronics 2 Laboratory

FOUN 6902.description: Selected sociological concepts and theories will form the basis for a critical analysis of schooling. Special attention will be given to the emergence of schools and to how schools serve diverse populations.
FOUN 6902.name: Sociological Bases of Education

FOUN 8102.description: An explorative study of constructs and concepts of cultural diversity within groups based on notions of class, race, sex, ethnicity, ableness, and religion/spiritualties. Consideration of expectations and organizational practices as informed by diversity issues.
FOUN 8102.prereq: Doctoral admission and one of the following: FOUN 6901, FOUN 6902, or FOUN 6905.
FOUN 8102.name: Perspectives on Leadership Among Diverse Populations

FOUN 8104.description: An examination of major research methodologies and a preview of the different paradigms and assumptions that underlie controlled disciplined inquiries. Techniques associated with particular methodologies in educational administration will be introduced, and their strengths and weaknesses will be analyzed.
FOUN 8104.name: Research Strategies in Educational Administration

FOUN 1501.description: Historical, political, legal, cultural and ethical perspectives on the work and roles of teachers and schooling. Issues confronting educators, voters, parents and children. Twenty-five hours of field work, orienting students to classrooms and to the organization and governance of school districts.
FOUN 1501.name: Introduction to Education

FOUN 5880.description: An advanced study of sociological, historical, and/or philosophically based research which provides analysis of a particular educational issue with special emphasis on implications for diverse populations and/or diverse school settings.
FOUN 5880.name: Special Topics in Foundations of Education

FOUN 6982.description: Individual investigation of advanced topics under the guidance of selected department faculty. May be repeated.
FOUN 6982.name: Independent Study/Action Research

FOUN 6990.description: Selected topics for an advanced study of a topic to be addressed from a sociological, historical, philosophical, assessment, or research perspective.
FOUN 6990.prereq: Completion of a master's degree or advanced licensure.
FOUN 6990.name: Advanced Seminar in Foundations of Education

FOUN 6905.description: Critical analysis of first-person and other historical accounts of teachers, students, communities, and school reforms as they inform curricular, professional, and social challenges that face educators in their communities today.
FOUN 6905.name: Educational Challenges in Historical Perspective

FOUN 6995.description: A workshop designed for the development of particular skills and/or perspectives on a school-related topic.
FOUN 6995.name: Workshop in the Foundations of Education

FOUN 8112.description: Consideration of traditional and evolving qualitative methods and literature that apply to doctoral study of problems in teaching, school leadership, and school change.
FOUN 8112.name: Qualitative Research for Educators

FOUN 8111.description: An in-depth treatment of the major correlational, experimental, and quasi-experimental research designs and associated statistical analyses, including the design and analysis of surveys and factor analytic techniques. Experience in data analysis using SPSS or other statistical packages. 3 s.h. Cross  listed with EDAD 8111.
FOUN 8111.name: Advanced Research Design and Statistics

FOUN 3710.description: Critical review of types, purposes, procedures, uses, and limitations of assessment strategies and techniques including authentic assessment, value-added assessment, and alternate assessment. Standardized testing and implications for current practice.
FOUN 3710.name: Educational Assessment

FOUN 5875.description: Selected topics for a focused study on problems, issues, or concerns to be addressed by a sociological, historical, philosophical, assessment, or research perspective.
FOUN 5875.name: Seminar in Foundations of Education

FOUN 6901.description: A philosophical examination and critical reflection on educational theories, including a familiarization with historical contexts and socio/cultural conditions that fostered and related resistance to these theories.
FOUN 6901.name: Philosophical Analysis of Education

FOUN 6914.description: An introductory course in frequency distributions, measures of central tendency, measures of variability, calculations and meaning of percentiles, normal distribution theory, reliability and validity of measures, and basic statistical analysis.
FOUN 6914.name: Statistical Methods in Education

FOUN 6904.description: Basic methodologies and techniques of educational research design and elementary statistical concepts are introduced. This course relies on critical thinking and analytical discourse for the examination and evaluation of research studies.
FOUN 6904.name: Introduction to Educational Research

FOUN 3708.description: School as a dynamic social institution. An analysis of how schools interact with diverse communities and with social, political, and cultural institutions and traditions. Twenty-five hours of field research.
FOUN 3708.prereq: Admission to the College of Education or permission of chairperson.
FOUN 3708.name: Education and Society

FOUN 8113.description: Perspectives for critical analysis, investigation of ways of knowing, and an examination of criteria that have been used successfully for negotiating status and justifying claims within contested domains of inquiry. 3 s.h.
FOUN 8113.prereq: FOUN 8104 and EDAD 8111/FOUN 8111.Cross listed with EDAD 8113.
FOUN 8113.name: Theories of Inquiry

EMCE 6919.description: Objectives of elementary school social studies programs in terms of current needs; adaptation of materials of instruction in terms of the social science skills; evaluation of student progress; critical analysis of methods of improving instruction in social studies.
EMCE 6919.name: Social Studies Programs in the Elementary School

EMCE 5854.description: Students will analyze and reflect on major concepts, research, and theories about the physical, cognitive, emotional, moral, and social development of students in grades 4-9 and research information concerning the historic, philosophical, and organizational components of middle level schools, including program assessment and evaluation of learning environments.
EMCE 5854.name: Middle School Theory and Practice

EMCE 7042.description: A restricted professional development course for classroom teacher educators invited to supervise the instructional program of student teachers and field experience students. The course concentrates on developing analytical observation, conferencing, evaluation, and supervision skills based on scientific knowledge and theoretical constructs.
EMCE 7042.prereq: Invitation from YSU and endorsement from home school district to serve as a classroom teacher educator.Cross-listed: SPED 7042 and SED 7042.
EMCE 7042.name: Professional Development for Classroom Teacher Educators

EMCE 4815.description: Critical study of current developments in objectives, methods, materials, and evaluation in science education as they affect the elementary science program. Includes discussions, field trips, demonstrations and laboratory work.
EMCE 4815.name: Seminar in Elementary School Science

EMCE 5812.description: Candidates will learn language arts and social studies teaching methods, design integrated lessons, incorporate state and national standards, and utilize assessment methods for grades 4-5.
EMCE 5812.name: Integrated Language Arts and Social Studies for 4th and 5th Grades

EMCE 5811.description: By exploring math and science teaching practice for grades 4-5, the candidates will review teaching methods of math and science, master the contents stated in the Ohio Academic Standards, find and design math and science programs and lessons and strengthen the assessment methods for the classroom instruction.
EMCE 5811.name: Early Childhood Generalist: Math and Science

EMCE 6918.description: An analysis of past and present programs of elementary school mathematics; evaluation of programs, including a consideration of adequacy of content, recognition of mathematics as a system, and provision of number experiences for the learner.
EMCE 6918.name: Elementary School Mathematics Programs

EMCE 5816.description: In-depth study of diagnosis and remediation as they affect the elementary school mathematics program. Includes discussions, field trips, demonstrations and laboratory work.
EMCE 5816.name: Diagnosis and Remediation of Elementary School Mathematics

EMCE 6920.description: Focus on the objectives for science education in the elementary school; the elementary school science curriculum; process and inquiry in the elementary school science curriculum; process and inquiry in the elementary school science program; teacher education; educational media; and the evaluation of science teaching.
EMCE 6920.name: Elementary School Science Programs

EMCE 6921.description: A study of recent trends in elementary school organization and instruction (non-graded units, team teaching, middle schools, etc.) Developing an understanding of the meaning of curriculum at the elementary level, evidence of need for curricular changes, influences of society on curriculums, exploration of current status and trends; and the role of teacher and administrator in curriculum appraisal and development.
EMCE 6921.name: Issues, Problems, Developments, and Curriculum in Elementary Education

EMCE 5901.description: Intensive study of selected topics, issues, or problems of current interest in early and/or middle childhood education. Grading is S/U. May be repeated.
EMCE 5901.name: Early/Middle Childhood Education Workshop

EMCE 5900.description: Intensive study of selected topics, issues, or problems of current interest in early and/or middle childhood education. Grading is S/U. May be repeated.
EMCE 5900.name: Early/Middle Childhood Education Workshop

EMCE 5903.description: Intensive study of selected topics, issues, or problems of current interest in early and/or middle childhood education. Grading is S/U. May be repeated.
EMCE 5903.name: Early/Middle Childhood Education Workshop

EMCE 5902.description: Intensive study of selected topics, issues, or problems of current interest in early and/or middle childhood education. Grading is S/U. May be repeated.
EMCE 5902.name: Early/Middle Childhood Education Workshop

MUHL 5879.description: A study of vocal literature from all periods. Special emphasis on English language repertoire and on material especially suitable for high school students. Songs are prepared for performance in class.
MUHL 5879.prereq: MUTC 2632, MUHL 3771, MUHL 3772, MUHL 3773, and MUHL 3774.
MUHL 5879.name: Vocal Literature

MUHL 3787.description: (General) Illustrated lectures on art and music to develop the cultural growth of the non-art and non-music student. Art and music forms, comparisons of compositional styles, and discussion of the developments, influences, and experiments of the important periods to date. No prior training in art or music required. Not intended for Art majors. Listed also as ART 3787.
MUHL 3787.name: History and Appreciation of Art and Music

MUHL 6990.description: Individual research and writing culminating in the preparation of a master's thesis.
MUHL 6990.prereq: Completion of 15 semester hours coursework and approval of thesis proposal by the Dana Graduate Committee.
MUHL 6990.name: Thesis 1

MUHL 5874.description: Musical developments from Beethoven through Wagner; aesthetic, formal, technical and historical trends with special emphasis on nationalism and the music drama.
MUHL 5874.prereq: MUTC 2632, MUHL 3771, MUHL 3772, MUHL 3773, and MUHL 3774.
MUHL 5874.name: Nineteenth Century

MUHL 5871.description: The evolution of musical styles during the period 1600-1750. A historical survey of documents and music literature of the time: opera from Monteverdi to Handel; keyboard and instrumental works; significant choral works, etc.
MUHL 5871.prereq: MUTC 2632, MUHL 3771, MUHL 3772, MUHL 3773, and MUHL 3774.
MUHL 5871.name: Baroque Music

MUHL 5873.description: A historical survey of opera: its development as an art form from its beginnings to the present.
MUHL 5873.prereq: MUTC 2632, MUHL 3771, MUHL 3772, MUHL 3773 and MUHL 3774.
MUHL 5873.name: Opera History

MUHL 5872.description: Musical developments from the decline of the baroque to the turn of the century; historical and stylistic elements contributing to the rise of classicism and culminating in the works of Mozart, Haydn, Beethoven.
MUHL 5872.prereq: MUTC 2632, MUHL 3771, MUHL 3772, MUHL 3773 and MUHL 3774.
MUHL 5872.name: Eighteenth Century and the Viennese Classical School

MUHL 2617H.description: A historical survey of the use of music in the motion picture. Examination of different styles in works by major composers.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities.
MUHL 2617H.name: Honors Film Music

MUHL 5878.description: A study of a specific topic to be announced each time the course is offered. May be repeated once with different topic.
MUHL 5878.prereq: MUTC 2632, MUHL 3771, MUHL 3772, MUHL 3773, and MUHL 3774.
MUHL 5878.name: Selected Topics in Music History

MUHL 3774.description: A historical survey of music in America. Students will study the important composers and musical genres and the cultural contexts and social forces that influence the creation and dissemination of music. In addition to the core content of the class, students will be introduced to parallel narratives in the visual arts, literature, and theater. Students will also demonstrate, through examination and written assignments, their understanding of American musical styles and how they have developed within America’s unique historical context, demographics, and social structures.
MUHL 3774.prereq: sophomore standing and MUTC 1531 or permission of instructor, and MUHL 3773.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities.
MUHL 3774.name: Music History and Literature 4

MUHL 3775.description: Students will study and develop an understanding of jazz origins, influences, performers, compositions, and stylistic features from the turn of the century to the present. This will include study of early jazz, the swing era, bebop, cool, hard bop, post bop, modal music, modal chromatic music, free jazz, and fusion.
MUHL 3775.prereq: MUTC 1520 or minimum 80% on the music theory placement exam.
MUHL 3775.name: Jazz History

MUHL 6946.description: Topical studies will develop a historical perspective of a specific period of jazz or a specific jazz artist including related cultures, events, and the development of musical style. Sample topics: early jazz, the Post-Bop Era, the music of John Coltrane. May be repeated with a different topic.
MUHL 6946.name: Selected Topics in Jazz History

MUHL 2616H.description: A historical survey of the origins, influences, and stylistic features of jazz from its beginnings to the present, with emphasis on performers, compositions, and innovations.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities.
MUHL 2616H.name: Honors Survey of Jazz

MUHL 6940.description: The development of polyphonic music, early organum to ca. 1450, with emphasis on techniques, styles, and forms. Seminar, with readings, reports, and musical illustrations.
MUHL 6940.name: Music in the Middle Ages

MUHL 3771.description: An introduction to the intersection of music and culture. Students will explore the cultural contexts and the social, economic, and technological forces that influence the creation and dissemination of music. In addition to the core content of the class, students will be introduced to parallel narratives in the visual arts, literature, and theater. Students will demonstrate, through examination and written assignments, their understanding of how music history is a function of cultural values and choices.
MUHL 3771.prereq: sophomore standing and MUTC 1520 or permission of instructor.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities.
MUHL 3771.name: Music History and Literature 1

MUHL 3772.description: An introductory history of musical culture in Europe from Antiquity to 1750 C.E. Students will study the important composers and musical genres and the cultural contexts and social forces that influence the creation and dissemination of music. In addition to the core content of the class, students will be introduced to parallel narratives in the visual arts, literature, and theater. Students will also demonstrate, through examination and written assignments, their understanding of how music history is a function of cultural values and choices.
MUHL 3772.prereq: sophomore standing, MUTC 1520 or by examination, and MUHL 3771.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities.
MUHL 3772.name: Music History and Literature 2

MUHL 3773.description: An introductory history of musical culture in Europe from 1750 C. E. to the present. Students will study the important composers and musical genres and the cultural contexts and social forces that influence the creation and dissemination of music. In addition to the core content of the class, students will be introduced to parallel narratives in the visual arts, literature, and theater. Students will also demonstrate, through examination and written assignments, their understanding of how music history is a function of cultural values and choices.
MUHL 3773.prereq: sophomore standing and MUTC 1520 or by examination, and MUHL 3772.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities.
MUHL 3773.name: Music History and Literature 3

MUHL 2621.description: The development of listening techniques applicable to Western and non-Western music through the comparison and contrast of the music of significant historical periods. For non-music majors.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities, International Perspectives, Social and Personal Awareness.
MUHL 2621.name: Music Literature and Appreciation

MUHL 2620.description: The study of African American musical genres from slavery to the present with focus on stylistic features, innovations, and the culture in which they were created. Topics may include Folk Music, Blues, Gospel, Ragtime, Jazz, Musical Theater, Art/Classical Music, Rhythm & Blues, Funk, Disco and House, Techno, Hip-Hop, Rap, Gender Issues, Popular Music Industry, and Musical Agency.
MUHL 2620.name: Music of African Americans

MUHL 2623.description: Introduction to the study of music and culture. Basic parameters of music and its function in society are explored. Two MUEN large ensembles other than Marching Band must be taken in addition to this course to satisfy the requirements for GER credit. 1 s.h.
MUHL 2623.name: Core Concepts of Music

MUHL 2622.description: The changing styles in American popular music from its origins to the present day studied through an examination of representative compositions and performers.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities.
MUHL 2622.name: Popular Music in America

MUHL 6943.description: An examination of select problems in musicology. May be repeated with permission of instructor.
MUHL 6943.name: Seminar in Musicology

MUHL 6991.description: Individual research and writing culminating in the preparation of a master's thesis.
MUHL 6991.prereq: Completion of 15 semester hours coursework and approval of thesis proposal by the Dana Graduate Committee.
MUHL 6991.name: Thesis 2

MUHL 6944.description: An investigation of the literature written for symphony orchestra.
MUHL 6944.name: Seminar in Symphonic Literature

MUHL 2618H.description: A historical survey of the evolution of rock n' roll into rock with emphasis on the interrelationships of the music and social and political influences and the interaction of rock with other musical styles.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities.
MUHL 2618H.name: Honors ock n Roll to Rock

MUHL 5860.description: An investigation of the solo keyboard works of major composers from the earliest times to the present day.
MUHL 5860.name: Keyboard Literature

MUHL 6941.description: Musical developments from ca. 1450-1600 dealing with the vocal music of this period, both sacred and secular, and the formulation of independent instrumental styles. Seminar with readings, reports, and musical illustrations.
MUHL 6941.name: Music in the Renaissance

MUHL 2616.description: A historical survey of the origins, influences, and stylistic features of jazz from its beginnings to the present, with emphasis on performers, compositions, and innovations.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities.
MUHL 2616.name: Survey of Jazz

MUHL 2617.description: A historical survey of the use of music in the motion picture. Examination of different styles in works by major composers.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities.
MUHL 2617.name: Film Music

MUHL 6960.description: A study of research tools and methodologies as applied to music scholarship and bibliography. This course is intended to lay the foundation for the thesis or exit paper, and a final research project or project proposal is required. May include the study of historical, philosophical, qualitative, quantitative, and/or analytic research methods, as deemed appropriate for students' areas of research. Crosslisted with MUED 6960.
MUHL 6960.name: Research in Music

MUHL 6945.description: Various topics related to the study of music literature. Specific topic is announced each time the course is offered. May be repeated with a different topic.
MUHL 6945.name: Selected Topics in Music Literature

MUHL 6977.description: Development of advanced music scholarship skills through readings, analysis, and critique of some of the major ideas about music's value and place in society that have been advanced by scholars ranging from the ancient Greeks to contemporary music critics, performers, philosophers, educators, and psychologists. Course takes an interdisciplinary approach to developing the skills to articulate music advocacy arguments. One of three core required courses for all masters students.
MUHL 6977.name: Philosophies of Music

MUHL 2618.description: A historical survey of the evolution of rock n' roll into rock with emphasis on the interrelationships of the music and social and political influences and the interaction of rock with other musical styles.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities.
MUHL 2618.name: Rock n' Roll to Rock

MUHL 2619.description: A historical survey of music as it relates to the different cultures, with emphasis on the development of instruments, vocal practices and performance media within specific cultures.
MUHL 2619.name: Music of Non-Western Societies

EMS 1501.description: Introduction to the roles, responsibilities, EMS systems, and medical and legal considerations of the EMS profession.
EMS 1501.name: Introduction to Prehospital Medicine

EMS 1500.description: Provides the basic knowledge and skills to be an Emergency Medical Technician. Meets all National Highway and Safety administration National Emergency Medical Services Education Standards and the State of Ohio Approved Emergency Medical Services Curriculum Standards for the Emergency Medical Technician. Must be taken concurrently with EMS 1500L and EMS 1500C.
EMS 1500.name: Emergency Medical Technician

EMS 1503.description: Intensive course designed to prepare the student in the methodology of advanced patient assessment, and the relevance of clinical signs and symptoms identified. Airway anatomy, equipment, procedures as they pertain to advanced airway management.
EMS 1503.prereq: Admission to EMS program or permission of instructor.
EMS 1503.name: Patient Assessment and Airway Management

EMS 1502.description: Study of general lifespan development of the body, how pathophysiologic changes affect it. Provides a foundational basis for viewing the body as a system, understanding its functions, anticipated reaction to injury, illness and intervention.
EMS 1502.prereq: Admission to EMS program or permission of instructor.
EMS 1502.name: General Pathophysiology for the Paramedic

EMS 1505.description: Includes simulated emergency traumatic situations and actual patient contact emphasizing physical assessment, patient interviewing, and management techniques. Meets 3 hours per week. Must be taken concurrently with EMS 1501, EMS 1502, EMS 1503, and EMS 1504.
EMS 1505.prereq: Admission to the EMS program or special permission of program director.
EMS 1505.name: Emergency Medical Techniques 1 Lab

EMS 1504.description: Study of traumatic emergencies normally encountered prehospitally with emphasis on pathophysiology, etiology, symptomatology, and management.
EMS 1504.prereq: Admission to EMS program or permission of Program Director.
EMS 1504.name: Principles of Trauma

EMS 1507.description: Intense study of the etiology, pathophysiology, symptomatology, and management principles for cardiovascular emergencies. Includes electrophysiological principles of EKG interpretation. Must be taken concurrently with EMS 1508.
EMS 1507.prereq: Admission to EMS program or permission of instructor.
EMS 1507.name: Cardiovascular Emergencies

EMS 1506.description: Clinical experiences in the emergency department and in the operating room allowing the student to work on various skills necessary for the paramedic. Total of 90 clinical hours. Must be taken concurrently with EMS 1503 and EMS 1505.
EMS 1506.prereq: Admission to EMS program or permission of instructor.
EMS 1506.name: Emergency Medical Services Clinical 1

EMS 1508.description: Performance of fundamental techniques employed in the management of cardiovascular emergencies. Three hours lab per week. Must be taken concurrently with EMS 1507.
EMS 1508.name: Cardiovascular Techniques Lab

EMS 2609.description: Capstone Field Internship experience requiring the paramedic student to perform successfully as a team leader on an advanced life support unit in the prehospital setting. A minimum of 30 team leads is required with an assigned field preceptor. Approximately 22 hours of field internship per week.
EMS 2609.name: EMS Prehospital Field Internship

EMS 2603.description: Precepted hospital clinical in the adult and pediatric emergency department; obstetrics, labor and delivery; and, psychiatric department. Total of 120 hours of clinical experience. Must be taken concurrently with EMS 2600.
EMS 2603.name: Clinical Experience 3

EMS 2601.description: Techniques necessary to effectively manage conditions in EMS 2600. Three hour lab. Must be taken concurrently with EMS 2600 and EMS 2605.
EMS 2601.prereq: Admission to the EMS program or permission by program director.
EMS 2601.name: Emergency Medical Techniques 3 Lab

EMS 2600.description: Study of etiology, pathophysiology, symptomatology and management of special needs patients. Includes gynecology, obstetrics, neonatology, pediatrics, geriatrics, behavioral, abuse/assault, infectious and communicable diseases, and chronic care. Must be taken concurrently with EMS 2601.
EMS 2600.prereq: EMS 1507 and EMS 1512 or permission of instructor.
EMS 2600.name: Emergency Medical Services Special Populations

EMS 2607.description: Focus on skills and competencies required for PALS, PHTLS, NRP. To be taken concurrently with EMS 2606.
EMS 2607.prereq: Admission to the EMS program or special permission by the program director.
EMS 2607.name: EMS Special Certifications Lab

EMS 2606.description: Provides the Paramedic with certifications beneficial to prehospital care. These certifications are nationally recognized and commonly sought after by paramedics, and desired by employers. Include PALS, PHTLS, NRP, and EMPACT. To be taken concurrently with EMS 2607.
EMS 2606.prereq: Admission to EMS program or special permission of instructor.
EMS 2606.name: EMS Special Certifications

EMS 2605.description: Intense study of the etiology, pathophysiology, symptomatology, and management principles of pulmonary emergencies. Must be taken concurrently with EMS 2601.
EMS 2605.name: Pulmonary Emergencies

EMS 2604.description: Performance of advanced life support procedures under the direct supervision of a selected paramedic field preceptor. Total of 150 hours.
EMS 2604.name: Prehospital Field Experience 2

EMS 1500C.description: Clinical and Field Internship experience necessary to acquire the skills required to be an Emergency Medical Technician. Meets all national and state curriculum standards for the EMT. Must be taken concurrently with EMS 1500 and EMS 1500L. Ten hours per week after week 12.
EMS 1500C.name: Emergency Medical Technician Clinical and Field Internship

EMS 1500L.description: Laboratory experience necessary to acquire skills required to be an Emergency Medical Technician. Meets all National and State curriculum standards for the EMT. Six hour lab. Must be taken concurrently with EMS 1500 and EMS 1500C.
EMS 1500L.name: Emergency Medical Technician Laboratory

EMS 1516.description: Field experience with an approved advanced life support unit under the direct supervision of a selected paramedic field preceptor. Total of 200 hours. To be taken concurrently with EMS 1507 and EMS 1512.
EMS 1516.name: Prehospital Field Experience 1

EMS 1514.description: Introduction to common rescue tools and techniques utilized in basic victim disentanglement and extrication.
EMS 1514.prereq: Admission to EMS program or permission of instructor.
EMS 1514.name: Emergency Medical Services Operations

EMS 1515.description: Hospital clinical experience to include rotations through the following: Adult emergency department, critical and intensive care units. Total of 95 hours. Must be taken concurrently with EMS 1508 and EMS 1513.
EMS 1515.name: Clinical Experience 2

EMS 1512.description: Study of pathophysiology, symptomatology, etiology, and management techniques of commonly encountered medical emergencies. Must be taken concurrently with EMS 1513.
EMS 1512.name: Medical Conditions and Management Techniques

EMS 1513.description: Simulated situations and actual patient contact emphasizing performance of emergency medical techniques utilized to manage common medical emergencies. Must be taken concurrently with EMS 1512.
EMS 1513.name: Emergency Medical Techniques 2 Lab

EMS 2613.description: In-depth study of the underlying abnormalities and physiologic disturbances resulting from traumatic injuries and medical illnesses as it relates to emergency medical care. Includes analysis of case studies. Must be taken concurrently with EMS 2614.
EMS 2613.name: Critical Care Paramedic

EMS 2614.description: Designed to prepare the student as a competent care provider in the transport of critical patients by ground or air unit. Topics include 12-leads, IABPs, RSI, lab data, EtCO2 monitoring, and advance pharmacology. Must be taken concurrently with EMS 2613.
EMS 2614.name: Critical Care Paramedic Laboratory

EMS 2631.description: Field internship in a variety of advanced life-support units to expose the student to hospital-based, public third service, private, and fire service EMS. Includes a field component involving wilderness rescue and emergency medicine. Must be taken concurrently with EMS 2613.
EMS 2631.name: Advanced Clinical and Field Internship Experience

PSYC 3777.description: A psychological examination of the impact of culture on individual social behavior as applied to topics such as attribution, moral reasoning, gender differences, and group dynamics.
PSYC 3777.prereq: A minimum of 15 s.h. of Psychology including PSYC 3700.
PSYC 3777.name: Cross-Cultural Social Psychology

PSYC 3750.description: Selected areas of study not covered in the mainstream curriculum. May be repeated with different topics to a maximum of 9 s.h. toward the major.
PSYC 3750.name: Special Topics in Psychology

PSYC 3775.description: A critical overview of the major personality theories and theorists in the field of psychology, their application to the understanding of everyday life and a description of the pertinent research applicable to the evaluation of personality theories.
PSYC 3775.name: Personality

PSYC 3755.description: Foundations of human development from conception through approximately the first decade of life. Fundamental issues of developmental processes in biological, cognitive, and social-emotional domains and their broader implications for society and later development of the individual.
PSYC 3755.name: Child Development

PSYC 3780.description: The primary factors affecting an individual's attitude toward illness, bereavement, and mortality. The psychological and physiological aspects of disease processes and death.
PSYC 3780.name: Psychological Aspects of Disease and Death

PSYC 3757.description: Human development from adulthood through old age.
PSYC 3757.name: Adult Development

PSYC 3756.description: Human development from preteen to young adulthood.
PSYC 3756.name: Adolescent Development

PSYC 3758.description: Study of theory and research on development from conception to death. Focus upon psychological, physiological, social and cultural influences. May not be taken for credit if the student has received credit for two or more of PSYC 3755, PSYC 3756, PSYC 3757.
PSYC 3758.prereq: PSYC 1560.Gen Ed: Social Science, Well Being, Social and Personal Awareness.
PSYC 3758.name: Lifespan Development

PSYC 4850.description: Major topics in psychology not covered in listed courses. Two s.h. may be applied to the psychology major.
PSYC 4850.prereq: Senior standing in psychology, or consent of instructor.
PSYC 4850.name: Seminar

PSYC 3779.description: Overview of career preparation and professional development. Students obtain information on career preparation, job search strategies, and graduate studies.
PSYC 3779.name: Careers in Psychology

PSYC 4860.description: Classical and contemporary theories of motivation. Overview of research and theory on the interactive role of biological, learned, and cognitive components in motivation of human behavior, including emotion, need for achievement, affiliation, and power.
PSYC 4860.name: Motivation

PSYC 4835.description: Advanced and specialized topics in developmental psychology. Topics vary over semesters, and may include the study of infancy, the development of exceptional children, cross-cultural developmental psychology, among others. May be repeated with different topics to a maximum of 6 s.h. toward the major.
PSYC 4835.prereq: PSYC 3755 or PSYC 3756 or PSYC 3757 or PSYC 3758.
PSYC 4835.name: Special Topics in Developmental Psychology

PSYC 3760L.description: Laboratory demonstrations and experiments using research techniques in perception. Two hours per week.Concurrent: PSYC 3760.
PSYC 3760L.name: Perception Laboratory

PSYC 3728L.description: An introduction to experimental methods for studying effects of environmental stimuli on brain function and behavior in animals. Two hours per week. Permit required.
PSYC 3728L.prereq: PSYC 3728 with "C" or above or concurrent.
PSYC 3728L.name: Physiological Psychology Laboratory

PSYC 3702L.description: An introduction to conducting research on psychological disorders, to include a critical review of research literature, examination of case studies, and gathering field-based data. Two hours per week. or.
PSYC 3702L.prereq: PSYC 2617 with "C" or better; and Prereq.Concurrent: PSYC 3702 or PSYC 3702H.
PSYC 3702L.name: Abnormal Psychology Laboratory

PSYC 3710L.description: Measurement and research techniques in basic and applied psychophysiology. Two hours laboratory-discussion.
PSYC 3710L.name: Psychophysiology Laboratory

PSYC 3702H.description: Patterns of deviant behavior, including current systems of classification; classic syndromes; the nature and trend of major maladjustments; possible causative factors; and methods of prevention and treatment.
PSYC 3702H.name: Honors Abnormal Psychology

PSYC 4800.description: A critical overview of major psychotherapeutic approaches to mental health including an evaluation of empirical validity. Students will develop an increased sensitivity to multicultural and ethical issues.
PSYC 4800.name: Introduction to Psychotherapy

PSYC 6964.description: This course provides intensive instruction in functional assessment procedures and direct observation methods to be used by the applied behavior analyst in service delivery in community, mental health and education settings.
PSYC 6964.prereq: Admission to the MS in Applied Behavior Analysis program or permission of the instructor.
PSYC 6964.name: Observational Methods & Functional Assessment

PSYC 3755L.description: Experimental and nonexperimental research methods for gathering data on the development of children. Two hours per week. A criminal background check is required to take the course.
PSYC 3755L.prereq: PSYC 2617 with "C" or better and PSYC 3755 (may be taken concurrently).
PSYC 3755L.name: Child Development Laboratory

PSYC 3700L.description: An introduction to planning and conducting social psychological research. Topics include creating participant impact while minimizing loss of control, reducing demand characteristics and experimenter bias, and enhancing mundane and experimental realism. Two hours per week.Concurrent: PSYC 3700.
PSYC 3700L.name: Social Psychology Laboratory

PSYC 3700H.description: Examination of the influence of social interactions on the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors of the individual and the group.
PSYC 3700H.prereq: PSYC 1560 or SOC 1500.Gen Ed: Social Science.
PSYC 3700H.name: Honors Social Psychology

PSYC 3730L.description: Laboratory and field-based research techniques relating to the study of women and to gender similarities and differences. Two hours per week.
PSYC 3730L.prereq: PSYC 2617 and PSYC 2618 with "C" or better; PSYC 3730 must be taken concurrently.
PSYC 3730L.name: Psychology of Women Laboratory

PSYC 3770.description: Individual study of a special problem, or a review of the literature relating to a specific psychological problem or issue. A written report is required, one copy of which remains on file in the department. May be repeated for a maximum of 4 s.h. with different problems.
PSYC 3770.prereq: PSYC 1560 and consent of the chairperson.
PSYC 3770.name: Individual Study

PSYC 6959.description: To explore behavior change resulting from training interventions, both general as well as specific age-related training issues.  General topics in training will include transfer, retention, and habilitation issues.  Specific training domains will encompass attention training, exercise training, memory training, job training and motivation, behavior problems, and computer training.
PSYC 6959.prereq: Admission to the MS in Applied Behavior Analysis program or permission of the instructor.
PSYC 6959.name: Behavior Change Interventions and Aging

PSYC 3724.description: A continuation of inferential statistics: complex analysis of variance and nonparametric statistics; additional study of special correlational techniques and concepts of regression and prediction, Recommended for the student preparing to seek an advanced degree.
PSYC 3724.name: Advanced Statistical Methods in Psychology

PSYC 2692.description: An interdisciplinary approach to the study of human sexuality. Listed also as PHLT 2692.Gen Ed: Well Being, Social and Personal Awareness.
PSYC 2692.name: Human Sexuality

PSYC 6930.description: Comprehensive theoretical and empirical coverage of topics in pediatric and health psychology.
PSYC 6930.name: Child and Adolescent Health Psychology

PSYC 6936.description: This course will survey major theories and empirical findings of cognitive development and the development of interpersonal relations across childhood.
PSYC 6936.name: Cognitive and Social Development

PSYC 3709.description: Principles of psychology as applied to the educational process, including characteristics of the individual learner, the classroom, the instructor, methods and techniques, and other factors in the learning process.
PSYC 3709.name: Psychology of Education

PSYC 3760.description: Theories and experimental evidence on how environmental, physiological, and personal factors influence the reception, organization, and interpretation of sensory input.
PSYC 3760.name: Perception

PSYC 3707.description: Psychological principles pertaining to intimate relationships, both marital and non-marital, and family dynamics. Includes topics such as communication, problem solving, domestic violence, and sexuality.
PSYC 3707.prereq: PSYC 1560.Gen Ed: Well Being, Social and Personal Awareness.
PSYC 3707.name: Psychology of Intimate Relationships

PSYC 3705.description: A study of the learning process with emphasis on factors such as reinforcement, respondent conditioning, discrimination, generalization, transfer, etc.; an introduction to modern learning theory.
PSYC 3705.name: Psychology of Learning

PSYC 3728.description: The structural-functional relationships of the various divisions of the neural system, their relationship to the organism as a whole, and their contributions to human behavior.
PSYC 3728.name: Physiological Psychology

PSYC 3700.description: Examination of the influence of social interactions on the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors of the individual and the group.
PSYC 3700.prereq: PSYC 1560 or SOC 1500.Gen Ed: Social Science.
PSYC 3700.name: Social Psychology

PSYC 3701.description: Examines psychological research and theories pertaining to music. Topics include perception of musical attributes such as pitch, musical illusions, cognitive organization of music, and music and emotion. Previous musical knowledge is not required.
PSYC 3701.name: Psychology of Music

PSYC 6990.description: Study of topics in psychology. To be announced by topic. Repeatable to six semester hours with change in topic.
PSYC 6990.name: Seminar in Psychology

PSYC 3740.description: Theories and principles of test construction, and an overview of psychological tests and questionnaires use in mental health, educational, and vocational settings.
PSYC 3740.name: Psychological Measurement

PSYC 2618.description: Further exploration of psychological research methods and statistical analysis, with emphasis on inferential techniques.
PSYC 2618.prereq: "C" or better in PSYC 2617 and psychology major, or consent of instructor.
PSYC 2618.name: Research Methods and Statistics 2

PSYC 4815.description: Psychosocial factors that affect the promotion and maintenance of health, as well as the prevention and treatment of illness.
PSYC 4815.name: Health Psychology

PSYC 6955.description: The study of abnormal behavior with an emphasis placed on psychopathological conditions.
PSYC 6955.name: Psychopathology

PSYC 3790.description: Exploration of different types of work and issues encountered in professional positions within the field of psychology. Supervised field work hours (approximately 4 hours per week) will be arranged. Criminal background check required. May be repeated one time.
PSYC 3790.prereq: 9 s.h. in Psychology, junior/senior standing, and consent of chair.
PSYC 3790.name: Field Work in Psychology

PSYC 2617.description: An introduction to psychological research methods and descriptive statistics. Students learn how to conduct ethical research and report their findings as well as to critically evaluate the research of others. Three hours of lecture, two hours of lab per week.
PSYC 2617.prereq: "C" or better in PSYC 1560 and psychology major, or consent of instructor.
PSYC 2617.name: Research Methods and Statistics 1

PSYC 1560.description: An examination of scientific and clinical approaches to understanding the relationships between one's physical, mental, and emotional well-being, and quality of life, including the basic principles governing the growth and maintenance of behavior, emotion, and cognition.Gen Ed: Social Science.
PSYC 1560.name: General Psychology

PSYC 1560H.description: An examination of scientific and clinical approaches to understanding the relationships between one's physical, mental, and emotional well-being, and quality of life, including the basic principles governing the growth and maintenance of behavior, emotion, and cognition.Gen Ed: Social Science.
PSYC 1560H.name: Honors General Psychology

PSYC 7000.description: An introduction to the basic principles of pharmacology; a review of the structures and mechanisms of the central nervous system, with emphasis on neurotransmission; and a survey of the drugs that especially affect the central nervous system, including possible mechanisms of action.
PSYC 7000.name: Psychopharmacology

PSYC 3705L.description: Laboratory studies of learning processes. Students use observational and data-recording techniques as they apply to investigations of learning processes. Laboratory activities include investigations of classical conditioning, reinforcement, shaping, extinction, practice effects or other phenomena. Two hours per week.Concurrent: PSYC 3705.
PSYC 3705L.name: Psychology of Learning Laboratory

PSYC 6940.description: The study of major personality theories and their implications for psychotherapy and mental health work.
PSYC 6940.name: Personality Theory

PSYC 3761L.description: Laboratory demonstrations and experiments using research techniques in cognition. Two hours per week.Concurrent: PSYC 3761.
PSYC 3761L.name: Cognition Laboratory

PSYC 3761.description: Experimental methods, research findings, and current theories concerned with human cognitive processes. The information-processing approach, focusing on how information is transformed, stored, manipulated, and retrieved. Topics include attention, pattern recognition and categorization, memory, and language.
PSYC 3761.name: Cognition

PSYC 6965.description: The application of basic principles of behavior in business and industry settings. Students are expected to master fundamental principles of behavior analysis and apply those principles to a variety of performance problems in business and industry.
PSYC 6965.prereq: Admission to the MS in Applied Behavior Analysis program or permission of the instructor.
PSYC 6965.name: Behavioral Systems Analysis

PSYC 4890.description: Data collection and a research paper on a topic approved by the thesis advisor. This project takes two semesters to complete. Must be repeated for a maximum of 2 s.h.
PSYC 4890.prereq: 16 s.h. in psychology, including a "C" or better in PSYC 2618, and consent of thesis advisor and departmental chairperson.Gen Ed: Capstone.
PSYC 4890.name: Senior Thesis

PSYC 4895.description: A capstone experience for the major in psychology.
PSYC 4895.prereq: Senior status in psychology, PSYC 2618, and completion in one psychology laboratory course.Gen Ed: Capstone.
PSYC 4895.name: Senior Psychology Capstone Experience

PSYC 3785H.description: Study of selected topics within psychology suitable to the honors program.
PSYC 3785H.prereq: Admission to the Psychology Honors Program, permit required.
PSYC 3785H.name: Honors Seminar in Psychology

PSYC 4857.description: Broad overview of development and change across the adult lifespan, focusing on an examination and understanding of biological aging and how they affect functioning, adjustment, and wellness. Distinction between primary aging (normal, universal biological changes) and secondary aging (disease, lifestyle-determined changes) will be made.
PSYC 4857.name: Biopsychological Aspects of Health and Aging

PSYC 7060.description: Design, proposal, completion, and reporting of scholarly research deemed acceptable by the BATC (Behavior Analysis Training Committee). A student may register for 6 s.h. in one semester or for 3 s.h. in each of two semesters..
PSYC 7060.prereq: Admission to the MS in Applied Behavior Analysis program or permission of the instructor.
PSYC 7060.name: Thesis

PSYC 3763.description: The variety of behaviors within the animal world.
PSYC 3763.name: Comparative Psychology

PSYC 6969.description: The second-year practicum will give students experience designing and implementing behavior analytic interventions with a specific client population. This population will be different than that encountered in Practicum I. Possible settings include industry, senior care, prisons, and rehabilitation centers. This course will follow the experience guidelines of the Behavior Analysis Certification Board (www. BACB.com), which requires 1,000 total hours of practicum experience. Students will work 20 hours per week at their practicum site (BACB requirement for Practicum).
PSYC 6969.prereq: Admission to the MS in Applied Behavior Analysis program or permission of the instructor.
PSYC 6969.name: Practicum 2

PSYC 6968.description: The first-year practicum will give students experience doing functional analyses and behavior assessments with a specific client population. Possible settings include industry, senior-care, prisons, and rehabilitation centers. This course will follow the experience guidelines of the Behavior Analysis Certification Board (www. BACB.com), which requires 1,000 total hours of practicum experience. Students will work 20 hours per week at their practicum site (BACB requirement for Practicum).
PSYC 6968.prereq: Admission to the MS in Applied Behavior Analysis program or permission of the instructor.
PSYC 6968.name: Practicum 1

PSYC 3740L.description: Application of psychological measurement techniques, test construction, and psychometric analyses. Optional lab, but must be taken concurrently with PSYC 3740.
PSYC 3740L.name: Psychological Measurement Laboratory

PSYC 3756H.description: Human development from preteen to young adulthood.
PSYC 3756H.name: Honors Adolescent Development

PSYC 3702.description: Patterns of deviant behavior, including current systems of classification; classic syndromes; the nature and trend of major maladjustments; possible causative factors; and methods of prevention and treatment.
PSYC 3702.name: Abnormal Psychology

PSYC 6957.description: Examines the principles and methods of developmental psychology as they are applied to adulthood.  Includes physical functioning, cognitive and behavioral processes, intimacy and family issues, personality and emotional development, career development, and sociocultural factors in the aging process.
PSYC 6957.name: Advanced Adult Development and Aging

PSYC 6966.description: This course covers direct measurement, graphing data, visual inference, single-subject research methodology, program monitoring and evaluation, and ethical issues in applied behavior analytic research.
PSYC 6966.prereq: Admission to the MS in Applied Behavior Analysis program or permission of the instructor.
PSYC 6966.name: Research Methods in Applied Behavior Analysis

PSYC 4841.description: The development of scientific psychology, with major emphasis on trends since the mid-19th century.
PSYC 4841.name: History of Psychology

PSYC 6960.description: An introduction to the scientific and theoretical foundation of applied behavior analysis including definitions and characteristics, principles and concepts, and behavior change procedures.
PSYC 6960.prereq: Admission to the MS in Applied Behavior Analysis program or permission of instructor.
PSYC 6960.name: Fundamentals of Applied Behavior Analysis

PSYC 6963.description: Introduction to the practice and application of empirically derived behavioral interventions, antecedent manipulations, extinction, differential reinforcement procedures, and punishment procedures for behavior maintained by social positive reinforcement, negative reinforcement, and automatic reinforcement.
PSYC 6963.prereq: Admission to the MS in Applied Behavior Analysis program or permission of the instructor.
PSYC 6963.name: Behavioral Interventions and Ethical Considerations

PSYC 6962.description: The course is designed to help students understand the philosophical and theoretical underpinnings of behavior analysis and to become familiar with some of the controversial issues surrounding the field from both modern and historical perspectives.
PSYC 6962.prereq: Admission to the MS in Applied Behavior Analysis program or permission of the instructor.
PSYC 6962.name: Behavior Theory and Philosophy

PSYC 6907.description: Basic problems dealing with mental health, individual differences, motivation, and minor deviant behavior.
PSYC 6907.name: Psychology of Adjustment

PSYC 6906.description: Expanded aspects of child and adolescent psychology.
PSYC 6906.name: Advanced Child Development

PSYC 6905.description: A life-span perspective to theoretical and empirical issues of development from conception to death.
PSYC 6905.name: Human Growth and Development

PSYC 3730.description: An exploration of psychological research and theories as they apply to girls and women. A critical examination of gender similarities and differences.
PSYC 3730.name: Psychology of Women

PSYC 6903.description: Examination of the teaching and learning process and its implications for use in education.
PSYC 6903.name: Psychology of Learning and Education

PSYC 3734.description: Scientific and conceptual foundations of applied behavior analysis. Basic principles of behavior analysis and application in applied settings are emphasized. The behavioral approach is contrasted with other approaches to the understanding and treatment of behavior, with a focus on scientific criteria and methodological differences. Ethical standards are covered.
PSYC 3734.name: ABA Principles 1: Applied Behavior Analysis

PSYC 6961.description: An examination of the roles that consequences, and their scheduling, play in the acquisition, maintenance, and structure of behavior, mechanisms and theories about mechanisms by which consequences select and shape behavior, and issues surrounding methods, measurement, and quantification.
PSYC 6961.prereq: Admission to the MS in Applied Behavior Analysis program or permission of the instructor.
PSYC 6961.name: Foundations of Experimental Analysis of Behavior

PSYC 4891H.description: The student prepares an empirical research paper on a topic approved by an honors thesis advisor and honors thesis committee. May be repeated for a maximum of 4 s.h.
PSYC 4891H.prereq: Admission to the Psychology Honors Program.Gen Ed: Capstone.
PSYC 4891H.name: Honors Thesis

PSYC 3709L.description: Application of principles of psychology in a K-12 educational setting. Evaluation and synthesis of psychological principles, theories, and research. Three hours per week, one hour to be arranged.
PSYC 3709L.prereq: PSYC 1560.Concurrent: PSYC 3709 or consent of instructor.
PSYC 3709L.name: Psychology of Education Lab

PSYC 3710.description: An introduction to the relationship between the psychological and physiological basis of behavior. Response systems, such as cardiovascular, respiratory, and gastrointestinal, as well as applications of principles and theories.
PSYC 3710.name: Psychophysiology

PSYC 3712.description: Principles of psychology applied to business and industry with emphasis upon both personnel and organizational behavior. Topics include job analysis, selection, performance appraisal, organizational development, job satisfaction, motivation, and leadership.
PSYC 3712.name: Industrial/Organizational Psychology

PHYS 6989.description: One semester immersion, usually through full-time paid employment at a partner company.  Work completed at the internship site will contribute to the professional development and expertise portfolio of the student.
PHYS 6989.name: Engineering Physics Internship

PHYS 1500L.description: Experimental work designed to supplement PHYS 1500. Three hours per week.Prereq. or concurrent: PHYS 1500.
PHYS 1500L.name: Conceptual Physics Laboratory

PHYS 4805.description: Research conducted under the direction of a faculty member. The grading is Traditional/PR.
PHYS 4805.name: Undergraduate Physics Research

PHYS 5826.description: General properties and behavior of the nucleus; nuclear models; nuclear reactions; radioactivity and decay processes; accelerators; current topics; elementary particles. Laboratory experiments. Prereq. PHYS 3704, PHYS 3704L, and MATH 3705.
PHYS 5826.name: Nuclear Physics

PHYS 5823.description: Emission and absorption of radiation, including stimulated emission. Optical cavities and wave guides. Introduction to lasers. Modulation and detection of light. Applications of lasers to information processing and other technologies. Introduction to nonlinear optical and opto-electronic phenomena and nonlinear optical materials.
PHYS 5823.name: Laser Physics and Photonics

PHYS 6900.description: Intensive study of selected topics of current interest in physics education. May be repeated. Grading is S/U.
PHYS 6900.name: Physics Education Workshop

PHYS 1507.description: Broad survey of the origin and distribution of the various forms of energy found in nature. Examination of the physical laws governing society's use of energy and environmental consequences resulting therefrom. Not applicable to the major in Physics or to the combined major in Physics and Astronomy.
PHYS 1507.name: Energy and the Environment

PHYS 1506.description: The basic laws of physics applied to various biological and physiological problems. Designed for majors in the allied health fields, e.g., Respiratory care. Not applicable to the major in Physics or to the combined major in Physics and Astronomy.
PHYS 1506.name: Physics for Health Care

PHYS 1502.description: Study of electricity, magnetism, and light. Topics include electric charge, electric forces and fields, electric potential, capacitance and resistance in direct current circuits, basic circuit analysis, magnetic forces and fields, induced emf, inductance, reflections, refraction, geometric optics as applied to lenses and mirrors, interference, and diffraction.
PHYS 1502.prereq: PHYS 1501 or equivalent.Gen Ed: Science Substitute.
PHYS 1502.name: Fundamentals of Physics 2

PHYS 1501.description: Topics include kinematics, forces, energy, momentum, rotational kinematics, torque, angular momentum, simple harmonic motion, and mechanical waves. Not recommended for mathematics, chemistry, physics, or engineering majors.
PHYS 1501.prereq: C or better in MATH 1507 or MATH 1510 and MATH 1511, or readiness for MATH 1571 or equivalent, or at least level 40 on the Mathematics Placement Test.Gen Ed: Science Substitute.
PHYS 1501.name: Fundamentals of Physics 1

PHYS 1500.description: A conceptual treatment of selected theories and laws of classical and modern physics and their application to the understanding of natural phenomena. The evolution of these laws from hypotheses to functional relationships examined in a historical context. Not applicable to the major in Physics or to the combined major in Physics and Astronomy.Gen Ed: Natural Science.
PHYS 1500.name: Conceptual Physics

PHYS 2608.description: The physical principles accounting for the production, propagation, and perception of sound waves. The relevance of these principles to phenomena ranging from hearing to the operation of various musical instruments. Introduction to auditorium acoustics. This course is designed for Music majors. Not applicable to the Physics major or to the combined Astronomy and Physics major.Gen Ed: Natural Science.
PHYS 2608.name: Sound

PHYS 3741.description: Intermediate theory of electric and magnetic fields. Topics include electric field, scalar potential, techniques for calculating scalar potential (method of images, Laplace's and Poisson's equations, multipole expansion, Green's Function approach), dielectrics and polarization, Maxwell's equations and their application to the propagation of electromagnetic waves including reflection, refraction, transmission, and absorption; guided waves, retarded potentials, radiating systems, special relativity. Must be taken in sequence, before PHYS 3742.
PHYS 3741.prereq: MATH 3705 and either PHYS 2611 or ECEN 2633.
PHYS 3741.name: Electromagnetic Field Theory 1

PHYS 2601.description: Description and analysis of motion including kinematics and dynamics of translation and rotation; analysis of equilibrium, energy, and momentum of objects; gravity; mechanical oscillations and waves. This course is designed primarily for students enrolled in the NEOMED-YSU program or in pre-medical curricula.
PHYS 2601.prereq: MATH 1507 and MATH 1508 or equivalent.Prereq. or concurrent: MATH 1571, MATH 1581H, or MATH 1585H.Gen Ed: Science Substitute.
PHYS 2601.name: General Physics for Applied Medical Studies 1

PHYS 6971.description: A study of the structure/property relationships of matter in the condensed state at the electronic, atomic, and molecular level.  Using quantum chemistry, symmetry, chemical bonding, and electrochemistry, this course will investigate the theoretical underpinnings for the properties of amorphous, crystalline, and semi-crystalline structures including metals, semiconductors, ceramics, polymers, and composites.  Properties studied include mechanical, electrical, thermal, and magnetic.
PHYS 6971.name: Condensed Matter 1

PHYS 2602.description: Description and analysis of electrical and magnetic effects; geometric and physical optics and the wave nature of light; introduction to atomic physics, quantum mechanics, nuclear structure and radiation.
PHYS 2602.name: General Physics for Applied Medical Studies 2

PHYS 6977.description: A lecture course on the application of fundamental physical principles and statistical techniques to the design, operation, characterization, optimization and data analysis of data from a broad palette of transducers, sensors and measurement systems.  Signal noise detection modalities for noisy environments, intrinsic sensor noise, technical noise.
PHYS 6977.name: Physical Measures and Fundamental Characteristics

PHYS 3730.description: Laboratory-based course in digital and analog electronics. Topics include AC and DC circuit theory; digital and analog electronics including filters, op amps, counters, digital integrated logic circuits, and A/D and D/A conversion; computer interfacing.
PHYS 3730.name: Electronic Instrumentation

PHYS 2607.description: Selected topics in physical science appropriate to the middle- and secondary-level curriculum. Emphasis on diverse hands-on classroom activities, and multiple approaches to communicating basic concepts in physical science. Topics include simple machines, light and sound, batteries and bulbs, physical properties of solids, liquids and gases.
PHYS 2607.prereq: MATH 1501 or at least level 3 on the Mathematics Placement Test and admission to BCOE upper-division status.Gen Ed: Science Substitute.
PHYS 2607.name: Physical Science for Middle and Secondary Education

PHYS 2610L.description: Experimental work designed to supplement the PHYS 2610, 2611 sequence. Three hours per week.Prereq. or concurrent: PHYS 2610 or PHYS 2601 for PHYS 2610L.
PHYS 2610L.name: General Physics laboratory 1

PHYS 2610R.description: Discussion and problem solving based on current material in PHYS 2610.Concurrent with: PHYS 2610.
PHYS 2610R.name: General Physics 1 Recitation

PHYS 3705.description: Principles and theorems of thermodynamics derived from the observable macroscopic properties related to temperature, heat, and the underlying statistical origins of thermodynamic processes. Includes the laws of thermodynamics, entropy, state functions, differential equations of state, Maxwell relations, and Maxwell-Boltzmann statistics.
PHYS 3705.prereq: PHYS 2611 or ECEN 2633 and prerequisite or concurrent with MATH 2673.
PHYS 3705.name: Thermodynamics and Classical Statistical Dynamics

PHYS 3704.description: Special Theory of Relativity. Quantum phenomena related to electromagnetic radiation and material particles. The Bohr model of the hydrogen atom; the Schroedinger equation; the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle. Wave mechanics of single particles in one-dimensional potentials. Selected topics in atomic, nuclear and condensed matter physics.
PHYS 3704.prereq: PHYS 2611 or ECEN 2633 and prerequisite or concurrent with MATH 2673.
PHYS 3704.name: Modern Physics

PHYS 3703.description: Kinematics and dynamics of particles and rigid bodies in inertial and non-inertial reference systems. Linear and non-linear oscillations and oscillating systems. Conditions for chaotic motion. Gravitational and central forces. Langrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics.
PHYS 3703.prereq: PHYS 2611 or ECEN 2633 and prerequisite or concurrent with MATH 3705.
PHYS 3703.name: Classical Mechanics and Dynamics

PHYS 3705L.description: Experimental work designed to supplement PHYS 3705. Three hours per week.Prereq. or concurrent: PHYS 3705.
PHYS 3705L.name: Thermodynamics and Classical Statistical Mechanics Laboratory

PHYS 5890.description: Intensive study of selected topics of current interest in Physics education. Not applicable to the major in Physics or the combined Astronomy and Physics major. May be repeated for different topics.
PHYS 5890.prereq: Admission to upper-division status in the College of Education or to the Graduate School.
PHYS 5890.name: Physics and Astronomy for Educators

PHYS 6930.description: Material properties of semiconductors, the physics and principles of operation of various semiconductor devices including Schottky diodes, PN junction diodes, photodetectors, LEDs, and bipolar junction transistors.  Electrical, Optical, and Physical characterization methods used for semiconductor materials and devices.
PHYS 6930.prereq: Completion of at least one of the following courses or their equivalent: PHYS 3742, PHYS 3750, PHYS 5810, or PHYS 5830.
PHYS 6930.name: Semiconductor Materials and Devices

PHYS 1501L.description: Experimental work designed to supplement the PHYS 1501, PHYS 1502 sequence. Two hours per week.Prereq. or concurrent: PHYS 1501.
PHYS 1501L.name: Fundamentals of Physics Laboratory 1

PHYS 3742.description: Intermediate theory of electric and magnetic fields. Topics include electric field, scalar potential, techniques for calculating scalar potential (method of images, Laplace's and Poisson's equations, multipole expansion, Green's Function approach), dielectrics and polarization, Maxwell's equations and their application to the propagation of electromagnetic waves including reflection, refraction, transmission, and absorption; guided waves, retarded potentials, radiating systems, special relativity.
PHYS 3742.name: Electromagnetic Field Theory 2

PHYS 5830.description: Selected topics in condensed matter physics: mechanical, thermal, electrical, and magnetic properties of amorphous and crystalline materials; crystal structures.
PHYS 5830.name: Condensed Matter Physics

PHYS 5835.description: Treatment of atomic, molecular, and nuclear structure based on the analysis of electromagnetic and other spectra.
PHYS 5835.name: Spectroscopy

PHYS 5835L.description: Experimental work designed to supplement PHYS 5835. Three hours per week.Prereq. or concurrent: PHYS 5835.
PHYS 5835L.name: Spectroscopy Laboratory

PHYS 5811.description: The postulates of wave mechanics, Matrix mechanics, angular momentum coupling, scattering, perturbation theory, intrinsic spin, emission and absorption of radiation. Fermi-Dirac and Bose-Einstein statistics with applications in quantum theory. Must be taken in sequence.
PHYS 5811.name: Quantum Mechanics and Quantum Statistical Mechanics 2

PHYS 5810.description: The postulates of wave mechanics, Matrix mechanics, angular momentum coupling, scattering, perturbation theory, intrinsic spin, emission and absorption of radiation. Fermi-Dirac and Bose-Einstein statistics with applications in quantum theory. Must be taken in sequence before PHYS 5811.
PHYS 5810.name: Quantum Mechanics and Quantum Statistical Mechanics 1

PHYS 5850.description: The study of a standard topic at greater depth, of the development of a correlated background for areas of physical knowledge, or the physical and educational experimentation necessary to develop new physics courses. May be repeated twice.
PHYS 5850.prereq: Senior standing in Physics, Electrical Engineering, or Education.
PHYS 5850.name: Special Topics in Physics

PHYS 1501R.description: Discussion and problem solving based on current material in PHYS 1501.Concurrent with: PHYS 1501.
PHYS 1501R.name: Fundamentals of Physics 1 Recitation

PHYS 2611L.description: Experimental work designed to supplement the PHYS 2610, 2611 sequence. Three hours per week.Prereq. or concurrent: PHYS 2611 or PHYS 2602.
PHYS 2611L.name: General Physics laboratory 2

PHYS 6980.description: A combined lecture (2hours/week) and laboratory (3 hours/week) course that includes theoretical study and hands-on experience in a mixed signal environment emphasizing data acquisition, software design and data analysis using C and vector language tools (MATLAB). Interfacing, hard and soft interrupts, micro-controller and embedded controller applications, FPGA, and mixed signal ASICs and PLCs and ladder logic.
PHYS 6980.name: Computer Environment Application Analysis

PHYS 6981.description: A combined lecture (2hours/week) and laboratory (3 hours/week) course that includes theoretical study and hands-on experience in both hardware and software used in creating, recording and analyzing telemetry from a diverse cohort of sensors.  Theoretical principles applied in the design/implementation/analysis of sensing tools for developing diagnostic acumen.  Various data acquisition, reduction and control methodologies.
PHYS 6981.name: Experimental Diagnostic Technology

PHYS 3750.description: The mathematics techniques required in the study of classical, statistical, and quantum mechanics, and field theory.
PHYS 3750.prereq: MATH 3705 and either PHYS 2611 or ECEN 2633.
PHYS 3750.name: Mathematical Physics

PHYS 3704L.description: Experimental work designed to supplement PHYS 3704. Three hours per week.Prereq. or concurrent: PHYS 3704.
PHYS 3704L.name: Modern Physics Laboratory

PHYS 2610.description: A course in mechanics; the kinematics and dynamics of masses in translation and rotation; Newton's Laws; gravity; the conservation laws of energy and momentum; simple harmonic motion and introduction to wave motion and sound.
PHYS 2610.prereq: High school physics or PHYS 1501.Prereq. or concurrent: MATH 1571.Gen Ed: Science Substitute.
PHYS 2610.name: General Physics 1

PHYS 2611.description: Study of electric and magnetic fields and their effects; introduction to electric circuits; light as an electromagnetic wave; introduction to geometrical and physical optics.
PHYS 2611.prereq: PHYS 2610.Prereq. or concurrent: MATH 1572.Gen Ed: Science Substitute.
PHYS 2611.name: General Physics 2

PHYS 3722L.description: Experimental work designed to supplement PHYS 3722. Three hours per week.Prereq. or concurrent: PHYS 3722.
PHYS 3722L.name: Advanced Optics Laboratory

PHYS 1520H.description: Introduction to past and recent ideas in physics with specific emphasis on their impact on historical and contemporary thought. The treatment, largely non-mathematical, is enhanced by selected readings suitable for the beginning honors student in any field. Not applicable to the major in Physics or to the combined major in Physics and Astronomy.
PHYS 1520H.prereq: Admission to the Honors Program or permission of instructor and Director of Honors.
PHYS 1520H.name: Honors Perspectives in Physics

PHYS 1502L.description: Experimental work designed to supplement the PHYS 1501, PHYS 1502 sequence. Two hours per week.Prereq. or concurrent: PHYS 1502.
PHYS 1502L.name: Fundamentals of Physics Laboratory 2

PHYS 3722.description: Sources and detection of light; intermediate geometrical and physical optics, including dispersion, scattering, absorption, polarization, coherence, interference, Fresnel and Fraunhoffer diffraction.
PHYS 3722.prereq: MATH 2673 and either PHYS 2611 or ECEN 2633.
PHYS 3722.name: Advanced Optics and Light

NURS 2650.description: Concepts of pharmacology applies to major drug classes. Emphasis on application of nursing process to drug therapy across the lifespan.
NURS 2650.name: Pharmacology

NURS 4846L.description: Community Health Nursing for RNs Laboratory.
NURS 4846L.name: Community Health Nursing for RNs Laboratory
