Equal emphasis on problems suitable for contests in the seventh or eighth grade (such as the American Mathematics Competition 8 and MathCounts) and at the level of the Praxis II examination for Middle School Mathematics. May be repeated 2 times.
MATH 4870.prereq: MATH 2624 or MATH 2625 or STAT 2601; MATH 3767; MATH 3768; and either MATH 4869 or concurrent registration in MATH 4869.
MATH 4870.name: Mathematics Seminar for Middle School Teachers

MATH 4875.description: Complex numbers and their geometric representation, analytic functions of a complex variable, contour integration, Taylor and Laurent series, residues and poles, conformal mapping.
MATH 4875.name: Complex Variables

MATH 2687H.description: Introduction to mathematical modeling of topics covered in calculus. Emphasizes the use of technology such as computer algebra systems, technical document processing, and graphics software for solving problems and reporting solutions.
MATH 2687H.name: Honors Calculus Laboratory 2

MATH 3795.description: The study of a mathematical topic or the development of a special area of mathematics. May be repeated once.
MATH 3795.prereq: MATH 1549 or MATH 1570 or MATH 1571 or MATH 2623 or MATH 2651.
MATH 3795.name: Topics in Mathematics

MATH 2623.description: Mathematics models emphasizing basic ideas in mathematics and statistics, stressing concept formation rather than manipulative skills. Credit will not be given for both MATH 2623 and MATH 2625.
MATH 2623.prereq: MATH 1501 or Level 20 on the Mathematics Placement Test.Gen Ed: Mathematics.
MATH 2623.name: Quantitative Reasoning

MATH 6922.description: A continuation of MATH 5821 with special emphasis on groups acting on sets, Sylow's Theorem and its applications, ring homomorphisms, ideals, and polynomial rings.  Credit will not be given for MATH 4822 and MATH 6922.
MATH 6922.name: Advanced Topics in Group and Ring Theory

MATH 6923.description: This course introduces the major results in advanced field theory.  These results include splitting fields, algebraic extensions, finite extensions, cyclotomic polynomials, and finite fields.  Credit will not be given for MATH 4823 and MATH 6923.
MATH 6923.name: Advanced Topics in Field Theory

MATH 1513.description: Function concepts including trigonometric, exponential, and logarithmic functions. Application problems and graphing. Supplemental topics.
MATH 1513.prereq: Math Placement Level 45 or higher.Gen Ed: Math Substitute.
MATH 1513.name: Algebra and Transcendental Function

MATH 6928.description: Advanced study of number theory: theory and distribution of primes, computational number theory, and additive number theory.
MATH 6928.name: Advanced Number Theory

MATH 1511.description: This course, along with MATH 1510 is primarily intended to prepare STEM students for MATH 1570 or MATH 1571. Topics include algebraic structure and graphs of trigonometric functions and inverse trigonometric functions, angle measurements, similar triangles, trigonometric identities, vectors, complex numbers, polar coordinates and solving trigonometric equations with applications.
MATH 1511.prereq: MATH 1505 or MATH 1507 or Math Placement Level 35.Gen Ed: Math Substitute.
MATH 1511.name: Trigonometry

MATH 3715.description: A course in discrete mathematical structures to prepare students for advanced courses. Topics include set theory, functions and relations, logic and quantifiers, truth tables and Boolean expressions, induction and other techniques of proof, and graphs. Credit will not be given for both CSCI 3710 and MATH 3715.
MATH 3715.name: Discrete Mathematics

MATH 5895.description: The study of a standard mathematical topic in depth or the development of a special area of mathematics. May be repeated twice.
MATH 5895.prereq: 24 s.h. of mathematics applicable to the mathematics major including either MATH 3721 or MATH 3751.
MATH 5895.name: Selected Topics in Mathematics

MATH 6990.description: Study under the supervision of a staff member. May be repeated.
MATH 6990.name: Independent Study

MATH 6996.description: Individual research project culminating in a written report or paper, though not as broad in scope as a thesis. May be repeated once if the second project is in a different area of mathematics.
MATH 6996.name: Mathematical Project

MATH 6995.description: Specialized topics selected by the staff. May be repeated up to 12 semester hours.
MATH 6995.prereq: Permission of graduate coordinator and department chair.
MATH 6995.name: Special Topics

MATH 6999.description: A student may register for six semester hours in one semester or for three semester hours in each of two semesters.
MATH 6999.name: Thesis

MATH 4843.description: The mathematical foundation of probability theory including the study of discrete and continuous distributions. Other topics selected from limit theorems, generating functions, applications. Credit will not be given for MATH 4843 and STAT 4843.
MATH 4843.name: Theory of Probability

MATH 2686H.description: A sequence of honors courses in analytical geometry and calculus which cover essentially the same material as MATH 1571, 1572, 2673, in two semesters instead of three. A detailed study of limits, derivatives, and integrals of functions of one and several variables and their applications. This sequence will be offered at most once during each academic year.
MATH 2686H.name: Honors Calculus 2

MATH 6911.description: Theory and solution techniques used in engineering applications.  Topics include brief review of ordinary differential equations and linear algebra; vector calculus, integral theorems, complex analysis, series, residue theory, potential theory, special functions, integral transforms, partial differential equations and applications in mathematical modeling.
MATH 6911.name: Advanced Engineering Mathematics 2

MATH 6910.description: Theory and solution techniques used in engineering applications.  Topics include brief review of ordinary differential equations and linear algebra; vector calculus, integral theorems, complex analysis, series, residue theory, potential theory, special functions, integral transforms, partial differential equations and applications in mathematical modeling.
MATH 6910.name: Advanced Engineering Mathematics 1

MATH 6915.description: Order-theoretic and monadic foundations of mathematics: ordered structures; topologies; powerset operators of a function; applications to continuity, compactness, algebra, logic, and calculus.
MATH 6915.prereq: MATH 3721 Abstract Algebra I and MATH 3751 Real Analysis I, or permission of graduate coordinator.
MATH 6915.name: Mathematical Foundations

MATH 3705H.description: Methods and theory of solving differential equations with applications. Existence, uniqueness. First order equations. Higher order linear equations. Introduction to partial differential equations and boundary value problems, including Laplace's equation.
MATH 3705H.name: Honors Differential Equations

MATH 3721.description: Introduction to abstract algebra investigating fundamental concepts in group and ring theory. Topics include groups, subgroups, cyclic groups, permutation groups, cosets, direct products, homomorphisms, factor groups, rings, integral domains and polynomial rings.
MATH 3721.name: Abstract Algebra 1

MATH 3720.description: Matrices; matrix operations; linear transformations; applications.
MATH 3720.name: Linear Algebra and Matrix Theory

MATH 7015.description: Content varies with each offering, implements ideas from MATH 6915, MATH 6980, MATH 6981, and studies foundations of topology from a variety of viewpoints (algebraic, categorical, logical, order theoretic, powerset theoretic, set theoretic, etc.). Emphasis on current literature and open questions. May be repeated with approval of graduate coordinator.
MATH 7015.prereq: MATH 6915, MATH 6980, MATH 6981, or equivalent, or permission of graduate coordinator.
MATH 7015.name: Advanced Topics in Foundations of Topology

MATH 4897H.description: Individualized study of a topic in mathematics culminating in a written report and an oral presentation at a national or regional meeting or a local seminar.
MATH 4897H.prereq: 24 s.h. of mathematics applicable to the mathematics major including both MATH 3721 and MATH 3751 and permission of the department chairperson.
MATH 4897H.name: Thesis

MATH 6980.description: Basic concepts of topological spaces and mappings between them, including compactness, connectedness, and continuity. Credit will not be given for both MATH 4880 and MATH 6980.
MATH 6980.prereq: MATH 3721 Abstract Algebra I and MATH 3751 Real Analysis I, or permission of graduate coordinator.
MATH 6980.name: Topology 1

MATH 4855.description: A second course in differential equations with emphasis on nonlinear problems and qualitative methods or on boundary value problems. Topics are chosen from: proofs of fundamental theorems, phase plane analysis, limit cycles and the Poincare-Bendixon theorem, biological models, stability via Liapunov functions, asymptotic methods, and boundary value problems.
MATH 4855.name: Ordinary Differential Equations

MATH 4857.description: Introduction to partial differential equations (PDE) including solution techniques and applications. Classifications of the basic types of PDE's (hyperbolic, parabolic and elliptic) and dependence on boundary and initial conditions. Topics include Fourier series, integral transforms (Fourier, Laplace), and applications in vibrations, electricity, heat transfer, fluids or other selected topics.
MATH 4857.name: Partial Differential Equations

MATH 6905.description: Intensive preparation for teaching lower-level mathematics courses, featuring formal instruction and orientation on teaching issues, evaluated presentations, mentored classroom instruction, and weekly teaching seminars. Topics include course design, policies, syllabi, grading; classroom teaching problems; orientation in Mathematics Assistance Center, specific lower-level mathematics courses, online tutorial services. Required of and limited to graduate assistants in the Department of Mathematics and Statistics. To be taken each semester student is a graduate assistant. Grading is S/U. Does not count toward credit in the program.
MATH 6905.name: Teaching Practicum

MATH 7005.description: Content varies with each offering. Implements ideas from MATH 6915, MATH 6980, MATH 6981, and studies categorical methods in topology and related concrete categories. Emphasis on current literature and open questions. May be repeated with approval of graduate coordinator.
MATH 7005.prereq: MATH 6915, MATH 6980, MATH 6981, or equivalent, or permission of the graduate coordinator.
MATH 7005.name: Advanced Topics in Categorical Topology

MATH 5875.description: Complex numbers and their geometric representation, analytic functions of a complex variable, contour integration, Taylor and Laurent series, residues and poles, conformal mapping.
MATH 5875.name: Complex Variables

MATH 4823.description: This course introduces advanced topics in field theory. Topics may include principal ideal domains, irreducibility, quotient rings, algebraic extensions, finite fields, splitting fields, and the Galois group.
MATH 4823.name: Abstract Algebra 3

MATH 4822.description: A continuation of MATH 3721 with special emphasis on fields. Additional topics in pure or applied algebra.
MATH 4822.name: Abstract Algebra 2

MATH 6924.description: An introduction to Galois Theory with special emphasis on the Galois group, the Fundamental Theorem of Galois Theory, and radical extensions.
MATH 6924.name: Galois Theory

MATH 6975.description: Analytic and meromorphic functions of a complex variable, contour integration, the Cauchy-Goursat theorem, Taylor and Laurent series, residues and poles, conformal mapping. Credit will not be given for both MATH 5875 and MATH 6975.
MATH 6975.prereq: MATH 3751 Real Analysis I, or permission of graduate coordinator.
MATH 6975.name: Complex Analysis 1

MATH 7035.description: Content varies with each offering. Implements ideas from MATH 6915, MATH 6980, MATH 6981, and studies topology from the standpoint of lattice-valued (fuzzy) subsets. Emphasis on current literature and open questions. May be repeated with approval of graduate coordinator.
MATH 7035.prereq: MATH 6915, MATH 6980, MATH 6981, or equivalent, or permission of the graduate coordinator.
MATH 7035.name: Advanced Topics in Lattice-Valued Topology

MATH 5860.description: A course in numerical analysis aimed at developing a broad understanding of the subject. Credit will not be given for both MATH 3760 and MATH 5860.
MATH 5860.name: Topics in Numerical Analysis

MATH 5861.description: Numerical methods of initial-value problems, eigenvalue problems, iterative methods for linear and nonlinear systems of equations, and methods involving least squares, orthogonal polynomials, and fast Fourier transforms.
MATH 5861.name: Numerical Analysis 2

MATH 2623H.description: Mathematics models emphasizing basic ideas in mathematics and statistics, stressing concept formation rather than manipulative skills. Credit will not be given for both MATH 2623 and MATH 2625.
MATH 2623H.prereq: MATH 1501 or Level 20 on the Mathematics Placement Test.Gen Ed: Mathematics.
MATH 2623H.name: Honors Quantitative Reasoning

MATH 4832.description: General properties of functions and transformations; isometries and transformations of the Euclidean plane; the complex plane, its geometry and subfields; transformational, analytical, and vector approaches to Euclidean geometry; connections to other branches of mathematics and applications.
MATH 4832.name: Euclidean Transformations

MATH 4830.description: The development of Euclidean and non-Euclidean geometries from postulate systems.
MATH 4830.name: Foundations of Geometry

MATH 1510.description: This course is primarily intended to prepare STEM students (along with MATH 1511) for MATH 1570 or 1571 and business students for MATH 1552. Topics include real numbers, equations and inequalities, linear, quadratic, polynomial, exponential, and logarithmic functions, graphing techniques, systems of equations, and applications. The course fulfills the general education requirements for mathematics.
MATH 1510.prereq: MATH 1505 or MATH 1507 with a "C" or better or Math Placement Level 35 or higher.Gen Ed: Math Substitute.
MATH 1510.name: College Algebra

MATH 2665.description: Conceptual foundations of topics from number theory, operations, functions, algebra, geometry, measurement, probability, and data analysis. Emphasis on multiple approaches and representations, problem solving, and communication of mathematical reasoning. Includes inquiry-based laboratory experiences with manipulatives and computing technology.
MATH 2665.prereq: At least Level 40 on the Mathematics Placement Test or concurrent registration in MATH 1507 (for both).Gen Ed: Math Substitute.
MATH 2665.name: Foundations of Middle School Mathematics 2

MATH 6981.description: Separation, metrization, compactification. Additional topics will be selected from point-set topology, fuzzy topology, algebraic topology, combinatorial topology, topological algebra.
MATH 6981.prereq: MATH 4880 or MATH 6980, or permission of graduate coordinator.
MATH 6981.name: Topology 2

MATH 7025.description: Content varies with each offering, implements ideas from MATH 6915, MATH 6980, MATH 6981, and studies various topics in point-set topology. Emphasis on current literature and open questions. May be repeated with approval of graduate coordinator.
MATH 7025.prereq: MATH 6980, MATH 6981, or equivalent, or permission of graduate coordinator.
MATH 7025.name: Advanced Topics in General Topology

MATH 6965.description: Lebesgue integration and measure on the real line. General measure theory and functional analysis, including the Radon-Nikodym theorem, the Fubini theorem, the Hahn-Banach theorem, the closed graph and open mapping theorems, and weak topology.
MATH 6965.prereq: MATH 5852 and either MATH 4880 or MATH 6915 or permission of graduate coordinator.
MATH 6965.name: Abstract Analysis 1

MATH 1552.description: Apply functions, linear systems, linear programming to business including use of technology; mathematics of finance and an introduction to limits, derivatives and integrals with business applications. No credit for students who have completed MATH 1570 or MATH 1571.
MATH 1552.prereq: MATH 1510 or at least Level 45 on the Mathematics Placement Test.Gen Ed: Math Substitute.
MATH 1552.name: Applied Mathematics for Management

MATH 5852.description: Uniform convergence of sequences of functions and some consequences; functions on n-space: derivatives in vector spaces, mean value theorem, Taylor's formula, inverse mapping theorem, implicit mapping theorem.
MATH 5852.name: Real Analysis 2

MATH 5851.description: A course in analysis aimed at developing a broad understanding of the subject. Credit will not be given for both MATH 3751 and MATH 5851.
MATH 5851.name: Topics in Analysis

MATH 3750.description: A survey of the historical development of mathematics.
MATH 3750.name: History of Mathematics

MATH 3751.description: Introduction to the properties of the real number system and metrics and metric properties, with critical analysis of limits, continuity, differentiability, integration, and other fundamental concepts underlying the calculus.
MATH 3751.name: Real Analysis 1

MATH 1586H.description: Introduction to mathematical modeling of topics covered in calculus. Emphasizes the use of technology such as computer algebra systems, technical document processing, and graphics software for solving problems and reporting solutions.
MATH 1586H.name: Honors Calculus Laboratory 1

MATH 2673.description: A sequence of integrated courses in analytic geometry and calculus. A detailed study of limits, derivatives, and integrals of functions of one and several variables with applications.
MATH 2673.name: Calculus 3

MATH 2670.description: The elements of differential and integral calculus, with emphasis on applications. Analytical geometry, differentiation and integration techniques and series representations. Introduction to differential equations, transform calculus, and Fourier analysis. This is a basic methods course particularly adapted for those who require applied topics in mathematics. Not applicable toward the Mathematics major. Credit will not be given for both MATH 1549 and MATH 1570.
MATH 2670.name: Applied Calculus 2

MATH 1580H.description: Counting techniques, probability, matrices and linear systems. Emphasis on the role of mathematical models in explaining and predicting phenomena in life sciences.
MATH 1580H.name: Honors Biomathematics 1

MATH 6957.description: An introduction to partial differential equations (PDE) and their applications.  The classification of the basic types of linear partial differential equations, development of how boundary and initial conditions affect solutions, exploration, and application of solution techniques for PDEs and explosions in orthogonal functions will be presented.
MATH 6957.name: Partial Differential Equations

MATH 6955.description: Proofs of existence and uniqueness of nonautonomous, nonlinear equations. Additional topics may include advanced linear systems, partial differential equations, and integral equations.
MATH 6955.prereq: MATH 5852 and either MATH 3705 Differential Equations or MATH 4855, or permission of graduate coordinator.
MATH 6955.name: Advanced Differential Equations

MATH 5845.description: An introduction to operations research with emphasis on mathematical methods. Topics may include: linear programming, sensitivity analysis, duality theory, transportation problems, assignment problems, transshipment problems, and network problems.
MATH 5845.name: Operations Research

MATH 1564.description: Conceptual foundations of topics from number theory, operations, functions, algebra, geometry, measurement, probability, and data analysis. Emphasis on multiple approaches and representations, problem solving, and communication of mathematical reasoning. Includes inquiry-based laboratory experiences with manipulatives and computing technology.
MATH 1564.prereq: At least Level 40 on the Mathematics Placement Test or concurrent registration in MATH 1507 (for both).
MATH 1564.name: Foundations of Middle School Mathematics 1

MATH 3768.description: An integrated, conceptual, and function-centered approach to the foundations of algebra, geometry, and trigonometry for preservice middle childhood mathematics specialists. Emphasis on multiple approaches and representations, problem solving, and communication of mathematical reasoning. Includes inquiry-based laboratory experiences. Not applicable to the mathematics major.
MATH 3768.prereq: MATH 2665 and either 40 on the Mathematics Placement test or MATH 1507.
MATH 3768.name: Algebra/Geometry for Middle School Teachers 2

MATH 3767.description: An integrated, conceptual, and function-centered approach to the foundations of algebra, geometry, and trigonometry for preservice middle childhood mathematics specialists. Emphasis on multiple approaches and representations, problem solving, and communication of mathematical reasoning. Includes inquiry-based laboratory experiences. Not applicable to the mathematics major.
MATH 3767.prereq: MATH 1564 and either 40 on the Mathematics Placement test or MATH 1507.
MATH 3767.name: Algebra/Geometry for Middle School Teachers 1

MATH 7055.description: Content varies with each offering. Implements ideas from MATH 6915, MATH 6930, MATH 6965, MATH 6980, MATH 6981, MATH 6984, and focuses on current research activities of seminar participants. Student registrants are expected to make at least one major presentation each month of the term. May be repeated with approval of graduate coordinator.
MATH 7055.name: Seminar in Topology and Abstract Analysis

MATH 3760.description: The theory and techniques of numerical computation. The solution of a single equation, interpolation methods, numerical differentiation and integration, direct methods for solving linear systems.
MATH 3760.name: Numerical Analysis 1

MATH 1585H.description: A sequence of honors courses in analytical geometry and calculus which cover essentially the same material as MATH 1571, MATH 1572, MATH 2673, in two semesters instead of three. A detailed study of limits, derivatives, and integrals of functions of one and several variables and their applications. This sequence will be offered at most once during each academic year.
MATH 1585H.prereq: Level 90 on the Mathematics Placement Test.Gen Ed: Math Substitute.
MATH 1585H.name: Honors Calculus 1

MATH 4882.description: Interdisciplinary and individualized study of a topic in biology and mathematics. Student project mentored jointly by faculty in biology and mathematics. May be repeated once. Grading is Traditional/PR. Listed also as BIOL 4882.
MATH 4882.prereq: MATH 3701, BIOL 3701, senior status and permission of the department chairperson.
MATH 4882.name: Biomathematics Research

MATH 6942.description: Topics may include integer programming, advanced linear programming, nonlinear programming, dynamic programming, queuing theory, Markov analysis, game theory, and forecasting models.
MATH 6942.prereq: MATH 5845 and STAT 3743 Probability and Statistics.
MATH 6942.name: Advanced Operations Research

MATH 4880.description: An introduction to the basic concepts of general topology: compactness, connectedness, and continuity in topological spaces.
MATH 4880.name: Introduction to Topology

MATH 1581H.description: A study of functions, differential and integral calculus. Emphasis on the role of mathematical models in explaining and predicting phenomena in life sciences. Credit will not be given for both MATH 1581H and MATH 1571.
MATH 1581H.prereq: Admission to NEOMED-YSU program.Gen Ed: Math Substitute.
MATH 1581H.name: Honors Biomathematics 2

MATH 4884.description: An introduction to the study of theories in formalized languages and to the theory of models.
MATH 4884.name: Mathematical Logic

MATH 1570.description: The elements of differential and integral calculus, with emphasis on applications. Analytical geometry, differentiation and integration techniques and series representations. Introduction to differential equations, transform calculus, and Fourier analysis. This is a basic methods course particularly adapted for those who require applied topics in mathematics. Not applicable toward the Mathematics major. Credit will not be given for both MATH 1549 and MATH 1570.
MATH 1570.prereq: MATH 1513, or MATH 1510 and MATH 1511, or at least Level 50 on the Mathematics Placement Test.Gen Ed: Math Substitute.
MATH 1570.name: Applied Calculus 1

MATH 1571.description: A sequence of integrated courses in analytic geometry and calculus. A detailed study of limits, derivatives, and integrals of functions of one and several variables with applications.
MATH 1571.prereq: MATH 1513, minimum grade of "C", or MATH 1510 and MATH 1511, minimum grade of "C" in both courses, or at least Level 70 on the Mathematics Placement Test.Gen Ed: Math Substitute.
MATH 1571.name: Calculus 1

MATH 1572.description: A sequence of integrated courses in analytic geometry and calculus. A detailed study of limits, derivatives, and integrals of functions of one and several variables with applications.
MATH 1572.name: Calculus 2

MATH 7045.description: Content varies with each offering. Implements ideas from MATH 6915, MATH 6965, MATH 6966, MATH 6980, MATH 6981, and studies the overlap between topology and abstract analysis (topological games, topological groups, separate versus joint continuity, etc.). Emphasis on current literature and open questions. May be repeated with approval of graduate coordinator.
MATH 7045.prereq: MATH 6915, MATH 6965, MATH 6980, MATH 6981, or equivalent, or permission of graduate coordinator.
MATH 7045.name: Advanced Topics in Topological Analysis

MATH 4869.description: Polynomial and exponential functions, limits, derivatives, integrals, and applications. Interpretation of slope and area in graphs of functions from applied settings. Applications of limits to the derivations of geometric formulas. Relations between tables, graphs, and the symbolic representation of functions.
MATH 4869.name: Functions, Calculus, and Applications for Middle School Teachers

MATH 2651.description: A conceptual development of mathematics topics underlying today's Pre-K-grade 3 curriculum. Emphasis on multiple approaches, problem solving, and communication of mathematics. Incorporates classroom activities, manipulatives, technology, and activities developmentally appropriate for young children.
MATH 2651.prereq: MATH 1501 or Level 20 on the Mathematics Placement Test.
MATH 2651.name: Mathematics for Early Childhood Teachers 1

MATH 2652.description: A conceptual development of mathematics topics underlying today's Pre-K-grade 3 curriculum. Emphasis on multiple approaches, problem solving, and communication of mathematics. Incorporates classroom activities, manipulatives, technology, and activities developmentally appropriate for young children.
MATH 2652.name: Mathematics for Early Childhood Teachers 2

MATH 3785.description: Matrices, matrix operations, and the application of numerical methods. Not applicable to the Mathematics major.
MATH 3785.name: Numerical Methods

MATH 4896.description: Individualized study of a topic in mathematics culminating in a written report and an oral presentation at a national or regional meeting or a local seminar. May be repeated once.
MATH 4896.prereq: 24 s.h. of mathematics applicable to the mathematics major including either MATH 3721 or MATH 3751 and permission of the department chairperson.Gen Ed: Capstone.
MATH 4896.name: Senior Undergraduate Research Project

MATH 6930.description: Classical differential geometry of curves and surfaces, differentiable manifolds with tensors.
MATH 6930.name: Differential Geometry

MATH 5828.description: A study of congruences, Diophantine equations, quadratic residues, special number theory functions, and selected applications.
MATH 5828.name: Number Theory

MATH 1505.description: This course is intended to prepare STEM students for their college-level mathematics requirement. Topics include linear and nonlinear equations and inequalities; problem solving; relations of function types that include linear, polynomial, radical, rational, exponential, and logarithmic; applications. Math Placement Level 10 or higher. Does not count toward a degree.
MATH 1505.name: Intermediate Algebra with Applications

MATH 1507.description: Topics include functions of the following: linear, polynomial, rational, exponential, and logarithmic. Emphasis on function relations and graphing by algebraic techniques and technology. Solving linear, nonlinear equations and inequalities. Does not count toward a degree.
MATH 1507.prereq: MATH 1501 or Level 20 on Math Placement Test.
MATH 1507.name: Intermediate Algebra

MATH 5825.description: A study of abstract vector spaces, linear transformations, duality, canonical forms, the spectral theorem, and inner product spaces.
MATH 5825.name: Advanced Linear Algebra

MATH 1501.description: Arithmetic of integers and of rational numbers; linear equations and inequalities in one variable; polynomials, factoring, algebraic fractions, radicals and quadratic equations; linear systems in two variables; graphs. Does not count toward a degree.
MATH 1501.name: Elementary Algebraic Models

MATH 5821.description: A course in abstract algebra aimed at developing a broad understanding of the subject. Credit will not be given for both MATH 3721 and MATH 5821.
MATH 5821.name: Topics in Abstract Algebra

MATH 3705.description: Methods and theory of solving differential equations with applications. Existence, uniqueness. First order equations. Higher order linear equations. Introduction to partial differential equations and boundary value problems, including Laplace's equation.
MATH 3705.name: Differential Equations

MATH 5835.description: The pigeonhole principle; permutations, combinations, the binomial theorem; the inclusion-exclusion principle; recurrence relations; graphs and digraphs, paths and cycles, trees, bipartite graphs and matchings.
MATH 5835.name: Introduction to Combinatorics and Graph Theory

MATH 3701.description: Introduction to interdisciplinary research in biology and mathematics. Topics include current research by faculty and students, cross disciplinary communication, report writing, technical presentations, literature reading, laboratory techniques and safety. May be repeated once. Listed also as BIOL 3701.
MATH 3701.name: Biomathematics Seminar

MATH 3702.description: Approaches to and practice with problem solving with examples from a broad spectrum of mathematics. Emphases include problems at the level of the Praxis II examination for mathematics and problems suitable for high school contests such as the American Mathematics Competition 10 and 12.
MATH 3702.name: Problem Solving Seminar for Secondary Mathematics

VION 4802.description: Private Music Lessons.Gen Ed: Capstone, Capstone.
VION 4802.name: Violin

VION 4804.description: Private Music Lessons.Gen Ed: Capstone, Capstone.
VION 4804.name: Violin

VION 4806.description: Private Music Lessons.Gen Ed: Capstone, Capstone.
VION 4806.name: Violin

ENGL 2618H.description: Writers and works in relation to the diversity of American culture, politics, lifestyles, and social movements.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities, Domestic Diversity, Social and Personal Awareness.
ENGL 2618H.name: Honors American Literature and Diversity

ENGL 4830.description: Concentrated study of the works of a British writer who has contributed significantly to the literary tradition. May be repeated once with different topic.
ENGL 4830.name: Major Figures in British Literature

ENGL 4831.description: Study of a literary genre, a group of writers who shared a cultural context or who influenced one another's work, or a trend or development in literature. May be repeated once with different topic.
ENGL 4831.name: British Genres, Circles, and Movements

ENGL 2651.description: Introduction to language principally for prospective teachers, with emphasis on the nature and function of language and its history, variations, and acquisition.
ENGL 2651.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.Gen Ed: Domestic Diversity, Social Science, Social and Personal Awareness.
ENGL 2651.name: Introduction to Language

ENGL 3710.description: Beginnings to the Enlightenment. Students read a selection of British literature, emphasizing literary history and written analysis.
ENGL 3710.name: British Literature 1

ENGL 3711.description: From Romanticism to the Present. Students read a selection of British literature, emphasizing literary history and written analysis.
ENGL 3711.name: British Literature 2

ENGL 3712.description: Colonial period to 1865. Examine works from a range of American authors and genres drama, fiction, poetry, short stories, novels, and non-fiction essays within their cultural, historical, and literary contexts.
ENGL 3712.name: American Literature 1

ENGL 3713.description: 1865 to present. Examine works from a range of American authors and genres drama, fiction, poetry, short stories, and non-fiction essays within their cultural, historical, and literary contexts.
ENGL 3713.name: American Literature 2

ENGL 2617H.description: Examination of works by and about women, drawn primarily from American and English writers.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities, Domestic Diversity, Social and Personal Awareness.
ENGL 2617H.name: Honors Women in Literature

ENGL 6920.description: Prose, poetry, and/or drama of the period studied in historical and cultural context and from various critical perspectives. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 6920.name: Twentieth-Century British Studies

ENGL 6922.description: Studies. Examines works in relation to the history and social and cultural developments of the period. Nonliterary texts may be included, such as film, visual arts, and music. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 6922.name: Twentieth-Century American

ENGL 6923.description: A study of working-class literature, culture, and artistic production, with emphasis on the literary history, the material conditions, and the intersection of race, ethnicity, gender, and sexual orientation in the works of literature by and about the working class.
ENGL 6923.name: Working Class Literature

ENGL 6927.description: Survey of historical developments from the 18th through mid-20th centuries in British and American literature for young people.
ENGL 6927.name: Historical Survey of Literature for Young People

ENGL 1540.description: Practice in adapting college-level writing conventions, organizational strategies, and revision and editing techniques to a variety of writing tasks. Focus on responding to written texts in ways that demonstrate expressive, analytical, and evaluative thinking. Students divide their time between regular classrooms and computer classrooms, where they have the opportunity to acquire and develop basic word-processing and electronic communication skills. Does not count toward the graduation requirement in composition. Open to students on the basis of Composition and Reading Test results. Grading is ABC/NC. Does not count toward the graduation requirement in composition and does not count toward a degree.
ENGL 1540.name: Introduction to College Writing

ENGL 6993.description: Examination and discussion of contemporary theories of discourse analysis, with some attention to the history and development of rhetorical theory.
ENGL 6993.name: Discourse Theory

ENGL 1590H.description: Primarily British or American works in a variety of genres, chosen to illuminate a central topic, are read and discussed critically to promote understanding and enjoyment of reading. Focused on one of four topics: Nature and the Environment, The Good Life, Science and Technology, or Social Justice.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities.
ENGL 1590H.name: Honors Introduction to Literature

ENGL 4843.description: Advanced instruction in professional and technical writing, expanding skills through the creation and design of various types of documents.
ENGL 4843.prereq: ENGL 3743 with grade of "C" or better.
ENGL 4843.name: Advanced Professional and Technical Writing

ENGL 6992.description: Focus on a selected topic in technical writing or professional communication (e.g., proposal writing, science writing, computer documentation, nonfiction prose). May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 6992.name: Professional Communication

ENGL 4849.description: Study of the skills needed to make appropriate decisions about the content, grammar, mechanics, style, organization, and format of scholarly, trade, journalistic, and other professional publications, including newsletters and electronic publications. Topics include stages in the publishing process, proofreading, hard-copy versus online editing, mechanical and substantive editing, and the use of house and press styles.
ENGL 4849.prereq: Completion of ENGL 3743 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 4849.name: Professional and Technical Editing

ENGL 6900.description: Basic concepts and methods of literary research and analysis.
ENGL 6900.name: Methods of Literary Research

ENGL 2665.description: Introduction to film as a medium of artistic expression. Technical aspects of film and the relationship of film to other media and to society.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities.
ENGL 2665.name: Introduction to Film Study

ENGL 6901.description: Theories and methods of composition research; emphasis on strategies for conducting, analyzing, and writing about classroom and workplace studies.
ENGL 6901.name: Methods of Composition Research

ENGL 3765.description: Study of a particular type of film, such as comedy, western, documentary, or science fiction. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 3765.prereq: ENGL 3710, ENGL 3711, ENGL 3712, ENGL 3713 or ENGL 2665.
ENGL 3765.name: Film Genres

ENGL 6955.description: In-depth study of selected issues in contemporary linguistic theory.
ENGL 6955.name: Advanced Linguistics

ENGL 6957.description: Supervised teaching in an English as a second language (ESL) program. Additionally, weekly seminar attendance is required.
ENGL 6957.name: TESOL Practicum

ENGL 6956.description: Introduction to teaching English as a second language (ESL), including reading, writing, listening, and speaking. Focus will be on using communicative methods with nonnative speakers.
ENGL 6956.name: TESOL Methods

ENGL 6951.description: A study of research on the learning of first and second languages. Topics include developmental sequences, learner variables, critical periods and conditions for learning, and the roles of input and interaction. The course is designed for those planning to teach languages.
ENGL 6951.name: Language Acquisition

ENGL 6950.description: An investigation of the relationship between language and society. Includes discussion of dialects and standard languages, language planning, linguistic identity, multi- and bilingualism, class, gender, ethnicity, and social interaction.
ENGL 6950.name: Sociolinguistics

ENGL 6953.description: Exploration of the issues involved in managing and producing professional publications, including publications in students' own fields. Focus on organizational, editorial, and authorial voice; editorial policies; audience analysis; and the processes by which publications are conceived, designed, and produced.
ENGL 6953.name: Publications Issues and Management

ENGL 6952.description: An investigation of the linguistic, social, and cultural dimensions of literacy. The course covers theoretical frameworks of language and literacy, the relationship between speech and writing, cultural notions of literacy, and the acquisition of literacy in first and additional languages.
ENGL 6952.name: Linguistics of Literacy

ENGL 6958.description: Descriptions and analysis of English grammar structure.
ENGL 6958.name: English Grammar

ENGL 2665H.description: Introduction to film as a medium of artistic expression. Technical aspects of film and the relationship of film to other media and to society.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities.
ENGL 2665H.name: Honors Introduction to Film Study

ENGL 1550.description: Strategies for writing as a means of critical inquiry, with focus on writing processes and on the roles of writer, audience, and purpose as they affect writing. Students divide their time between regular classrooms and computer classrooms, where they have the opportunity to acquire and develop basic word-processing and electronic communication skills. Open to students on the basis of Composition and Reading Test results or successful completion of ENGL 1509, ENGL 1539 or ENGL 1540. Grading is ABC/NC.
ENGL 1550.name: Writing 1

ENGL 1550H.description: Strategies for writing as a means of critical inquiry, with focus on writing processes and on the roles of writer, audience, and purpose as they affect writing. Writing assignments treat a broad range of ideas, especially in response to challenging readings. Stylistic experimentation is encouraged so that each student can develop a distinctive writing style. Students divide their time between regular classrooms and computer classrooms, where they have the opportunity to acquire and develop basic word-processing and electronic communication skills. Grading is ABC/NC.
ENGL 1550H.prereq: Eligibility for the Honors program and permit on the basis of Composition and Reading Test results or upon recommendation of 1550 instructor and approval of the Director of Composition.
ENGL 1550H.name: Honors Writing 1

ENGL 4852.description: Examination of the linguistic, social, and cultural dimensions of reading and writing and their impact on literacy acquisition and performance in language.
ENGL 4852.name: Linguistics of Literacy

ENGL 4850.description: An investigation of the relationship between language and society. Includes discussion of dialects and standard language, language planning, linguistic identity, multi- and bilingualism, class, gender, ethnicity, and social interaction. Listed also as FNLG 4850.
ENGL 4850.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 4850.name: Sociolinguistics

ENGL 4851.description: A study of research on the learning of first and second languages. Topics include developmental sequences, learner variables, critical periods and conditions for learning, and the roles of input and interaction. The course is designed for those planning to teach languages. Listed also as FNLG 4851.
ENGL 4851.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 4851.name: Language Acquisition

ENGL 4856.description: Introduction to teaching English as a Second Language (ESL), including reading, writing, listening, and speaking. Focus on using communicative methods with non-native speakers.
ENGL 4856.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 4856.name: TESOL Methods

ENGL 4857.description: Supervised teaching in English as a Second Language (ESL) program. Additionally, weekly seminar attendance required.
ENGL 4857.name: TESOL Practicum

ENGL 4855.description: In-depth study of selected issues in contemporary linguistic theory. Especially recommended for students pursuing advanced studies or a minor in linguistics or planning graduate studies.
ENGL 4855.name: Advanced Linguistics

ENGL 4858.description: Descriptions and analysis of English language structure.
ENGL 4858.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 4858.name: English Grammar

ENGL 4859.description: Study in depth of a specific topic such as stylistics, semantics, or rhetoric. May be repeated once with different topic.
ENGL 4859.prereq: ENGL 3740, ENGL 3741, or ENGL 3755 as appropriate to topic.
ENGL 4859.name: Selected Topics in Discourse

ENGL 3770.description: Poetry, prose, drama, and other forms of literary expression examined within the context of a specific aspect of American social, intellectual, and cultural history. May be repeated once with different topic.
ENGL 3770.name: American Literature in Historical Perspective

ENGL 6946.description: Project-based approach to theoretical and practical aspects of editing historical and literary documents for both print and digital contexts. Topics include document selection, transcription, verification, and annotation, as well as the implications for teaching and learning using traditional print and electronic archives and texts.Cross-listed: HIST 6946.
ENGL 6946.name: Historical Editing

ENGL 6944.description: Application of computer software and hardware to design and produce professional/technical documents.
ENGL 6944.name: Document Design and Production

ENGL 6945.description: Examines theory and research in professional and technical communication with emphasis on the application of theoretical concepts and empirical findings to practical problems in the field. Introduces students to theories and research methods through reading in current literature and through class research projects.
ENGL 6945.name: Theory of Professional and Technical Communication

ENGL 6943.description: In-depth discussion of audience, format, document design, and corporate structure. Focus on refining skills and providing theoretical support for practical applications.
ENGL 6943.prereq: ENGL 3743 Professional and Technical Communication and ENGL 4849 Professional and Technical Editing or ENGL 6949.
ENGL 6943.name: Technical Communication

ENGL 3743H.description: Intermediate composition course to introduce essential elements of professional and technical communication: audience and task analysis; techniques of gathering, interpreting, and presenting information; appropriate conventions, styles, and formats; elements of collaborative, global, and electronic communication; and application of computer technology to document design and production.
ENGL 3743H.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 3743H.name: Professional and Technical Writing

ENGL 2631H.description: Introductory study of myths, chiefly classical, with some attention to their origins and cultural significance, and of literary works, both classical and modern, in which myths are used.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities.
ENGL 2631H.name: Honors Mythology in Literature

ENGL 6949.description: A study of the skills needed to make appropriate changes in the content, grammar, mechanics, style, format, and organization of manuscripts for scholarly, trade, journalistic, and other professional publications. The course deals with stages in the publishing process, hard-copy versus online editing, mechanical and substantive editing, and the use of house and press styles.
ENGL 6949.name: Professional and Technical Editing

ENGL 1551H.description: Research on a topic of some depth, conducted independently and focused on a single project that results in a substantial investigative paper. Students divide their time between regular classrooms and computer classrooms, where they have the opportunity to perform research on the World Wide Web. Grading is ABC/NC.
ENGL 1551H.prereq: Eligibility for the Honors Program and any of the following: an ACT English score of 28 or higher, ENGL 1550H, or recommendation of ENGL 1550 instructor and approval of Director of Composition.
ENGL 1551H.name: Honors Writing 2

ENGL 4865.description: An important aspect of or approach to film not covered in other courses. May be repeated once with different topic.
ENGL 4865.prereq: ENGL 3710, ENGL 3711, ENGL 3712, ENGL 3713, or ENGL 2665.
ENGL 4865.name: Selected Topics in Film

ENGL 4864.description: Study of two or more American writers whose work is related. Focuses on writers who influenced each other, who wrote during the same period, or who explored similar themes or used similar literary styles.
ENGL 4864.name: American Literary Conversations

ENGL 4862.description: In-depth examination of a significant theme in American literature and culture through analysis of prose, poetry, drama, and/or film from different historical periods.
ENGL 4862.name: Themes in American Literature

ENGL 4860.description: British literature from the Anglo-Saxon period to the age of Chaucer, presented in the context of the period's history and culture.
ENGL 4860.name: The Medieval World

ENGL 6968.description: Examines forms such as poetry, the novel, the short story, essay, biography, autobiography, or travel literature. Emphasis may be on definition, development, cultural context, figures, or themes. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 6968.name: Studies in Literary Form

ENGL 6969.description: Discussion and application of approaches, techniques, and forms involved in the writing of novels.
ENGL 6969.name: Writing the Youth Novel

ENGL 3743.description: Intermediate composition course to introduce essential elements of professional and technical writing; audience and task analysis; techniques of gathering, interpreting, and presenting information; and application of computer technology to document design and production.
ENGL 3743.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 3743.name: Professional and Technical Writing

ENGL 3741.description: Designed to strengthen proficiency in writing, with emphasis on issues relating to the teaching of English. Limited to students seeking English or Integrated Language Arts certificates.
ENGL 3741.prereq: Admission to upper-division status in the College of Education.
ENGL 3741.name: Advanced Writing for Teachers

ENGL 3740.description: Designed to strengthen proficiency in essay writing, with emphasis on the development of ideas, analysis of style, clarity of thought and expression, editing, and proofreading.
ENGL 3740.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 3740.name: Advanced Writing

ENGL 3747.description: Supervised workshop in which students develop their individual poetic skills, styles, and talents. May be repeated once.
ENGL 3747.name: Poetry Writing Workshop

ENGL 3746.description: Supervised workshop in which students develop their individual narrative skills, styles, and talents. May be repeated once.
ENGL 3746.name: Fiction Writing Workshop

ENGL 3745.description: Practice in writing electronic documents, including web pages, interactive forms, and online portfolios.
ENGL 3745.name: Writing for Online Environments

ENGL 3744.description: Application of rhetorical strategies and principles of design to the preparation of texts in two specific professional communication genres: the proposal and the report.
ENGL 3744.name: Proposal and Report Writing

ENGL 2601.description: A course to increase proficiency in critical reading and writing. Designed specifically for students entering the College of Education; reading, discussions and writing assignments emphasize current issues in Education. Assignments allow students to practice, collaboratively and individually, the kinds of writing used in teaching. Does not count toward the English major.
ENGL 2601.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 2601.name: Intermediate Writing for Teachers

ENGL 3749.description: Examination and application of elements associated with novels for young readers. Students will develop their own narrative skills, styles, and talents in a supervised workshop, May be repeated once.
ENGL 3749.name: Writing the Youth Novel

ENGL 3748.description: Examination and application of story concepts, theme and character development, structure, page design, and formatting. Students will develop their own story, treatment, and screenplay. May be repeated once.
ENGL 3748.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 3748.name: Screenwriting

ENGL 6976.description: Theories, issues, and/or criticism in the teaching of English. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 6976.name: Studies in English Education

ENGL 6975.description: Approaches to teaching English and the language arts. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 6975.name: English Education Seminar

ENGL 6974.description: Intensive study and activity in a topic related to teaching English and the language arts. Does not count toward degree credit. Grading is S/U. May be repeated.
ENGL 6974.name: English Education Workshop

ENGL 6966.description: Discussion and application of approaches, techniques, and forms involved in the writing of poetry. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 6966.name: Writing of Poetry

ENGL 4870.description: A project course requiring the integration of website development tools and techniques, database development, effective writing for the web, and audience analysis, to produce a website of substantial depth and breadth. Oral and written presentations of final project. Listed also as CSIS 4870.
ENGL 4870.prereq: Senior standing and permission of instructor.Gen Ed: Capstone.
ENGL 4870.name: Web Communications Capstone

ENGL 4871.description: Study of African-American literature that explores the intersections between race, gender, and class in America, with emphasis on black minority culture, experience, and perspective.
ENGL 4871.name: The Black Experience in American Literature

ENGL 1539.description: Intensive individualized instruction in written communication and college-level reading practices in a computer-assisted environment. Open to students based on their Composition and Reading Placement Test results; does not count toward the graduation requirement in composition. Grading for English 1539 is ABC/NC. Does not count toward the graduation requirement in composition and does not count toward a degree.
ENGL 1539.name: Fundamentals of College Writing

ENGL 6963.description: An advanced study of primary and secondary texts from the field of multicultural literature and multicultural education. The course will emphasize the formation of social identities, the intersections of race, class, and gender, relationships among dominant and nondominant subjects in U.S. and other global cultures. The course will pay special attention to the theory and application of multiculturalist paradigms to education, professional work, and graduate study. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 6963.name: Perspectives in Multicultural Studies

ENGL 3755.description: Survey of elements of linguistic structure, methods of analysis and description, theoretical models, and the role of language in human affairs.
ENGL 3755.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 3755.name: Principles of Linguistic Study

ENGL 2618.description: Writers and works in relation to the diversity of American culture, politics, lifestyles, and social movements.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities, Domestic Diversity, Social and Personal Awareness.
ENGL 2618.name: American Literature and Diversity

ENGL 3757.description: Sounds, vocabulary, grammar, and usage, from old to contemporary English.
ENGL 3757.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 3757.name: Development of the English Language

ENGL 3750.description: Language structure as an instrument in human behavior and social institutions with emphasis on cross-cultural and intercultural communication.
ENGL 3750.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 3750.name: Language and Culture

ENGL 3751.description: Study of nonfiction works relevant to the theory and practice of professional writers and editors.
ENGL 3751.name: Readings in Professional and Technical Writing

ENGL 6965.description: Analysis of motion pictures and their creators; topics may include classic and contemporary styles, genres, and methods of production, as well as film theory and criticism. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 6965.name: Studies in Film

ENGL 2610.description: A survey of nonwestern literatures, emphasizing their cultural, historical, literary, and global contexts.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities, International Perspectives, Social and Personal Awareness.
ENGL 2610.name: World Literature

ENGL 6967.description: Discussion and application of approaches, techniques, and forms involved in the writing of fiction and/or nonfiction. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 6967.name: Writing of Prose

ENGL 6960.description: Examines a specific topic such as stylistics, semantics, sociolinguistics, second language acquisition, TESOL, or computational linguistics. May be repeated twice with a different topic.
ENGL 6960.name: Studies in Linguistics

ENGL 2617.description: Examination of works by and about women, drawn primarily from American and English writers.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities, Domestic Diversity, Social and Personal Awareness.
ENGL 2617.name: Women in Literature

ENGL 2615.description: Works from the science fiction and fantasy genres are read and discussed critically to promote understanding and enjoyment of reading.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities.
ENGL 2615.name: Science Fiction and Fantasy Literature

ENGL 1551.description: Practice in writing with emphasis on the process of investigation: exploration of topics, formulation of tentative theses, collection of data from suitable primary and secondary sources, and clear and appropriate presentation of the results of these inquiries. Students divide their time between regular classrooms and computer classrooms, where they have the opportunity to perform research on the World Wide Web. Grading is ABC/NC.
ENGL 1551.prereq: ENGL 1550 or ACT English score of 28 or higher, or appropriate Composition and Reading Test results.
ENGL 1551.name: Writing 2

ENGL 1509.description: Development of writing and reading comprehension skills in English through outlining, summary, and response. Emphasis on vocabulary, main idea, detail, and conclusion in assigned reading and writing. Entrance on basis of English-as-a-Second-Language placement test. Must be taken until a grade of C or better is achieved. May be repeated once with a different topic. Does not count toward a degree. Grading is ABC/NC.
ENGL 1509.name: Academic English for Non-native Speakers

ENGL 6991.description: Special topics in literature and creative writing for students in the Master of Fine Arts (MFA) program in creative writing. May be repeated once.
ENGL 6991.name: Special Topics MFA

ENGL 4887.description: Study of British literature from 1776 to 1832 and the social, cultural, and artistic forces that influenced it.
ENGL 4887.name: The Romantic Period

ENGL 4886.description: Study of British literature of the period and the social, cultural, and artistic forces that influenced it.
ENGL 4886.name: Restoration and Eighteenth Century British Literature

ENGL 4881.description: Study of Shakespeare's works along with an exploration of the artistic and social forces that shaped his writing.
ENGL 4881.name: Shakespeare and His World

ENGL 6997.description: Supervised work-and-learning experience in English under the direction of an English Department faculty member and an employee of a participating firm. Ten to 20 hours a week of student time are expected. Enrollment is contingent upon the availability of internships. Students are selected on the basis of personal qualifications, including GPA, courses taken, recommendations, and an interview. Either ENGL 6997 or ENGL 6998 may count toward the degree, not both.
ENGL 6997.name: English Internship

ENGL 4882.description: Study of British literature from 1500 to 1660 and the social, cultural, and artistic forces that influenced it.
ENGL 4882.name: The English Renaissance

ENGL 6999.prereq: Thesis proposal accepted by departmental committee.
ENGL 6999.name: Thesis

ENGL 6998.description: Supervised work-and-learning experience in professional communication under the direction of a University faculty member and an employee of a participating firm. Ten to 20 hours a week of student time are expected. Enrollment is contingent upon the availability of internships. Students are selected on the basis of personal qualifications, including GPA, courses taken, recommendations, and an interview. Either ENGL 6997 or ENGL 6998 may count toward the degree-not both.
ENGL 6998.name: Professional Writing Internship

ENGL 2623.description: Analysis of literary representations of work and class, with special attention to working class authors, subjects, and styles. Focuses on social and historical influences, as well as the impact of social changes and new knowledge upon working-class literature.
ENGL 2623.name: Literature, Work, and Class

ENGL 2620.description: Survey of pre-colonial, colonial, post-colonial, and modern African literature, with emphasis on experiences, styles, and themes of African writers. The effects of African literature on cultural discourse throughout the world.
ENGL 2620.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities.
ENGL 2620.name: African Literature

ENGL 6919.description: Contemporary young adult literature. Emphasis may be on development, trends, critical standards, cultural context, classroom selection and use. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 6919.name: Studies in Young Adult Literature

ENGL 6918.description: Contemporary children's literature. Emphasis may be on development, trends, critical standards, cultural context, classroom selection and use. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 6918.name: Studies in Children's Literature

ENGL 6911.description: Study of selected literary works reflecting medieval thought and culture. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 6911.name: The Medieval World

ENGL 6913.description: Varying emphases on the dramatic works of Shakespeare and/or his contemporaries. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 6913.name: Shakespeare and Renaissance Drama

ENGL 6912.description: Nondramatic literature of the British Renaissance. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 6912.name: Sixteenth- and 17th-Century British Studies

ENGL 6915.description: Prose, poetry, and/or drama from the colonial period up to the early 19th century examined in their historical and cultural contexts. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 6915.name: Early American Studies

ENGL 6914.description: Prose, poetry, and/or drama of the period studied in historical and cultural context and from various critical perspectives. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 6914.name: Restoration and 18th-Century British Studies

ENGL 6917.description: Examines 19th-century American literature and culture through particular themes, genres, styles, periods, and/or figures. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 6917.name: Nineteenth-Century American Studies

ENGL 6916.description: Prose, poetry, and/or drama of the period studied in historical and cultural context and from various critical perspectives. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 6916.name: Nineteenth-Century British Studies

ENGL 3780.description: Study of a particular type of literature (e.g., short story, autobiography, or film) as it developed in the United States. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 3780.name: American Genres

ENGL 1512.description: Development of conversation skills. Focus on oral-aural fluency, idiomaticity, extracting and organizing information, and situation-oriented communication strategies. Emphasis on meaningful topics relevant to the students' pursuit of their academic goals. Entrance on basis of English-as-a-Second-Language placement test. Does not count toward a degree. Grading is ABC/NC.
ENGL 1512.name: English Conversation for Non-native Speakers

ENGL 3738H.description: A comparative examination of a genre, historical period, or literary movement. May be repeated once with different topic.
ENGL 3738H.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 3738H.name: Selected Topics World Lit

ENGL 4896.description: Literature read in the context of the period's literary movements, culture, and history.
ENGL 4896.name: British Literature from World War II to the Present

ENGL 2631.description: Introductory study of myths, chiefly classical, with some attention to their origins and cultural significance, and of literary works, both classical and modern, in which myths are used.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities.
ENGL 2631.name: Mythology in Literature

ENGL 4895.description: Literature read in the context of the period's literary movements, culture, and history.
ENGL 4895.name: Early Twentieth Century British Studies

ENGL 4892.description: Nineteenth-century writers, works, and themes read in the context of the period's culture and history.
ENGL 4892.name: Nineteenth Century British Literature Studies

ENGL 4890.description: Study of literature, linguistics, or criticism and theory requiring a long, critical, research-based paper.
ENGL 4890.prereq: ENGL 3710, ENGL 3711, ENGL 3712 or ENGL 3713 and six additional courses in the major.Gen Ed: Capstone.
ENGL 4890.name: Senior Seminar

ENGL 4891.description: Exploration of a topic in English studies. An academic project or written report produced in consultation with an English instructor is required. May be repeated with different topics for a maximum of 3 s.h.
ENGL 4891.prereq: Senior standing in English and department permit.
ENGL 4891.name: Individual Study

ENGL 6989.description: Techniques and strategies for teaching college composition, including course design and classroom practice. Required of and limited to graduate assistants who are teaching in the English Department. First-year graduate assistants must register for three semester hours of Teaching Practicum in two successive semesters for a total of six semester hours. Does not count toward degree credit. Grading is S/U.
ENGL 6989.name: Teaching Practicum

ENGL 4898.description: Supervised work-and-learning experiences in professional communication under the direction of a faculty member and an employee of a participating firm. Ten to 20 hours of student time each week. Enrollment is contingent upon the availability of internships. Students are selected on the basis of relevant qualifications, including GPA, courses taken, recommendations, and an interview. May be repeated with the approval of the department chairperson.
ENGL 4898.name: Professional and Technical Writing Internship

ENGL 4899.description: Capstone experience for the Professional Writing and Editing major. Individualized research, analysis, development, and oral presentation of a project that incorporates audience-appropriate writing, design, and/or editing in a usable high-quality product. Taken during the students final undergraduate year.
ENGL 4899.prereq: ENGL 3743 with grade "C" or better.Gen Ed: Capstone.
ENGL 4899.name: Professional and Technical Writing Senior Project

ENGL 3732.description: An examination through language, literature, folklore, film and myth of the ways in which the meanings and representations of women have been constructed and implemented in Western culture. Introduces key concepts and theoretical frameworks drawn from current scholarship about women.
ENGL 3732.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 3732.name: Images of Women

ENGL 3730.description: Introduces middle school language arts teacher candidates to discussions about the teaching of writing and language and the development of methods of teaching reading, writing, and language.
ENGL 3730.prereq: ENGL 1551 with a grade of "C" or better.
ENGL 3730.name: Teaching Language Arts

ENGL 3737.description: Introduction to critical issues and approaches to popular culture through the study of various texts from literature, television, film, advertising, popular music, and computer cyberculture.
ENGL 3737.prereq: ENGL 1551 with grade of "C" or better.
ENGL 3737.name: Popular Culture Studies

ENGL 6902.description: May focus on particular theoretical approaches or provide an overview of literary criticism. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 6902.name: Literary Thought

ENGL 3738.description: A comparative examination of a genre, historical period, or literary movement. May be repeated once with different topic.
ENGL 3738.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 3738.name: Selected Topics in World Literature

ENGL 3739.description: Designed to strengthen proficiency in writing, with emphasis on issues related to the teaching of English in middle school. Limited to students seeking middle childhood licensure with a concentration in Language Arts.
ENGL 3739.prereq: Admission to upper division status in the Beeghly College of Education.
ENGL 3739.name: Writing for Middle School Teachers

ENGL 6906.description: Problems, issues, practices, and research that affect the teaching of literature at various grade levels and in college courses.
ENGL 6906.name: Teaching of Literature

ENGL 6907.description: Problems, issues, practices, and research that affect the teaching of writing at various grade levels and in college courses.
ENGL 6907.name: Teaching of Writing

ENGL 3790.description: Concentrated study of discourse in English, primarily literature, from cultures other than the dominant or majority culture of a given society. Designed to develop awareness and sensitivity to issues of difference, power, and cross-cultural perspectives, and to address and facilitate students' multicultural literacy. May be repeated once with different topic.
ENGL 3790.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 3790.name: Selected Topics in Multicultural Studies

ENGL 4821.description: Study of the role and responsibilities of the media advisor in high school and college. Topics include the unique legal and ethical concerns of student media, the training of student staff, the relationship of the student press to the academic administration, and publication-management concerns. Listed also as JOUR 4821.
ENGL 4821.name: Advising Student Media

ENGL 4897.description: Supervised experience directed by an English faculty member and a designated representative of a participating organization. Enrollment is contingent upon the availability of internships. Students are selected on the basis of qualifications including GPA, courses taken, recommendations and an interview.
ENGL 4897.prereq: 12 hours of English, junior or senior standing, and a department permit.
ENGL 4897.name: English Internship

ENGL 1560.description: Basic understanding of relations between ethnicity, gender, and speech style, distinguishing linguistics, sociolinguistics, and women's issues. Examination of topics such as language, socialization, oral vs written language, language and class membership, and intra-ethnicity variation in Urban Vernacular English.
ENGL 1560.name: Language, Ethnicity, and Gender

ENGL 2647.description: Examination and application of poetic techniques and conventions designed to introduce the basic elements of writing poetry.
ENGL 2647.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 2647.name: Introduction to Poetry Writing

ENGL 2646.description: Examination and application of narrative techniques and conventions designed to introduce the basic elements of writing fiction.
ENGL 2646.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 2646.name: Introduction to Fiction Writing

ENGL 3706.description: Provides an introduction to literary theory and criticism for English majors, emphasizing the history and application of critical approaches to literature. By reading core works in literary theory, students will learn application of theoretical approaches to various texts.
ENGL 3706.name: Introduction to Literary Theory

ENGL 3705.description: Study of literature for and about adolescents and of related topics, including young adults as readers, critical standards for evaluation, and the use of adolescent literature in secondary schools.
ENGL 3705.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 3705.name: Young Adult Literature

ENGL 3704.description: Study of fiction and nonfiction genres for students in the middle school grades, including characters and authors from various cultures and ethnicities. Required of middle childhood reading and language arts majors.
ENGL 3704.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 3704.name: Literature for Middle School Readers

ENGL 3703.description: Study of the development of children's literature, giving the prospective elementary teacher criteria for evaluating books for children. Required of all elementary education candidates.
ENGL 3703.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 3703.name: Literature for Young Children

ENGL 3700.description: Gateway course for English majors. Content to include key terms, strategies for reading, interpretation, research, and the conventions for assessing and using sources.
ENGL 3700.prereq: Completion of ENGL 1551 with grade "C" or better.
ENGL 3700.name: Literary Study

ENGL 1590.description: Literary works from various genres and periods by culturally diverse authors. Students learn literary terms to analyze and interpret literature. A major goal is to improve critical thinking skills by relating literature to film, music, art and/or live performance.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities.
ENGL 1590.name: Introduction to Literature

ENGL 6935.description: Prose, poetry, and/or drama of the period studied in historical and cultural context and from various critical perspectives. May be repeated once with a different topic.
ENGL 6935.name: Studies in Romanticism

HBRW 3706.description: Reading and discussion in Hebrew of selections from the Hebrew Scriptures. May be repeated once if the texts studied are different.
HBRW 3706.name: Readings in Hebrew Scripture

HBRW 2605.description: Reading and discussion in Hebrew of selections from the Hebrew Scripture.
HBRW 2605.name: Advanced Intermediate Hebrew

HBRW 3799.description: An individually-arranged program of foreign study in the Hebrew language. Programs can be of two general types: (1) trips or residential programs sponsored by consortial universities, and (2) independent academic coursework through institutions with which YSU does not have a consortial agreement. A written statement detailing the student's academic plan must be approved by a member of the Hebrew faculty, the chair of Foreign Languages and the dean of CLASS prior to the trip. May be repeated up to a total of 15 s.h., if specific course content changes. Note: study abroad generally requires about one year's advance planning.
HBRW 3799.prereq: Sophomore status and approval of the chair of Foreign Languages.
HBRW 3799.name: Study Abroad in Hebrew

HBRW 2600.description: Intensive training in understanding, speaking, reading, and writing Hebrew; knowledge of geography and daily life as well as appreciation of the culture of Hebrew speakers. Assignments in the Language Learning and Resource Center (LLRC).
HBRW 2600.name: Intermediate Hebrew

HBRW 1550.description: Beginning training in understanding, speaking, reading, and writing Hebrew. Geography and daily life, as well as appreciation of the culture of its speakers, are studied. Assignments in the Language Learning and Resource Center (LLRC). Grading is ABC/NC.
HBRW 1550.name: Elementary Hebrew

ITAL 3799.description: An individually-arranged program of foreign study in the Italian language. Programs can be of two general types: (1) trips or residential programs sponsored by consortial universities, and (2) independent academic coursework through institutions with which YSU does not have a consortial agreement. A written statement detailing the student's academic plan must be approved by a member of the Italian faculty, the chair of Foreign Languages and the dean of CLASS prior to the trip. Credit toward fulfillment of requirements for the Italian major will be determined by the chair of Foreign Languages and the Italian faculty. May be repeated up to a total of 15 s.h., if specific course content changes. Note: study abroad generally requires about one year's advance planning.
ITAL 3799.prereq: Sophomore status and approval of the chair of Foreign Languages.
ITAL 3799.name: Study Abroad in Italian

ITAL 3780.description: Review course emphasizing impromptu conversations and in-class essay writing. Intended for students who need additional coursework to achieve the level of Advanced Low on the ACTFL Oral Proficiency Interview and/or the ACTFL Writing Proficiency Test. May not be counted toward the major. Grading CR/NC.
ITAL 3780.prereq: 16 s.h. in Italian at the 3700 level or above and permission of Chair.
ITAL 3780.name: Italian Composition and Conversation Review

ITAL 4881.description: Capstone course emphasizing impromptu conversations and in-class essay writing. Students must achieve a level of Intermediate High on both the ACTFL Oral Proficiency Interview and the ACTFL Writing Proficiency Test.
ITAL 4881.prereq: 16 s.h. in Italian at the 3700 level or above and permission of Chair.
ITAL 4881.name: Italian Composition and Conversation Capstone

ITAL 3741.description: Introduction to Italian literature from the Enlightenment to the present through representative selections of key literary figures. Theoretical and critical approaches to help interpret texts. Regular in-class discussion and occasional in-class writing assignments, all in Italian.
ITAL 3741.name: Survey of Italian Literature 2

ITAL 3740.description: Introduction to Italian literature from the 14th Century to the Renaissance through representative selections of key literary figures. Theoretical and critical approaches to help interpret texts. Regular in-class discussion and occasional in-class writing assignments, all in Italian.
ITAL 3740.name: Survey of Italian Literature 1

ITAL 3750.description: A study of contemporary Italian literature and its movements and innovations across a variety of genres, including fiction, memoir, poetry, song lyrics, rap and journalism. Featuring the works of Ammaniti, Baricco, Benni, Consoli, Khouma, Mazzucco, Severgnini and Virzl. Regular in-class discussion and occasional in-class writing assignments, all in Italian.
ITAL 3750.name: Contemporary Italian Literature

ITAL 4880.description: Capstone course emphasizing impromptu conversations and in-class essay writing. Students must achieve a level of Advanced Low on both the ACTFL Oral Proficiency Interview and the ACTFL Writing Proficiency Test.
ITAL 4880.prereq: 16 s.h. in Italian at the 3700 level or above and permission of Chair.Gen Ed: Capstone.
ITAL 4880.name: Italian Conversation and Composition Capstone

ITAL 3724.description: Examination of basic concepts and issues of modern Italian linguistic theory in the areas of phonology, morphology, syntax and pragmatics., Special emphasis is placed on sociolinguistics and on theory and practice in Italian phonetics aimed at improving the pronunciation and intonation of second language learners. Regular in-class discussion and occasional in-class writing assignments, all in Italian.
ITAL 3724.name: Italian Linguistics and Phonetics

ITAL 3798.description: A structured but individualized program of study at the Culturforum Italian Language School in Cefalu, Sicily.
ITAL 3798.prereq: either ITAL 3702 or both ITAL 2605 and permission of Chair.
ITAL 3798.name: Study Abroad in Sicily

ITAL 2600.description: Intensive training in understanding, speaking, reading, and writing Italian; knowledge of geography and daily life as well as appreciation of the cultures of Italian speakers. Assignments in the Language Learning and Resource Center (LLRC).
ITAL 2600.name: Intermediate Italian
