Students submit a proposal of the internship, maintain a journal of experiences, and submit a final project paper.
BIOL 4899.prereq: Junior or senior standing in Biological Sciences and permission of the chairperson.
BIOL 4899.name: Internships in the Biological Sciences

BIOL 3725.description: Overview of structure, function, evolutionary history, behavior, ecology, and classification of mammals. Animal groups will be studied from diverse biological points of view.  Three hours lecture.
BIOL 3725.name: Mammalogy

BIOL 6950.description: The study of physiological mechanisms and adaptations of animals to environmental stresses of their habitats. Three hours lecture and three hours laboratory per week.
BIOL 6950.name: Comparative Animal Physiology

BIOL 5888.description: Lectures will cover the use of microbes for solving environmental problems. In the laboratory, teams of students will design and implement experiments in bioremediation. This course is intended for students in biology, environmental studies, chemistry, and engineering. Two hours lecture and four hours lab.
BIOL 5888.name: Environmental Biotechnology

BIOL 3741.description: Examination of the diversity of animal species and their interaction with the environment; the morphology, reproduction and ecology of a wide variety of invertebrate and vertebrate phylon. Three hours lecture, two hours lab.
BIOL 3741.name: Animal Diversity

BIOL 3740.description: Examination of the diversity of plant species and their interaction with the environment; the morphology, reproduction and ecology of a wide variety of vascular and nonvascular plants. Three hours lecture, two hours lab.
BIOL 3740.name: Plant Diversity

BIOL 3745.description: Examination of the physiology of higher plants with emphasis on the whole plant aspects as well as on biochemical, cellular and molecular aspects of how plants function including transport and translocation of water and solutes, photosynthesis and respiration, growth and development.
BIOL 3745.name: Plant Physiology

BIOL 4878.description: A socioeconomic, political and ecological approach to issues associated with the maintenance and value of biodiversity and ecosystem services; consequences of anthropogenic climate change, fragmentation, overharvesting, extinction, and invasion of non-native species; biofuels; ecological restoration, nature reserve design and sustainability. Three hours lecture.
BIOL 4878.prereq: BIOL 3759 or BIOL 3780 or permission of instructor.
BIOL 4878.name: Conservation Biology

BIOL 8869.description: Regional study of the human body with emphasis on functional and topographic anatomy and clinical correlations. Two hours lecture. Four hours lab.
BIOL 8869.name: Human Gross Anatomy 2

BIOL 4871.description: Introduction to the morphology, physiology, development, and control of insects. Survey of insect orders and families. Two hours lecture, four hours lab.
BIOL 4871.name: Entomology

BIOL 3705L.description: Introduction to Human Gross Anatomy Laboratory.
BIOL 3705L.name: Introduction to Human Gross Anatomy Laboratory

BIOL 3710.description: Composite study of the anatomical systems of mammals, based on the cat. One hour lecture, four hours lab.
BIOL 3710.name: Mammalian Anatomy

BIOL 6934L.description: An experimental approach to the examination of advanced human physiology through a detailed study of selected body systems.  Systems examined may include the cardiovascular, respiratory, and renal system, exchange dynamics among body fluid compartments, and acid-base balance.  Three hours lab.
BIOL 6934L.name: Advanced Physiology: Integrative Mechanisms Laboratory

BIOL 5813.description: The microscopic study of mammalian tissues and organs. Three hours lecture, two hours lab.
BIOL 5813.name: Vertebrate Histology

BIOL 8868.description: Regional study of the human body with emphasis on functional and topographic anatomy and clinical correlations.  Two hours of lecture-demonstration four hours of lab. h.
BIOL 8868.prereq: Admission to the YSU Physical Therapy Program  4 s.
BIOL 8868.name: Human Gross Anatomy 1

BIOL 5811.description: Structure, physiology, behavior, ecology, and evolution of birds. Natural history of common bird species and important bird groups, especially those in Ohio. Basic methods and skills for field study of birds. Three hours lecture, three hours lab.
BIOL 5811.name: Ornithology

BIOL 2603.description: This course is an introduction to general biology that focuses on those aspects of biology that are the fundamental basis of medicine and human biology.
BIOL 2603.name: Integrated Biology for BS/MD

BIOL 2602.description: The structure and function of plants and animals. Examination of the structure and functioning of organismic communities and ecosystems. Required of all biological sciences majors. Three hours of lecture, three hours of lab per week.
BIOL 2602.prereq: BIOL 2601 and CHEM 1515.Gen Ed: Science Substitute.
BIOL 2602.name: General Biology: Organisms and Ecology

BIOL 2601.description: The chemical and physical foundations of life, structure and function of cells and organelles, metabolism, basic molecular biology and inheritance, and principles of evolution. Three hours of lecture, three hours of lab per week.
BIOL 2601.prereq: CHEM 1515 or concurrent enrollment in CHEM 1515.Gen Ed: Science Substitute.
BIOL 2601.name: General Biology: Molecules and Cells

BIOL 6948.description: Examination of fungal and fungal-like organisms with emphasis placed upon their taxonomy, phylogenetic relationships, structure, function, physiology, genetics, and ecology. Their role in agriculture, medicine, and scientific research is explored as well. Three hours lecture and three hours laboratory.
BIOL 6948.name: Biology of Fungi

BIOL 6949.description: Specific cellular and molecular processes in fungal organisms will be examined in great detail. Topic areas include morphogenesis, dimorphism, signal transduction, gene expression and regulation, cellular differentiation, nutritional physiology, primary and secondary metabolism, and host/parasite interactions.
BIOL 6949.prereq: BIOL 3702 or equivalent, and graduate standing.
BIOL 6949.name: Cellular and Molecular Mycology

BIOL 3730.description: Concepts of human physiology that focus on the regulation of homeostatic mechanisms by the neural, endocrine, cardiovascular, respiratory, and renal systems. Four hours lecture.
BIOL 3730.name: Human Physiology

BIOL 3759.description: Examination of fundamental evolutionary mechanisms integral to such covered topics as natural selection, drift, genetic variance maintenance, gene flow consequences, phylogenetic resolution, modes of speciation, coevolution, cooperation and mating system structure. Ecological concepts will be integrated throughout.
BIOL 3759.prereq: BIOL 2601 and BIOL 2602 or instructor consent.
BIOL 3759.name: Evolution

BIOL 7000.description: An arranged course on subjects of microbiology. May be repeated with a different subject up to 2 s.h.
BIOL 7000.name: Topics in Microbiology

BIOL 6957.description: Fundamentals of immunological systems, including both humoral and cellular immunological responses. Immune response to infections, transplantation rejection, autoimmune diseases, allergy, and autoimmunity. Three hours of lecture a week.
BIOL 6957.name: Advanced Immunology

BIOL 4849.description: Survey of infectious diseases caused by fungi including their etiology, epidemiology, histopathology, diagnosis, and treatment. Host-parasite interactions and the environmental and molecular factors that contribute to establishment of fungal disease in humans and animals.
BIOL 4849.name: Medical Mycology

BIOL 4848.description: Examination of fungal and fungal-like organisms with emphasis placed upon their taxonomy, phylogenetic relationships, structure, function, physiology, genetics, and ecology. Exploration of their role in agriculture, medicine, and scientific research.
BIOL 4848.name: Biology of Fungi

BIOL 5824.description: Explores the biological basis of human experience and behavior. Topics include basic neuroanatomy and neuropharmacology, emotions, learning and memory, sleep and biological rhythms, reproductive behavior, and communication. Three hours lecture, three hours lab.
BIOL 5824.name: Behavioral Neuroscience

BIOL 4841.description: Biological implications of parasitism. Diagnosis, morphology, and life histories of the parasites of humans and domestic animals. One hour lecture, four hours lab.
BIOL 4841.name: Animal Parasitology

BIOL 5823.description: Mechanisms and control of eukaryotic DNA replication, current advances in understanding the genetics basis of cancer and other genetic diseases, problems and benefits of the various eukaryotic genome projects (human and others), gene therapy and genetic engineering in animals and plants.
BIOL 5823.name: Advanced Eukaryotic Genetics

BIOL 5804.description: Ecological, physical, and chemical aspects of aquatic ecosystems. Study of the interaction between organisms and their environment.
BIOL 5804.name: Aquatic Biology

BIOL 4890L.description: Introduction to basic molecular techniques such as transformation, use of restriction enzymes, agarose gel electrophoresis, and polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Three hours lab.
BIOL 4890L.name: Molecular Genetics Laboratory

BIOL 5806.description: Field study involving quantitative methods for the collection, analysis, and interpretation of ecological data in populations and communities. Pre-field trip lectures, specified experiments, independent study, a written report, and an oral presentation of the independent study project. Required off-campus travel. Field conditions may be rigorous and/or primitive.
BIOL 5806.name: Field Ecology

BIOL 6951.description: The study of processes critical to the development, maintenance, and function of the nervous system. Topics will be presented from an experimental perspective using the scientific literature as a resource.
BIOL 6951.name: Developmental and Comparative Neurobiology

BIOL 6982.description: A course dealing with the principles of pedagogy for BIOL 1552 Anatomy and Physiology II. This course addresses classroom and laboratory topics in human anatomy and physiology with an emphasis on the relationships between instruction and learning outcomes. Required of graduate teaching assistants providing instructional support for BIOL 1552. Students will be assigned a grade of S/U. May be repeated.
BIOL 6982.name: Teaching Practicum: 1552 Anatomy and Physiology 2

BIOL 6937.description: A socioeconomic, political and ecological approach to issues associated with the maintenance and value of biodiversity and ecosystem services; consequences of anthropogenic climate change, fragmentation, overharvesting, extinction, and invasion of non-native species; biofuels; ecological restoration, nature reserve design and sustainability.
BIOL 6937.prereq: BIOL 3759 or BIOL 3750 or permission from instructor.
BIOL 6937.name: Conservation Biology

BIOL 6957L.description: Immunologic laboratory techniques. Four hours of laboratory a week. Should be taken concurrently with BIOL 6957.
BIOL 6957L.name: Advanced Immunology Laboratory

BIOL 5861.description: Detailed examination of a variety of topics necessary for understanding animal behavior. Historical approaches to animal behavior, evolution and behavior genetics, physiology of behavior, behavioral ecology, and social organization and mating systems.
BIOL 5861.name: Animal Behavior

BIOL 1545.description: Explores the structure and function of the human body and its organ systems. Diseases and their relationship to various physiological systems. Four hours lecture, two hours lab. Not applicable to the Biology major.
BIOL 1545.prereq: High school biology and chemistry, or equivalent.Gen Ed: Science Substitute.
BIOL 1545.name: Allied Health Anatomy and Physiology

BIOL 5865.description: Functional Human Gross Anatomy. An applied perspective on human anatomical structure and function. Human anatomy will be studied from diverse points of view including, lecture, biomechanical discussion, anatomical models, and cadaver dissection. Three hours lecture, two hours laboratory.
BIOL 5865.name: Functional Human Gross Anatomy

BIOL 4835L.description: Experimental approach to the examination of advanced human physiology through a detailed study of selected body systems. Systems examined may include the musculoskeletal, gastrointestinal, metabolic and thermoregulatory. Three hours lab.Prereq. or concurrent BIOL 4835.
BIOL 4835L.name: Advanced Physiology: Regulatory Mechanisms Laboratory

BIOL 5868.description: Regional study of the human body with emphasis on functional and topographic anatomy and clinical correlations. Two hours lecture-demonstration, four hours lab.
BIOL 5868.prereq: Admission to the YSU Physical Therapy program or permission of instructor.
BIOL 5868.name: Gross Anatomy 1

BIOL 5869.description: Regional study of the human body with emphasis on functional and topographic anatomy and clinical correlations. Two hours lecture-demonstration, four hours lab.
BIOL 5869.name: Gross Anatomy 2

BIOL 3762.description: Identification, ecology, and significance of local plants. Two hours lecture, four hours lab.
BIOL 3762.name: Field Botany

BIOL 4850.description: Special biological problems for which materials and equipment are available and for which the student is qualified.
BIOL 4850.prereq: Senior standing or consent of the chairperson.
BIOL 4850.name: Problems in Biology

BIOL 3730L.description: Experimental approach to the study of human physiology that explores regulation of homeostasis by the neural, endocrine, cardiovascular, respiratory, and renal systems. Three hours laboratory.Prereq. or concurrent: BIOL 3730.
BIOL 3730L.name: Human Physiology Laboratory

BIOL 6952.description: Controlling variables, experimental design, and treatment of data from biological experiments.
BIOL 6952.name: Experimental Design

BIOL 3702.description: Fundamentals of the biology of microbes. The principles of microbial structure, function, reproduction, metabolism, genetics, phylogeny, host-parasite relationships, and immunity. Fundamental technical skills acquired through laboratory experiences. Three hours lecture, three hours laboratory.
BIOL 3702.prereq: BIOL 2601 or BIOL 2603 and concurrent enrollment in BIOL 3702L.
BIOL 3702.name: Microbiology

BIOL 6929.description: An examination of the structure, function, integration, and cellular control of the brain and spinal cord. Three hours lecture, two hours lab. Students who have enrolled in BIOL 4929 will not receive credit for this course.
BIOL 6929.name: Functional Neuroanatomy

BIOL 1552.description: Structure, function, and clinical applications of the endocrine, cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, digestive, and reproductive systems. Targeted for students in nursing and associated health professions. Three hours lecture, two hours lab. Not applicable to the Biology major.
BIOL 1552.name: Anatomy and Physiology 2

BIOL 1551.description: Structure, function, and clinical applications of the integument, musculature, skeletal, and nervous systems. Targeted for students in nursing and associated health professions. Three hours of lecture. Not applicable to the Biology major.
BIOL 1551.prereq: High school biology, CHEM 1501 or equivalent, and MATH 1501 or equivalent.Gen Ed: Science Substitute.
BIOL 1551.name: Anatomy and Physiology 1

BIOL 5853.description: Application of fundamental theory and procedures to the statistical analysis of biological data.
BIOL 5853.name: Biometry

BIOL 3775.description: Comparison of morphology of vertebrates, emphasizing evolutionary development of organ systems. Two hours lecture, three hours lab.
BIOL 3775.name: Comparative Vertebrate Anatomy

BIOL 6993.description: This course engages the student in the world of proteins, from the basic structure and function of proteins in biological systems, to the applied sciences involved in the development of commercially valuable proteins.  This course extends the students previous understanding and expertise in molecular biology to emphasize proteins.
BIOL 6993.name: Biology of Proteins

BIOL 6991.description: Discussion and demonstration of current methods and concepts related to research in biological sciences and writing of a graduate thesis proposal.  Not applicable for students enrolled in the nonthesis or biology education options.   May be repeated once.
BIOL 6991.name: Research Methods for Thesis

BIOL 6997.description: An arranged course in subjects at the molecular level of life. May  be repeated with different subject up to 2 s.h.
BIOL 6997.name: Topics in Molecular and Cellular Biology

BIOL 6996.description: An arranged course in terrestrial and aquatic ecology. May be repeated with a different subject up to 2 s.h.
BIOL 6996.name: Topics in Ecology

BIOL 4823.description: This course will present the student with the comprehensive body of knowledge concerning cancer biology. It will draw upon all areas of biological sciences; from environmental causal factors to the molecular mechanisms underlying tumor cell formation and development of malignant tumors. The scientific basis of therapies will be explored.
BIOL 4823.name: Cancer Biology

BIOL 4822.description: Overview of drugs used for the diagnosis, prevention, and treatment of disease. Topics include mechanisms of action, therapeutic and adverse drug effects, and clinical uses for each drug category.
BIOL 4822.name: Principles of Pharmacology

BIOL 6998.description: An arranged course for advanced subjects in vertebrate physiology. May be repeated with a different subject up to 2 s.h.
BIOL 6998.name: Topics in Physiology

BIOL 4829.description: This course synthesizes material covered in introductory microbiology and cell and molecular biology. Topics include biomolecule synthesis, molecular biology, bacterial genetics, gene expression, energy production photosynthesis, bacteriophages and microbial stress response.
BIOL 4829.name: Microbial Physiology

BIOL 6911.description: Overview of biomechanical principles involved with the structure and function of animals.  Topics include mechanical properties of biomaterials, comparative muscle architecture and physiology, and locomotor mechanisms of human walking and running.  Three hours lecture and two hours lab.
BIOL 6911.prereq: BIOL 2602 or BIOL 3705, and PHYS 1501 or PHYS 2610.
BIOL 6911.name: Comparative Biomechanics

BIOL 6935L.description: The experimental approach to the examination of advanced human physiology through a detailed study of selected body systems. Systems examined may include the musculoskeletal, gastrointestinal, metabolic and thermoregulatory. Three hours lab.
BIOL 6935L.prereq: BIOL 6935 or concurrent enrollment in BIOL 6935.
BIOL 6935L.name: Advanced Physiology: Regulatory Mechanisms Laboratory

BIOL 2602L.description: General Biology: Organisms and Ecology Laboratory.
BIOL 2602L.name: General Biology: Organisms and Ecology Laboratory

BIOL 6964.description: An examination of the mechanisms of transcription, translation, DNA replication, and RNA processing and transposition in both prokaryotes and eukaryotes.
BIOL 6964.prereq: BIOL 4890 Molecular Genetics or permission of instructor.
BIOL 6964.name: Advanced Molecular Genetics

BIOL 2602H.description: The structure and function of plants and animals. Examination of the structure and functioning of organismic communities and ecosystems. Required of all biological sciences majors. Three hours of lecture, three hours of lab per week.
BIOL 2602H.prereq: BIOL 2601 and CHEM 1515.Gen Ed: Science Substitute.
BIOL 2602H.name: Honors General Biology Organisms and Ecology

BIOL 3705.description: Overview of human structure, using a regional approach to examine the functional anatomy of the musculoskeletal, nervous, and visceral systems. Three hours lecture, two hours lab.
BIOL 3705.name: Introduction to Human Gross Anatomy

BIOL 3704.description: The physical origins and development of the human species as a member of the primate order and the biological bases of human differences disclosed by human paleontology and archaeology. Also listed with ANTH 3703.
BIOL 3704.name: Biological Anthropology

BIOL 3701.description: Introduction to interdisciplinary research in Biology and Mathematics. Topics include current research by faculty and students, cross disciplinary communication, report writing, technical presentations, literature reading, laboratory techniques and safety. May be repeated once. Listed also as MATH 3701.
BIOL 3701.name: Biomathematics Seminar

BIOL 3703.description: Fundamentals of immunology, including both humoral and cellular immunological responses. Applications of immunological methods in medical research and patient treatment.
BIOL 3703.prereq: BIOL 2601 or BIOL 2603 and BIOL 3702 recommended.
BIOL 3703.name: Clinical Immunology

BIOL 1560.description: Characteristics, epidemiology, and pathology of viruses, bacteria, and protozoa of medical significance. Other topics dealing with the control of microorganisms and food microbiology will be covered. Not applicable to a biology major. Two hours of lecture. Must be taken concurrent with BIOL 1560L or substitute.
BIOL 1560.name: Microbiology for the Health Professions

BIOL 4836.description: The relationship of molecular structure to cellular function. Concepts will be presented integrating the biochemical dynamics of bio-membrane systems including receptors, bioenergetics, and the physiochemical environment. Three hours of lecture.
BIOL 4836.name: Cell Biology: Molecular Mechanisms

BIOL 4837.description: The relationship of nucleic acid structure and protein structure will be studied in hands on series of laboratory experiments. Concepts presented will integrate the use of modern molecular biology techniques with contemporary approaches to current problems in biology. Three hours of laboratory.
BIOL 4837.name: Cell Biology: Protein Biology Laboratory

BIOL 4834.description: Examination of advanced human physiology through a detailed study of selected body systems. Systems examined may include the cardio-vascular, respiratory, and renal systems, exchange dynamics among body fluid compartments, and acid-base balance. Three hours lecture.
BIOL 4834.name: Advanced Physiology: Integrative Mechanisms

BIOL 4835.description: Examination of advanced human physiology through a detailed study of selected body systems. Systems examined may include musculoskeletal, gastrointestinal, metabolic and thermoregulatory. Three hours lecture.
BIOL 4835.name: Advanced Physiology: Regulatory Mechanisms

BIOL 6981.description: A course dealing with the principles of pedagogy for BIOL 1551 Anatomy and Physiology I. This course addresses classroom and laboratory topics in human anatomy and physiology with an emphasis on the relationships between instruction and learning outcomes. Required of graduate teaching assistants providing instructional support for BIOL 1551. Students will be assigned a grade of S/U. May be repeated.
BIOL 6981.name: Teaching Practicum: 1551 Anatomy and Physiology

BIOL 4830.description: An examination of the structure, function, integration, and cellular control of the brain and spinal cord. Three hours lecture, two hours lab.
BIOL 4830.name: Functional Neuroanatomy

BIOL 6988.description: May be repeated up to two semester hours.
BIOL 6988.name: Seminar in Biological Sciences

BIOL 6989.description: Independent study for graduate students wishing to learn specific biological research techniques. Applicable only to biology graduate students following the nonthesis or biology education options. May be repeated for up to a total of three semester hours.
BIOL 6989.prereq: Permission of instructor or department chair.
BIOL 6989.name: Graduate Research Experience

BIOL 4839.description: Advanced study of topics in physiology not covered in depth in other physiology courses. May be repeated twice up to 2 s.h.
BIOL 4839.name: Selected Topics in Physiology

BIOL 6935.description: Examination of advanced human physiology through a detailed study of selected body systems. Systems examined may include the musculoskeletal, gastrointestinal, metabolic and thermoregulatory. Three hours lecture.
BIOL 6935.name: Advanced Physiology: Regulatory Mechanisms

BIOL 6909.description: This course covers microbial communities and their interactions associated with the human host. Scientific literature on the identity and roles of microbes associated with the human gut, oral cavity, skin, genital-urinary tract and respiratory system will be reviewed, presented, and discussed.
BIOL 6909.prereq: One of the following courses: undergraduate microbiology, physiology, biochemistry, immunology, or molecular biology.
BIOL 6909.name: The Human Microbiome

BIOL 6934.description: Examination of advanced human physiology through a detailed study of selected body systems.  Systems examined may include the cardiovascular, respiratory, and renal systems, exchange dynamics among body fluid compartments, and acid-base balance.  Three hours lecture.
BIOL 6934.name: Advanced Physiology: Integrative Mechanisms

BIOL 6906.description: Students will learn about destination ecosystems, including associated organisms, interactions, physical, chemical, climatic conditions, culture, and human impacts. Students must be in good health, hike, swim, and handle primitive conditions. Course may be taken more than once with different destination ecosystems. This course involves travel expenses in addition to lab fees.
BIOL 6906.name: Ecosystems Field Ecology

BIOL 6900.description: An examination of how computer and informatics technology is applied to biological data analysis, particularly in the area of genomics data mining, and its use in genomics, molecular, and systems biology research.  Three hours of lecture per week.
BIOL 6900.name: Advanced Bioinformatics

BIOL 6901.description: Project-based learning course with a focus on using a Linux environment and a script language such as PERL for processing large genomic datasets. Relational databases such as MySQL and BioPERL will also be covered for genomic data analysis and display. Two hours of combined lecture and lab per week.
BIOL 6901.name: Computational Bioinformatics

BIOL 2601L.description: General Biology: Molecules and Cells Laboratory.
BIOL 2601L.name: General Biology: Molecules and Cells Laboratory

BIOL 2601H.description: The chemical and physical foundations of life, structure and function of cells and organelles, metabolism, basic molecular biology and inheritance, and principles of evolution. Three hours of lecture, three hours of lab per week.
BIOL 2601H.prereq: CHEM 1515 or concurrent enrollment in CHEM 1515.Gen Ed: Science Substitute.
BIOL 2601H.name: Honors General Biology Molecules and Cells

BIOL 3716.description: Isolation and characterization of DNA and RNA from microbes with an emphasis on cloning, sequencing, structural characterization, expression, and phylogenetic analysis. Two hours lecture, six hours laboratory.
BIOL 3716.prereq: BIOL 3702 and permission of the instructor.
BIOL 3716.name: Molecular Microbiology 1: Nucleic Acids

BIOL 3717.description: Protein Biology. Develops the analytical skills necessary to conduct molecular biology research in the area of protein analysis and proteomics. Two hours lecture and four hours laboratory per week.
BIOL 3717.name: Molecular Microbiology 2

BIOL 4809.description: Covers microbial communities and their interactions associated with the human host. Scientific literature on the identity and roles of microbes associated with the human gut, oral cavity, skin, genital-urinary tract and respiratory system will be reviewed, presented, and discussed.
BIOL 4809.name: The Human Microbiome

BIOL 3711.description: Theoretical and conceptual background necessary for understanding cellular structure-function relationships. Basic architecture of the cell, various organelles. The basic behavior of cells analyzed illustrating the integrative interaction of organelle systems.
BIOL 3711.name: Cell Biology: Fine Structure

BIOL 4801.description: The occurrence, detection, and control of microbes, including bacteria and viruses, in food, water, and the environment. Two hours lecture, four hours lab.
BIOL 4801.name: Environmental Microbiology

BIOL 4800.description: Fundamentals of the theories and applications of bioinformatics. Topics include the tools and databases used to analyze DNA and protein sequences and the evolutionary relationships between sequences from different organisms. Three hours of lecture, two hours of lab per week.
BIOL 4800.name: Bioinformatics

BIOL 4806.description: Students will learn about destination ecosystems, including associated organisms, interactions, physical, chemical, and climatic conditions, culture, and human impacts. Can be taken more than once for different destinations. Students must be in good health, hike, swim, and handle primitive conditions. This course involves travel expenses in addition to lab fees.
BIOL 4806.name: Ecosystem Field Ecology

BIOL 4805.description: Ecology, evolution, and taxonomy of fishes, especially those of Midwestern United States. Two hours lecture, two hours lab.
BIOL 4805.name: Ichthyology

BIOL 1505H.description: Biology applied to critical issues of today's society. Focus on the scientific method as relevant to modern biology issues. Not applicable to the Biology major.Gen Ed: Natural Science.
BIOL 1505H.name: Honors Biology and Modern World

BIOL 1505L.description: Student investigations in biological phenomena using a variety of laboratory approaches focused on a single theme or concept using the scientific method. Satisfies the Natural Science Laboratory requirement. Not applicable to the Biology major.
BIOL 1505L.name: Biology and the Modern World Laboratory

BIOL 4834L.description: Experimental approach to the examination of advanced human physiology through a detailed study of selected body systems. Systems examined may include the cardiovascular, renal and respiratory systems, exchange dynamics among body fluid compartments, and acid-base balance. Three hours lab.Prereq. or concurrent BIOL 4834.
BIOL 4834L.name: Advanced Physiology: Integrative Mechanisms Laboratory

BIOL 6975.description: An examination of how drugs interact with the nervous system, including the locus of action for neuroactive substances and the mechanisms by which these substances cause change in physiology and behavior.
BIOL 6975.prereq: Graduate standing or permission of instructor.
BIOL 6975.name: Neuropharmacology

BIOL 6940.description: This course will present advanced topics in biomolecule synthesis, molecular biology, bacterial genetics, gene expression, energy production photosynthesis, bacteriophages, and microbial stress response. An integrative laboratory project emphasizing some of these topics will be included. Three hours lecture and three hours laboratory.
BIOL 6940.name: Microbial Physiology

BIOL 3780.description: Examination of ecological principles affecting species distributions, interactions and biodiversity; dynamics of populations, communities and ecosystems; life history evolution; origin, maintenance and loss of genetic variation; mechanisms of speciation and extinction; experimental design and analysis. Three hours lecture, four hours lab.
BIOL 3780.name: General Ecology

BIOL 6979.description: A course dealing with the principles of pedagogy for BIOL 1545 Allied Health Anatomy and Physiology. This course addresses classroom and laboratory topics in human anatomy and physiology, with an emphasis on the relationships between instruction and learning outcomes. Required of graduate teaching assistants providing instructional support for BIOL 1545. Students will be assigned a grade of S/U. May be repeated.
BIOL 6979.name: Teaching Practicum: 1545 Anatomy and Physiology

BIOL 6978.description: A course dealing with principles of pedagogy for both classroom and laboratory settings. This is a broad-based course, which will address basic principles and concepts of modern biology. Emphasis is on relationships between instruction and learning outcomes. Required of all graduate teaching assistants in the Biological Sciences. Students will be assigned a grade of S/U. May be repeated.
BIOL 6978.name: Teaching Practicum 1: Principles of Biology

BIOL 6990.description: Research selected and supervised by departmental advisor and approved by graduate faculty of Biology Department and graduate dean. May be repeated for a maximum of six semester hours.
BIOL 6990.name: Master's Thesis Research

BIOL 5840.description: Molecular mechanisms for virulence of pathogenic organisms.
BIOL 5840.name: Advanced Microbiology

BIOL 5844.description: Current concepts of reproductive processes and their physiological control in mammalian systems.
BIOL 5844.name: Physiology of Reproduction

BIOL 6974.description: Current concepts of neuroendocrine processes will be discussed.
BIOL 6974.prereq: BIOL 5833 or equivalent, or permission of instructor.
BIOL 6974.name: Neuroendocrinology

BIOL 6976.description: Detailed study of ionic currents, regulation of neuronal firing patterns, synaptic transmission, and synaptic plasticity.
BIOL 6976.name: Cellular Neurophysiology

GRK 2603.description: Reading of selections from an Ancient Greek author or genre with emphasis on translation. Review of Ancient Greek grammar and introduction of some advanced grammatical constructions not covered in Ancient Greek 1550 or 2600. May be repeated once if topic is different.
GRK 2603.prereq: Permission of Chair and either placement test or GRK 2600.
GRK 2603.name: Directed Reading in Ancient Greek 1

GRK 2600.description: Continuation of GRK 1550 with emphasis on more complex aspects of Ancient Greek grammar. Translation of more advanced Ancient Greek texts, including some authentic passages.
GRK 2600.name: Intermediate Ancient Greek

GRK 3753.description: Reading of selections from an Ancient Greek author or genre with emphasis on translation and interpretation of text; review of Ancient Greek grammar, introduction of relevant modern scholarship, and writing of evaluative essays. May be repeated once if topic is different.
GRK 3753.name: Directed Reading in Ancient Greek 2

GRK 4883.description: Reading of selections from an Ancient Greek author or genre with emphasis on translation and interpretation of text. Review of Ancient Greek grammar. Writing of a research paper. May be repeated once if topic is different.
GRK 4883.name: Directed Reading in Ancient Greek 3

GRK 1550.description: Introduction to Ancient Greek with emphasis on those aspects of grammar most essential for developing the ability to read Greek. Translation of simple Ancient Greek texts into English. Grading is ABC/NC.
GRK 1550.name: Elementary Ancient Greek

SED 3706.description: Lesson/unit planning using instructional strategies that motivate diverse students. Integrates content knowledge, pedagogy, technology, and cross-disciplinary curriculum exploration. Critical reflection and analysis of teaching experiences through peer teaching and classroom teaching in local secondary schools.
SED 3706.prereq: BCOE upper-division status and approval of chairperson.Coreq.: TERG 3711, FOUN 3710 and one of SED 4800B, SED 4800C, SED 4800E, SED 4800, SED 4800M, SED 4800S or HMEC 4800 or FNLG 4801 or PHLT 3703, PHLT 3704 and PHLT 3705.
SED 3706.name: Principles of Teaching Adolescents

SED 6931.description: Historical development of the American secondary school curriculum, present nature, and recent developments. Study of reports, experiments, and typical programs. The roles of supervisors, administrators, teachers, pupils, and public in the development of curriculum.
SED 6931.prereq: Admission to the School of Graduate Studies and Research.
SED 6931.name: The Secondary School Curriculum

SED 4837.name: Super Stud Tch Comp Sci K 12

SED 4838.name: Super Stud Tch Drama Thtr K 12

SED 4850.description: Full-time 16 week student teaching in grades 4-adult supervised by University faculty and experienced career/technical practitioners licensed in the teaching subject of the candidate. Grading is CR/NC.
SED 4850.prereq: BCOE upper-division status, passing scores on PRAXIS II content and PLT test, criminal background check, and completion of adolescent/young adult or career/technical program excluding student teaching and student teaching seminar.Coreq.: SED 4842A.
SED 4850.name: Supervised Student Teaching: Career/Technical

SED 4800S.description: Theory and practice in learning how to plan, execute, and evaluate social studies lessons that are empowering, interesting, and reflective. Topics include: creating thematic unit plans; interpreting academic standards; writing instructional objectives; creating authentic learning activities; authentic assessment; classroom management and democratic discipline.
SED 4800S.prereq: BCOE upper-division status and approval of chairperson.Coreq.: SED 3706, TERG 3711 and FOUN 3710.
SED 4800S.name: Special Methods: Social Studies

SED 4800E.description: Exploring and demonstrating reflective teaching methods for adolescent learning of English: planning instruction, execution of teaching/learning activities, representations of English concepts, authentic assessment, English communication, purposeful use of instructional technology, classroom management for effective teaching.
SED 4800E.prereq: BCOE upper-division status and approval of chairperson.Coreq.: SED 3706 and FOUN 3710.
SED 4800E.name: Special Methods: English

SED 4800B.description: Techniques used in teaching integrated business subjects. Observation of teaching in a vocational setting, presentation of a lesson in a secondary or vocational school, unit development, reflective writing. Organization, administration, implementation, and evaluation of vocational business education programs at the secondary and adult education levels.
SED 4800B.prereq: BCOE upper-division status and approval of chairperson.Coreq.: SED 3706, TERG 3711 and FOUN 3710.
SED 4800B.name: Special Methods: Integrated Business

SED 4800M.description: Exploring and demonstrating reflective teaching methods for adolescent learning of mathematics: planning instruction, execution of teaching/learning activities, multiple representations of mathematical concepts, problem-solving strategies, authentic assessment, manipulative materials, mathematical communication, purposeful use of instructional technology, classroom management for effective teaching.
SED 4800M.prereq: BCOE upper-division status and approval of chairperson.Coreq.: SED 3706, TERG 3711 and FOUN 3710.
SED 4800M.name: Special Methods: Mathematics

SED 7025.description: Study of selected topics chosen by the secondary education staff. May be repeated by non-degree students. See TCED 7032.
SED 7025.name: Seminar in Secondary Education

SED 5993L.name: Sem Comp of Texts Gr 4 to 12

SED 4800C.description: Using NSTA/NCATE and Ohio content standards, candidates establish and maintain learning environments that provide diverse students with a holistic, interdisciplinary understanding of science. Background for teaching science, instructional strategies, classroom management, planning instruction, assessment, professional development, integration of content with inquiry emphasized. Field experience combining pedagogy/methodology in a middle grades or adolescent classroom required.
SED 4800C.prereq: BCOE upper-division status, 24 s.h. science, and approval of chairperson.
SED 4800C.name: Special Methods: Science

SED 6958.description: Strategies of teaching and supervision, including the use of media, the evaluation of instruction and pupil performance, and related personnel issues will be covered. The course is designed for personnel in nonschool settings who have teaching or supervisory responsibility in in-service programs.
SED 6958.name: Instructional Supervision for Nonschool Personnel

SED 6965.description: Full-time 16-week student teaching in grades 7-12 supervised by University faculty and experienced A/YA practitioners licensed in the teaching subject of the candidate. To be taken concurrently with SED 6965A. Grading is S/U.
SED 6965.prereq: Completion of all requirements for initial Adolescent/Young Adult licensure and permission of advisor.
SED 6965.name: Supervised Student Teaching: High School

SED 4827.description: Grading is CR/NC. See requirements for student teaching under COE.
SED 4827.prereq: BCOE upper-division status, passing scores on PRAXIS II content and PLT tests, criminal background check, and completion of foreign language program excluding student teaching and student teaching seminar.Coreq.: SED 4842A.Gen Ed: Capstone.
SED 4827.name: Supervised Student Teaching: Language (K-12)

SED 4842.description: Full-time 16-week student teaching in grades 7-12 supervised by University faculty and experienced AYA practitioners licensed in the teaching subject of the candidate. To be taken concurrently with SED 4842A. Grading is CR/NC.
SED 4842.prereq: BCOE upper-division status, passing scores on PRAXIS II content and PLT tests, criminal background check, and completion of adolescent/young adult or career/technical program excluding student teaching and student teaching seminar.Coreq.: SED 4842A.Gen Ed: Capstone.
SED 4842.name: Supervised Student Teaching: High School

SED 4843.description: Grading is CR/NC. See requirements for student teaching under COE.
SED 4843.prereq: BCOE upper-division status, passing scores on PRAXIS II content and PLT tests, criminal background check, and completion of visual art program excluding student teaching and student teaching seminar.Coreq.: SED 4842A.Gen Ed: Capstone.
SED 4843.name: Supervised Student Teaching: Visual Art (K-12)

SED 4844.description: Grading is CR/NC. See requirements for student teaching under COE.
SED 4844.prereq: BCOE upper-division status, passing scores on PRAXIS II content and PLT tests, criminal background check, and completion of music program excluding student teaching and student teaching seminar.Coreq.: SED 4842A.Gen Ed: Capstone.
SED 4844.name: Supervised Student Teaching: Music (K-12)

SED 4845.description: Grading is CR/NC. See requirements for student teaching under COE.
SED 4845.prereq: BCOE upper-division status, passing scores on PRAXIS II content and PLT tests, criminal background check, and completion of health program excluding student teaching and student teaching seminar.Coreq.: SED 4842A.Gen Ed: Capstone.
SED 4845.name: Supervised Student Teaching: Health (K-12)

SED 4846.description: Grading is CR/NC. See requirements for student teaching under COE.
SED 4846.prereq: BCOE upper-division status, passing scores on PRAXIS II content and PLT tests, criminal background check, and completion of physical education program excluding student teaching and student teaching seminar.Coreq.: SED 4842A.
SED 4846.name: Supervised Student Teaching: Physical Education (K-12)

SED 6990.description: Individual investigation of advanced topics under guidance of selected staff.
SED 6990.name: Independent Study

SED 7042.description: A restricted professional development course for classroom teacher educators invited to supervise the instructional program of student teachers and field experience students. The course concentrates on developing analytical observation, conferencing, evaluation, and supervision skills based on scientific knowledge and theoretical constructs.
SED 7042.prereq: Invitation from YSU and endorsement from home school district to serve as a classroom teacher educator.Cross-listed: EMCE 7042.
SED 7042.name: Professional Development for Classroom Teacher Educators

SED 4842A.description: Seminar topics are based on pedagogy, knowledge and application of professional practice and standards, critical theory, and knowledge of the adolescent and young adult learner. Completion of the Teacher Work Sample is required.Coreq.: One of SED 4827, SED 4842, SED 4843, SED 4844, SED 4845, or SED 4846.
SED 4842A.name: Student Teaching Seminar for Secondary Education

SED 6999.prereq: Approval of department graduate faculty and chair.
SED 6999.name: Thesis

ASL 1551.description: Continuation of ASL 1550 with further development of vocabulary, syntax and grammatical non-manual signals and additional study of the history and culture of the Deaf Community.
ASL 1551.name: Elementary American Sign Language 2

ASL 1550.description: Introduction to the fundamentals of American Sign Language (ASL), including vocabulary, syntax, and grammatical non-manual signals. Introduction to the history and culture of the Deaf Community. Grading is ABC/NC.
ASL 1550.name: Elementary American Sign Language 1

ASL 1552.description: Continuation of ASL 1551 with further development of vocabulary, syntax and grammatical non-manual signals and additional study of the history and culture of the Deaf Community.
ASL 1552.name: Intermediate American Sign Language 1

ASL 2600.description: Continuation of ASL 1552 with further development of vocabulary, syntax and grammatical non-manual signals and additional study of the history and culture of the Deaf Community.
ASL 2600.name: Intermediate American Sign Language 2

ADV 4855.description: Capstone course in the integrated marketing communications curriculum. By employing the fundamental theories and practices garnered from previous integrated marketing communications courses for a specific IMC problem, the focus is the development of an integrated marketing communications campaign.
ADV 4855.prereq: ADV 3711, ADV 3712, ADV 3717 and GPA of 2.5.
ADV 4855.name: IMC Campaigns

ADV 4850.description: Through employment with participating business organizations the student will receive professional advertising experience. Students work at a business organization under the direct guidance of a faculty advisor. Required paper on the relationship between advertising theory and practice.
ADV 4850.name: Advertising Internship

ADV 3717.description: Planning, executing, and controlling of media buys. Techniques of allocation of budget among print and electronic media explored on national, regional, and local levels familiarizing the student with syndicated media resources.
ADV 3717.name: Media Planning and Buying

ADV 3710.description: Study of the management function which investigates and evaluates public attitudes, policies, means, and techniques used in the field to earn public understanding and acceptance.
ADV 3710.name: Basic Public Relations

ADV 3711.description: Examines the integration of promotional activities within a marketing context. Presents the marketing communication role of the four elements in the promotional mix then takes a holistic perspective that focuses on the interrelationships among advertising, public relations, sales promotion, and personal selling.
ADV 3711.name: Marketing Communications

ADV 3712.description: The creative process is related to the different message and graphic needs required in advertising, public relations, and sales promotion. Examines the synergistic possibilities of the separate efforts focused on the same creative strategy within an integrated marketing communications (IMC) campaign.
ADV 3712.name: Creative Strategies in IMC

ADV 4899.description: This course will allow students to develop a special topic of interest under the direct supervision of a marketing faculty member. The objective of this course is to provide the student with a strong understanding of a specific area of advertising.
ADV 4899.name: Independent Study

ADV 3711H.description: Examines the integration of promotional activities within a marketing context. Presents the marketing communication role of the four elements in the promotional mix then takes a holistic perspective that focuses on the interrelationships among advertising, public relations, sales promotion, and personal selling.
ADV 3711H.name: Honors Marketing Communications

CCET 2620.description: Transportation planning and highway system design. Familiarization with AASHTO design manuals; geometric design and signalization of highway segments; capacity analysis and route selection. Cost-benefit analysis for transportation projects.
CCET 2620.name: Transportation Technology

CCET 3735.description: Study of principles of heavy highway construction as it relates to the current highway system. The reading and comprehension of highway construction plans and specifications.
CCET 3735.name: Heavy Highway Technology

CCET 2614L.description: Use and care of testing equipment, data retrieval, data reduction and report preparation. Physical testing of metals, concrete, aggregates, asphalts, soils and woods. Three hours per week.Prereq or concurrent: CCET 2604.
CCET 2614L.name: Materials Laboratory 1

CCET 2604.description: Introduction to the physical and chemical properties of materials and their behavior under various loads and environments. Concepts of stress and strain developed and evaluated for the application of axial, shear, torsional, and bending loads.
CCET 2604.prereq: ENTC 1505 and MATH 1513 grade of "C" or better.Prereq. or concurrent: MET 1515.
CCET 2604.name: Properties and Strength of Materials

CCET 4824.description: Application of environmental principles to land planning and development. Wastewater treatment processes and system design. Application of water and wastewater management to specific sites. Permitting and endangerment assessment. Three hours lecture, one hour computational lab per week.
CCET 4824.prereq: "C" or better in CCET 3724 and junior standing.
CCET 4824.name: Environmental Technology

CCET 3714L.description: Practice in soil identification and determination of soil properties. Use and care of basic soil testing equipment and standard test procedures. Three laboratory hours per week.Concurrent with: CCET 3714.
CCET 3714L.name: Soil Mechanics Laboratory

CCET 4807.description: Application of planning, scheduling, and control system techniques for an integrated project including theory, options, legal implications, and practices. Students plan and schedule projects using CPM computer software and set up control systems for the project. Three hours lecture, one hour laboratory per week.
CCET 4807.name: Project Planning & Scheduling

CCET 4809.description: Continuation of CCET 3709. Analysis techniques for common structures. Introduction to classical approaches to statically indeterminate structures and calculation of deflections. Use of standard computer programs such as StruCalc, SAP and SABLE. Three hours lecture, one hour computational lab per week.
CCET 4809.prereq: "C" or better in both CCET 3709 and MATH 1570.
CCET 4809.name: Structural Analysis 2

CCET 3708.description: Introduction and applications of Autodesk Revit 3D CAD program. Use of Revit software to assemble a complete building information model of a building and use the model to coordinate systems between disciplines, to create material take-offs, construction documents, and presentation drawings. Two hours lecture, three hours lab per week.
CCET 3708.name: Building Information Modeling

CCET 3709.description: Fundamental determination of member forces in trusses, beams, arches, frames and cables. Calculation of member stresses and defections. Two hours lecture, three hours computational lab per week.
CCET 3709.prereq: ENTC 1505, MATH 1513, CCET 2604, all with a grade of "C" or better.
CCET 3709.name: Structural Analysis 1

CCET 3705.description: Development of computer techniques used in solutions to problems in all fields of engineering technology. Students write computer programs to solve problems with which they are familiar. Use of database management, spreadsheets. May be taken by non-CCET majors. Two hours lecture, three hours lab per week.
CCET 3705.prereq: MATH 1570 grade of "C" or better and junior standing or consent of instructor.
CCET 3705.name: Computing for Technologists

CCET 3706.description: Structural design using AISC, ACI and similar codes. Selection of members and connections in accordance with manuals and code specifications. Design and AutoCAD projects required. Three hours lecture and three hours computational lab per week.
CCET 3706.name: Structural Design

CCET 4884.description: Interdisciplinary capstone course. An overview of the requirements and design procedures for civil and structural systems. Includes the analysis and design for site development, utilities, foundation, wall systems, framing systems, floor system and the preparation of the plans, specifications and estimate package. Includes a major interdisciplinary group project. Two hours lecture, three hours design studio.
CCET 4884.prereq: Senior standing in CCET or EET permission of instructor.Concurrent: EET 4880.
CCET 4884.name: Civil/Structural Facilities Design

CCET 3740.description: Design and construction office planning and scheduling techniques. Introduction to computer methods for program planning and updating. Financial, labor, and material resource allocation and tracking. Construction reports, contracts, specifications and general conditions. Relationships among owner, architect/engineer, and constructor.
CCET 3740.name: Construction Management

CCET 3724.description: Study of hydraulics and hydrologic principles and their applications to drainage requirements, storm-water management, detention/retention basin design, erosion and sedimentation control plans and land-use planning. Use of computer software for analysis and design. Two hours lecture, three hours of computational lab per week.
CCET 3724.prereq: DDT 1503, DDT 1504, ENTC 1505, MATH 1513, CCET 2604, MET 1515 all with a grade of "C" or better.
CCET 3724.name: Hydraulics and Land Development

CCET 2617.description: Basic properties of construction materials. Processing and placement methods. Purchase, use and replacement of construction equipment. Application of engineering economics to construction. Use of building codes.
CCET 2617.prereq: CCET 2604, MET 1515 both with a grade of "C" or better.
CCET 2617.name: Construction Methods and Materials

CCET 4810.description: Theory and applications of advanced land surveying techniques for: route surveying and geometric design; topographic site surveys and mapping; civil engineering, utilities, and construction surveys; global positioning systems; and quantities and final surveys. Two hours lecture and three hours field surveying laboratory.
CCET 4810.name: Construction Surveying

CCET 4813.description: Loading and behavior of steel structures and design of standard rolled shapes in accordance with current LRFD and ASD specifications. Design of welded and bolted connections and an introduction to design of cold-formed steel members. Three hours lecture, one hour design lab per week.
CCET 4813.prereq: "C" or better in both CCET 3706 and CCET 3709.
CCET 4813.name: Steel Design

CCET 4812.description: Behavior and design of concrete elements subject to flexure, shear, axial and combined effects. Emphasis on reinforced concrete design in accordance with the ACI Code including beams, T-beams, slabs, walls, and columns. An introduction to prestressed and precast concrete design. Three hours lecture, one hour design lab per week.
CCET 4812.prereq: "C" or better in both CCET 3706 and CCET 3709.
CCET 4812.name: Concrete Design

CCET 4815.description: Design of beams, columns, shear walls and bearing walls using clay and concrete masonry units. Application of allowable stress design (ASD) and strength design (SD) in accordance with the MSJC Building Code Requirements for Masonry Structures. Additional topics include prestressed and autoclaved aerated concrete (AAC) masonry. Three hours lecture, one hour lab per week.
CCET 4815.prereq: CCET 2617, "C" or better in both CCET 3706 and CCET 3709.
CCET 4815.name: Masonry Design

CCET 4814.description: Application of soil mechanics to the design of foundations. Topics include spread footings, drilled piers, piles, retaining walls, sheet piles walls and underground structures. Three hours lecture per week.
CCET 4814.name: Foundation Design

CCET 4816.description: Design of beams, poles, piles, diaphragms, shear walls and fasteners using timber elements. Application of the National Design Specification for Wood Construction that incorporates a dual format using both allowable stress design (ASD) and load and resistance factor design (LRFD). Additional topics include glued-laminated members and design of mechanical connectors. Design, analysis, construction, and testing of scale models is required. Three hours lecture, one hour lab per week.
CCET 4816.prereq: CCET 2617, "C" or better in both CCET 3706 and CCET 3709.
CCET 4816.name: Timber Design

CCET 3719.description: Mining methods, types of mines, information retrieval, mine stabilization, and the effects of abandoned mines on environmental and human activities, especially deep coal mines in the Mahoning Valley and adjacent areas. Two hours lecture and three hours of lab per week. Prereq. GEOL 1505 or equivalent or permission of instructor.
CCET 3719.name: Environmental Impact of Abandoned Mines

CCET 4890.description: New developments in CCET. Subject matter, special prerequisites, and credit hours to be announced in advance of each offering. May be repeated with different subject matter to a maximum of 8 s.h.
CCET 4890.prereq: Senior standing in CCET or consent of the instructor.
CCET 4890.name: Special Topics in Civil and Construction Engineering Technology

CCET 3711.description: Fundamentals of writing and interpreting specifications for materials and construction methods. Estimating materials and labor costs for construction projects. Use of computer estimating packages. Two hours lecture and three hours computational laboratory.
CCET 3711.prereq: ENTC 1505, MATH 1513, CCET 2604, MET 1515 all with grade of "C" or better.
CCET 3711.name: Specifications and Estimating

CCET 3714.description: A study of soil properties, classifications, strength and behavior. Theory of consolidation, shear strength and stability analysis. Two hours lecture per week.
CCET 3714.name: Soil Mechanics

MUAC 3763.description: Study of snare drum, marching percussion, timpani, jazz drum set, keyboard, Latin percussion, and orchestral accessories. Topics include instrument selection and maintenance techniques as well as pedagogical approaches. Designed to prepare students for instrumental music teaching careers.
MUAC 3763.name: Percussion Methods

MUAC 6977.description: Development of advanced music scholarship skills through readings, analysis, and critique of some of the major ideas about music's value and place in society that have been advanced by scholars ranging from the ancient Greeks to contemporary music critics, performers, philosophers, educators, and psychologists. Course takes an interdisciplinary approach to developing the skills to articulate music advocacy arguments. One of three core required courses for all masters students.
MUAC 6977.name: Philosophies of Music

MUAC 2668.description: Jazz techniques with emphasis on analysis of harmonic progressions, form, style, and performance requirements of the jazz idiom. Classes must be taken in sequence.
MUAC 2668.prereq: MUAC 1525 or a grade of "B" or better on the Jazz Placement Test.
MUAC 2668.name: Jazz Improvisation 2

MUAC 2694.description: A study of techniques useful in playing the piano for instrumentalists, with supervised studio and recital experience. May be repeated for credit.
MUAC 2694.name: Accompanying 2

MUAC 2691.description: A study of techniques useful in playing the piano for vocalists, with supervised studio and recital experience. May be repeated for credit.
MUAC 2691.name: Accompanying 1

MUAC 2692.description: A study of techniques useful in playing the piano for vocalists, with supervised studio and recital experience. May be repeated for credit.
MUAC 2692.name: Accompanying 1

MUAC 2693.description: A study of techniques useful in playing the piano for instrumentalists, with supervised studio and recital experience. May be repeated for credit.
MUAC 2693.name: Accompanying 2

MUAC 1556.description: Application of the principles of Lyric diction; utilization of the International Phonetic Alphabet in developing and reading phonetics transcriptions of English, Italian song texts.
MUAC 1556.name: Singer's Diction: English/Italian

MUAC 1557.description: Application of the principles of Lyric diction; utilization of the International Phonetic Alphabet in developing and reading phonetics transcriptions of German song texts.
MUAC 1557.name: Singer's Diction: German

MUAC 3781.description: (For keyboard and non-keyboard majors). Class instruction and keyboard experience in jazz chordal voicing techniques and jazz accompanying techniques. Classes must be taken in sequence. Meets two days per week.
MUAC 3781.prereq: MUAC 1582, MUAC 1525, a grade of "B" or better on the Jazz Placement Test, or permission of instructor.
MUAC 3781.name: Jazz Keyboard 1

MUAC 3782.description: (For keyboard and non-keyboard majors). Class instruction and keyboard experience in jazz chordal voicing techniques and jazz accompanying techniques. Classes must be taken in sequence. Meets two days per week.
MUAC 3782.prereq: MUAC 1582, MUAC 1525, a grade of "B" or better on the Jazz Placement Test, or permission of instructor.
MUAC 3782.name: Jazz Keyboard 2

MUAC 1558.description: Application of the principles of Lyric diction; utilization of the International Phonetic Alphabet in developing and reading phonetics transcriptions of French song texts.
MUAC 1558.name: Singer's Diction: French

MUAC 3733.description: Designed to prepare students for instrumental music teaching relative to woodwind instruments (flute, clarinet, oboe, bassoon, saxophone). Components include concepts of tone production, embouchure, articulation, and technique. Study material stresses common features as well as differences.
MUAC 3733.name: Woodwind Methods

MUAC 3759.description: A study of voice at the beginning level to explore techniques and approaches appropriate to school music instruction. A minimum level of performance is required. May be repeated.
MUAC 3759.name: Voice Class

MUAC 3732.description: Designed to prepare students for instrumental music teaching relative to brass instruments. Emphasis on tone production, the harmonic series, technique development, ranges and transposition, pedagogy, troubleshooting, and arranging techniques for brass instruments. Meets 2 hours per week.
MUAC 3732.name: Brass Methods

MUAC 3755.description: Study of the guitar at the beginning level to explore techniques and approaches appropriate to school music instruction. A minimum level of performance is required.
MUAC 3755.name: Guitar Class

MUAC 3734.description: Designed to prepare students for instrumental music teaching relative to string instruments (violin, viola, cello, string bass). Components include concepts of tone production, bowing, fingering as well as appropriate evaluation of pedagogy. Study material stresses common features as well as differences.
MUAC 3734.name: String Methods

MUAC 3735.description: Designed to prepare students jazz teaching relative to instruments and voice. Components include fundamental techniques and approaches for directing small and large jazz ensembles, teaching of basic improvisation skills, rhythms section/soloist interaction, and stylistic interpretation. Students will demonstrate basic performance proficiencies in jazz on their applied instruments and/or voices. Meets 2 hours per week.
MUAC 3735.name: Jazz Methods

MUAC 1581.description: Elements of keyboard techniques, with emphasis on sight reading, harmonization of popular and/or folk tunes, repertoire, transposition, and analysis. All major and minor scales and arpeggios, hands together. Required of all non-keyboard majors.Coreq.: Major-level applied lessons (1501 or higher).
MUAC 1581.name: Keyboard Musicianship 1

MUAC 1582.description: Continuation of MUAC 1581; with emphasis on sight-reading, harmonization of popular and/or folk tunes with more extended chords and accompaniment patterns, repertoire, transposition, and analysis. All major and minor scales and arpeggios, hands together. Required of all non-keyboard majors.: major-level applied lessons (1502 or higher).
MUAC 1582.prereq: minimum grade of "C" in MUAC 1581 and Coreq.
MUAC 1582.name: Keyboard Musicianship 2

MUAC 2667.description: Jazz techniques with emphasis on analysis of harmonic progressions, form, style, and performance requirements of the jazz idiom. Classes must be taken in sequence.
MUAC 2667.prereq: MUAC 1525 or a grade of "B" or better on the Jazz Placement Test.
MUAC 2667.name: Jazz Improvisation 1

MUAC 2682.description: The last course in the keyboard musicianship sequence which started with MUAC 1581. Proficiency at the piano will be evaluated through performance of stylistically varied repertoire, advanced accompanying and harmonization, sight reading, transposition, and three- and four-part score reading. Technique: all major and minor scales, tonic arpeggios.
MUAC 2682.prereq: minimum grade of "C" in MUAC 2681, placement exam by the Coordinator of Keyboard Musicianship; admission to Dana School of Music and enrollment in major-level lesson.
MUAC 2682.name: Keyboard Musicianship 4

MUAC 2681.description: A continuation and intensification of studies begun in MUAC 1581 and MUAC 1582, with emphasis on accompanying, score reading, harmonization (with secondary dominant chords), repertoire, and stylistic analysis. Technique: all major and minor scales; arpeggios.
MUAC 2681.prereq: minimum grade of "C" in MUAC 1582, placement exam by the Coordinator of Keyboard Musicianship; admission to Dana School of Music and enrollment in major-level lesson.
MUAC 2681.name: Keyboard Musicianship 3

MUAC 1522.description: Continuation of MUAC 1521. Intended for the student with no previous music studies, this second-semester course develops fundamental piano playing, through the study of music fundamentals and repertoire.
MUAC 1522.name: Keyboard Musicianship for Non Music Majors 2

MUAC 1521.description: Intended for the student with no previous music studies, this first-semester course develops fundamental piano playing, through the study of music fundamentals and repertoire.
MUAC 1521.name: Keyboard Musicianship for Non-Music Majors 1

MUAC 4868.description: Advanced jazz techniques with emphasis on analysis of harmonic progressions, form, style, and performance requirements of the jazz idiom. Courses must be taken in sequence.
MUAC 4868.name: Jazz Improvisation 4

MUAC 4867.description: Advanced jazz techniques with emphasis on analysis of harmonic progressions, form, style, and performance requirements of the jazz idiom. Courses must be taken in sequence.
MUAC 4867.name: Jazz Improvisation 3

DNCE 3781.description: Intermediate/advanced course building upon skills acquired in Ballet 1 and 2. Designed to enhance technique and artistry. May be repeated for a maximum of six credit hours.
DNCE 3781.prereq: DNCE 1573 or consent of the instructor.
DNCE 3781.name: Ballet 3

DNCE 4892.description: The theory and practice of sound dance teaching methods. An outside field experience in teaching dance will be required. Senior standing.
DNCE 4892.prereq: Completion of minimum of 2 hours of dance technique in each of the following forms: Modern, Ballet and Jazz (satisfied by the completion of course work in those areas or by permission of the instructor), plus DNCE 1550, DNCE 2606, DNCE 3730 and DNCE 4885.
DNCE 4892.name: Pedagogy of Dance Technique

DNCE 3791A.description: Involvement with the Dance Ensemble rehearsal process and performance. Must be taken seven semesters during the time a student is a dance major.Concurrent with: DNCE 1540 or DNCE 1570 or DNCE 1572 or by audition.
DNCE 3791A.name: Dance Participation

DNCE 3791B.description: Involvement with the Dance Ensemble rehearsal process and performance. Must be taken seven semesters during the time a student is a dance major.Concurrent with: DNCE 1540 or DNCE 1570 or DNCE 1572 or by audition.
DNCE 3791B.name: Dance Participation

DNCE 3791C.description: Involvement with the Dance Ensemble rehearsal process and performance. Must be taken seven semesters during the time a student is a dance major.Concurrent with: DNCE 1540 or DNCE 1570 or DNCE 1572 or by audition.
DNCE 3791C.name: Dance Participation

DNCE 3791D.description: Involvement with the Dance Ensemble rehearsal process and performance. Must be taken seven semesters during the time a student is a dance major.Concurrent with: DNCE 1540 or DNCE 1570 or DNCE 1572 or by audition.
DNCE 3791D.name: Dance Participation

DNCE 3791E.description: Involvement with the Dance Ensemble rehearsal process and performance. Must be taken seven semesters during the time a student is a dance major.Concurrent with: DNCE 1540 or DNCE 1570 or DNCE 1572 or by audition.
DNCE 3791E.name: Dance Participation

DNCE 3791F.description: Involvement with the Dance Ensemble rehearsal process and performance. Must be taken seven semesters during the time a student is a dance major.Concurrent with: DNCE 1540 or DNCE 1570 or DNCE 1572 or by audition.
DNCE 3791F.name: Dance Participation

DNCE 3791G.description: Involvement with the Dance Ensemble rehearsal process and performance. Must be taken seven semesters during the time a student is a dance major.Concurrent with: DNCE 1540 or DNCE 1570 or DNCE 1572 or by audition.
DNCE 3791G.name: Dance Participation

DNCE 1541.description: Intermediate modern dance techniques, composition, and improvisation. May be repeated up to six credit hours.
DNCE 1541.name: Modern Dance 2

DNCE 1540.description: Elementary techniques of body movement. Rhythmic fundamentals and Improvisation.
DNCE 1540.name: Modern Dance 1

DNCE 1565.description: Selected topics in the practice, theory or scholarship of dance. May be repeated if the topic is different.
DNCE 1565.name: Topics in Dance

DNCE 1542.description: Basic principles related to the form and structure of dance composition.
DNCE 1542.name: Dance Composition

DNCE 2698.description: The role of dance in culture and history, tracing the evolution of various folk, social, and concert forms. Structural and stylistic elements important for the appreciation of movement and dance.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities.
DNCE 2698.name: Survey of Dance

DNCE 4898.description: Capstone experience expected of all students in the major. Significant demonstration of practical or scholarly ability in Dance choreography and/or pedagogy.
DNCE 4898.name: Senior Project

DNCE 1573.description: Expands on vocabulary and established patterns of balletic movement. This course may be repeated up to six credit hours.
DNCE 1573.name: Ballet 2

DNCE 4871.description: Refinement of skills and artistic qualities essential for the performance of jazz dance repertory at a pre-professional level. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 credit hours.
DNCE 4871.prereq: DNCE 3770 or permission of the instructor.
DNCE 4871.name: Jazz Dance 4

DNCE 3791.description: Involvement with the Dance Ensemble rehearsal process and performance. Must be taken seven semesters during the time a student is a dance major.Concurrent with: DNCE 1540 or DNCE 1570 or DNCE 1572 or by audition.
DNCE 3791.name: Dance Participation

DNCE 2606.description: Skills and methods development, and the learning process as it applies to teaching children's dance and creative movement.
DNCE 2606.prereq: Sophomore standing or permission of the instructor.
DNCE 2606.name: Creative Dance for Children

DNCE 4881.description: Advanced-level movement skills and terminology. Skills increase in speed, complexity, and duration. This course may be repeated for a maximum of 6 credit hours.
DNCE 4881.name: Ballet 4

DNCE 4885.description: Anatomy and kinesiology for the dancer, common injuries in dance and their care and prevention, study of physiological support systems, as well as applied knowledge of one's body potential and limitations in dance.
DNCE 4885.prereq: junior/senior standing or consent of instructor.
DNCE 4885.name: Dance Kinesiology

DNCE 1570.description: Principles and practices of the basic techniques of tap dance, soft shoe, jazz, and the fundamental forms of dance movement found in musical theater.
DNCE 1570.name: Tap and Jazz 1

DNCE 1571.description: Further refinement and development of jazz and tap skills. This course may be repeated up to six credit hours.
DNCE 1571.name: Tap and Jazz 2

DNCE 1572.description: Theory and practice of classical ballet with emphasis on body placement and muscular awareness. Fundamentals of vocabulary, structure, and placement.
DNCE 1572.name: Ballet 1

DNCE 2662.description: Practical application of theater or dance skills through participation in special programming of the department, or specified studio/laboratory activities. Expected participation should amount to a minimum of thirty hours per semester. May be repeated for a maximum of 5 s.h.
DNCE 2662.name: Practicum in Theater and Dance

DNCE 3730.description: Designed to provide the dance student with basic musical knowledge and skills necessary for quality dance performance, production, and accompaniment. Â.
DNCE 3730.prereq: Minimum of 6 hours coursework in DNCE.
DNCE 3730.name: Music for Dance

DNCE 3770.description: Intermediate/advanced level class building upon a strong foundation in jazz dance. Refinement of technical and artistic proficiency. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 credit hours.
DNCE 3770.prereq: DNCE 1571 or permission of the instructor.
DNCE 3770.name: Jazz Dance 3

DNCE 1550.description: Conditioning, relaxation, and injury prevention techniques related to the needs of dancers and actors.
DNCE 1550.prereq: 2 hours credit in any jazz, ballet, or modern dance technique classes or permission of instructor.
DNCE 1550.name: Wellness for Actors and Dancers

DNCE 3751.description: Intermediate/advanced techniques in modern dance designed to develop professional performance quality. May be repeated up to six credit hours.
DNCE 3751.prereq: DNCE 1541 or consent of the instructor.
DNCE 3751.name: Modern Dance 3

DNCE 2680.description: Intermediate/advanced tap skills, with emphasis on speed, clarity of sound, and improvisation.
DNCE 2680.prereq: DNCE 1571 or permission of the instructor.
DNCE 2680.name: Tap Dance 3

DNCE 3767.description: The study of dance, movement, and staging for the musical theater, culminating in student choreographed/staged works from a variety of musical theater productions.
DNCE 3767.name: Choreography for Musical Theater

THTR 2668.description: The fundamental theories and techniques of acting. Major emphasis on theater acting, but consideration is given to radio and television acting.
THTR 2668.name: Acting 1: Fundamentals

THTR 2664.description: Applied skills course dealing with styles and techniques of performing for the musical theater. Covers auditioning, rehearsal process, and expressive delivery and gesture through song. Culminates in public recital.Prereq. or concurrent THTR 2668 and VOIC 1501T or other evidence of vocal training; and sophomore standing.
THTR 2664.name: Musical Theater Lab

THTR 2667.description: Technical elements of voice for the stage. Physical exercises designed to improve stage speech, vocal projection, articulation and clarity. Application of principles and skills to a variety of texts from a performer's perspective.
THTR 2667.name: Acting 2: Voice for the Actor

THTR 2661.description: Basic principles and techniques of stage management including job functions and responsibilities, production organization, problem solving and specialized paperwork. Stage management of a production and one hour lecture per week. Stage management of a production is a requirement of the class. Grade: Traditional/PR.
THTR 2661.name: Stage Management

THTR 3700C.description: Advanced involvement in the main stage productions of the department. Students will audition for all main stage productions, or accept a significant assignment in stage management, costume, scenery, lighting or other technical element of production. Must be taken each semester during the time that a student is in junior/senior residence as a theater major, for a minimum of 4 or its equivalent.
THTR 3700C.prereq: 3 s.h. of THTR 2600 or permission of the instructor.
THTR 3700C.name: Theater Participation 2

THTR 2662.description: Practical application of theater or dance skills through participation in special programming of the department, or specified studio/laboratory activities. Expected participation should amount to a minimum of thirty hours per semester. May be repeated for a maximum of 5 s.h. CROSS LISTED WITH DNCE 2662.
THTR 2662.prereq: THTR 1561 or THTR 1559 or special permission.
THTR 2662.name: Practicum in Theater and Dance

THTR 2607.description: An overview of the history of puppets in world drama, combined with practical exercises in making inanimate objects come to "life" for the purpose of creating works of theater. Includes puppet construction and performance.
THTR 2607.name: Puppetry

THTR 2600A.description: Expected involvement in the main stage productions of the department. Students will audition for all main stage productions, or accept a significant assignment in stage management, costume, scenery, lighting or other technical element of production. Must be taken once each semester during the time that a student is in residence as a theater major, for a minimum of 3, or its equivalent.
THTR 2600A.prereq: a declared major in theater, and faculty permission.
THTR 2600A.name: Theater Participation

THTR 2600B.description: Expected involvement in the main stage productions of the department. Students will audition for all main stage productions, or accept a significant assignment in stage management, costume, scenery, lighting or other technical element of production. Must be taken once each semester during the time that a student is in residence as a theater major, for a minimum of 3, or its equivalent.
THTR 2600B.prereq: a declared major in theater, and faculty permission.
THTR 2600B.name: Theater Participation

THTR 2600C.description: Expected involvement in the main stage productions of the department. Students will audition for all main stage productions, or accept a significant assignment in stage management, costume, scenery, lighting or other technical element of production. Must be taken once each semester during the time that a student is in residence as a theater major, for a minimum of 3, or its equivalent.
THTR 2600C.prereq: a declared major in theater, and faculty permission.
THTR 2600C.name: Theater Participation

THTR 2600.description: Expected involvement in the main stage productions of the department. Students will audition for all main stage productions, or accept a significant assignment in stage management, costume, scenery, lighting or other technical element of production. Must be taken once each semester during the time that a student is in residence as a theater major, for a minimum of 3, or its equivalent.
THTR 2600.prereq: a declared major in theater, and faculty permission.
THTR 2600.name: Theater Participation

THTR 1512.description: The history and development of the musical theater genre, including an in-depth study of significant works and individual practitioners.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities, Arts and Humanities.
THTR 1512.name: Survey of Musical Theater

THTR 3791.description: Faculty-supervised study and practical demonstration of a theater or dance performance. Credit given for significant acting or dancing roles, assistant directing, or stage management assignments in Department of Theater and Dance programming. For students with appropriate experience. May be taken twice.
