THTR 3791.prereq: THTR 2668 or DNCE 1542 and faculty approval.
THTR 3791.name: Rehearsal and Performance

THTR 5864.description: A study of specific theories, techniques, and various important styles in play directing.
THTR 5864.name: Directing 2

THTR 4899.description: In-depth study of selected aspects in theater scholarship, theory or practice. May be repeated if the topic changes.
THTR 4899.prereq: Junior standing or permission of instructor.
THTR 4899.name: Topics in Theater

THTR 4898.description: Capstone experience expected of all seniors in the degree programs of the department. Significant demonstration of practical or scholarly ability in one of the sub-disciplines comprising the disciplines of theater or dance, and showing evidence of solid writing, speaking, and critical thinking skills. Grading is A,B,C,NC/PR.
THTR 4898.prereq: Senior standing with the expectation of graduating by the end of the following semester.Gen Ed: Capstone, Capstone.
THTR 4898.name: Senior Project

THTR 1559.description: An introduction to the processes of analyzing, directing, staging, and producing plays; demonstration and practice.
THTR 1559.name: Play Production

THTR 4869.description: Basic elements of playmaking, improvisation, story dramatization, pantomime, dialogue, and characterization. Experience with area school children provided when possible. Intended for elementary education majors and drama certification.
THTR 4869.prereq: Junior standing with 9 s.h. of theater courses (including THTR 1559 and THTR 2668) or junior standing in Elementary Education with permission of instructor.
THTR 4869.name: Creative Dramatics

THTR 4868.description: A study of the process of theater production by and for elementary school children, including theory, objectives, and methods.
THTR 4868.prereq: THTR 3762 or senior standing in Elementary Education with permission of instructor.
THTR 4868.name: Children's Theater

THTR 3792.description: Faculty-supervised study resulting in the design and/or execution of scenery, lighting, or costumes for public performance. For students with appropriate experience. May be taken twice.
THTR 3792.prereq: THTR 3763 or THTR 3765 or THTR 3769 and theater faculty committee approval.
THTR 3792.name: Projects in Production

THTR 1590.description: The history of the motion picture from its beginnings to the present, with emphasis on the milestones of film as a performing art. Viewing of significant films from various periods and countries.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities, Arts and Humanities.
THTR 1590.name: History of Motion Pictures

THTR 4860.description: History of the physical theater and representative dramatic texts from 1700 to the modern era.
THTR 4860.prereq: 9 s.h. of THTR coursework, 3 of which must be upper division.
THTR 4860.name: Theater History after 1700

THTR 4863.description: A study of specific theories, techniques, and approaches to creating the various styles of acting. Emphasis on scene study featuring important historical styles of performance.
THTR 4863.name: Acting 3: Styles

THTR 3700D.description: Advanced involvement in the main stage productions of the department. Students will audition for all main stage productions, or accept a significant assignment in stage management, costume, scenery, lighting or other technical element of production. Must be taken each semester during the time that a student is in junior/senior residence as a theater major, for a minimum of 4 or its equivalent.
THTR 3700D.prereq: 3 s.h. of THTR 2600 or permission of the instructor.
THTR 3700D.name: Theater Participation 2

THTR 4866.description: Participation in the summer theater program involving all aspects of theatrical production. Positions of significant responsibility.
THTR 4866.prereq: Junior standing in Theater, or permission of instructor.
THTR 4866.name: Summer Theater Workshop

THTR 2690.description: Analysis of the structure of the motion picture, the development of the script, the function of editing, the approach to acting in film production, and the problems faced by a director in film production. Criteria of artistic film making. Examples from motion pictures are screened and discussed.
THTR 2690.prereq: Sophomore standing.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities, Arts and Humanities.
THTR 2690.name: The Art of Motion Pictures

THTR 3700B.description: Advanced involvement in the main stage productions of the department. Students will audition for all main stage productions, or accept a significant assignment in stage management, costume, scenery, lighting or other technical element of production. Must be taken each semester during the time that a student is in junior/senior residence as a theater major, for a minimum of 4 or its equivalent.
THTR 3700B.prereq: 3 s.h. of THTR 2600 or permission of the instructor.
THTR 3700B.name: Theater Participation 2

THTR 2670.description: The development of skills necessary for the oral interpretation of various types of literature: prose, poetry, and drama. The thorough analysis of each work and communication of the work to an audience.
THTR 2670.name: Oral Interpretation

THTR 4895.description: A practical application of drama/theater in education theories and skills in a field-based lab experience in the schools. Students submit project proposals geared either to the elementary or secondary level. Proposals must be approved by a theater faculty committee. Repeatable for a total of 6 s.h.
THTR 4895.prereq: THTR 1561, THTR 1559 and THTR 3762; or THTR 1559, THTR 3761 and THTR 4868.
THTR 4895.name: Arts in Education Internship: Theater

THTR 4891.description: History of the physical theater and representative dramatic texts from the Classical period through the Renaissance.
THTR 4891.prereq: 9 s.h. of THTR coursework, 3 of which must be upper division.
THTR 4891.name: Theater History Before 1700

THTR 4893.description: Independent work in theater production under faculty/staff guidance. Intended as a continuation of individualized creative work beyond THTR 3791 or THTR 3792. Project dependent upon approval of the evaluating faculty member and the student. May be repeated with different topics for a total of 9 s.h.
THTR 4893.name: Independent Study in Theater

THTR 3701.description: This course covers topics vital to preparation for the business of professional theater. Contracts, taxes, marketing, resumes, e-portfolios, interviewing, job hunting and legal considerations are among several topics to be discussed.
THTR 3701.prereq: THTR 1560, THTR 1561, or THTR 2668 and junior standing as theater major.
THTR 3701.name: Professional Preparation

THTR 3700A.description: Advanced involvement in the main stage productions of the department. Students will audition for all main stage productions, or accept a significant assignment in stage management, costume, scenery, lighting or other technical element of production. Must be taken each semester during the time that a student is in junior/senior residence as a theater major, for a minimum of 4 or its equivalent.
THTR 3700A.prereq: 3 s.h. of THTR 2600 or permission of the instructor.
THTR 3700A.name: Theater Participation 2

THTR 1500.description: Survey of the department programs, policies, practices, and facilities, with particular emphasis on the needs of theater majors. Various aspects of theater study which may increase chances for success in the field. Creation of production records, portfolios, and vitae pertinent to the theater artist. To be taken within the first 30 hours of coursework.
THTR 1500.name: Auditions and Portfolios

THTR 3768.description: Critical approaches to dramatic literature. Analysis of dramatic works for production values.
THTR 3768.prereq: THTR 1559 and THTR 2668 or permission of instructor.
THTR 3768.name: Script Analysis

THTR 1563.description: Introduction to stage costuming through the study and application of costume construction techniques and costume crafts, the use of appropriate equipment, and costume maintenance through various projects involving the special techniques used for stage costuming.
THTR 1563.name: Costume Construction and Craft

THTR 3700.description: Advanced involvement in the main stage productions of the department. Students will audition for all main stage productions, or accept a significant assignment in stage management, costume, scenery, lighting or other technical element of production. Must be taken each semester during the time that a student is in junior/senior residence as a theater major, for a minimum of 4 or its equivalent.
THTR 3700.prereq: 3 s.h. of THTR 2600 or permission of the instructor.
THTR 3700.name: Theater Participation 2

THTR 1561.description: The technical elements of play production, with emphasis on stage mechanics, set construction, and scene painting.
THTR 1561.name: Stagecraft

THTR 1560.description: The theory, history, cultural role, and physical characteristics of the theater as an institution in human society.Gen Ed: Arts and Humanities, Arts and Humanities.
THTR 1560.name: Understanding Theater

THTR 3766.description: Applied skills class specializing in armed and unarmed combat for the stage. Safety factors in stage fighting, including safe use of rapier and dagger. Performance in public required.
THTR 3766.prereq: THTR 2668 or MUEN 0012 or HPES 1514 or permission of instructor.
THTR 3766.name: Stage Combat

THTR 3765.description: A study of historical development, basic electrical theory, switch boards and lighting instruments; color theory, principles and practices in stage lighting. Lab hours to be arranged.
THTR 3765.prereq: THTR 1559 and THTR 1561 or consent of instructor.
THTR 3765.name: Lighting Design

THTR 3764.description: A survey of stage costumes based on western styles from the ancient Egyptians to the present with emphasis on periods in which the theater flourished.
THTR 3764.name: History of Stage Costume

THTR 3763.description: The history of design in terms of stage scenery; an investigation of current trends, techniques, and media; practical execution of models and sketches by the student.
THTR 3763.prereq: THTR 1559 and THTR 1561 or consent of the instructor.
THTR 3763.name: Scene Design

THTR 3762.description: An intensive study of the process of directing plays. Whenever possible, students direct the equivalent of a one-act play for public presentation. Lab hours by arrangement.
THTR 3762.prereq: THTR 1559 and THTR 3768 or concurrently or permission of instructor.
THTR 3762.name: Directing 1

THTR 3761.description: Design and application of makeup for the stage including techniques for character and age makeup, making and applying facial hair, and other specialized makeup procedures.
THTR 3761.name: Stage Makeup

THTR 3769.description: Costume design for the stage through a study of script analysis, design concepts and principles, and costume rendering techniques.
THTR 3769.name: Costume Design

THTR 4870.description: A exploration of the theory and technique of film and video performance, and the special demands they make upon an actor.
THTR 4870.prereq: THTR 2668 and THTR 2667 and junior standing, or consent of instructor.
THTR 4870.name: Acting 4: Acting on Camera

MUIN 1561.description: Introduction to the music recording process and the recording studio. An overview of music recording grounded in History and the principles of acoustics. An exploration of analog and digital technology involved in music recording. Two hours lecture, two hours lab.
MUIN 1561.name: Music Recording Workshop

MUIN 4866.description: Practicum in appropriate music recording environments. Addresses all aspects of the music recording industry. Students meet once a week on campus to share and discuss experiences from the intern position. A minimum of 12 hours per week will be spent in the field.
MUIN 4866.prereq: MUIN 3765 and senior standing in music recording.
MUIN 4866.name: Recording Internship

MUIN 4867.description: Independent student project to showcase skills and techniques learned in the content courses. Presentation of project in a public exhibition required.
MUIN 4867.prereq: MUIN 3765 and senior standing in music recording.
MUIN 4867.name: Senior Project

MUIN 3762.description: An overview of MIDI and electronic musical instrument technology. Sequencers and mixing in the MIDI environment. Basic compositional techniques using MIDI and the computer, and the application of MIDI in the music recording environment.
MUIN 3762.name: Digital Sound Production

MUIN 3763.description: A study of both linear and non-linear music recording and editing. Various hardware and software options, as well as the production of recording projects in both domains.
MUIN 3763.name: Digital Recording and Editing

MUIN 3764.description: Investigation of the characteristics of different microphones, microphone design, microphone selection, and microphone placement. The accessories of various miking situations will be investigated. Experiments with different microphone techniques in both the analogue and digital domains.
MUIN 3764.name: Advanced Microphone Techniques

MUIN 3765.description: Investigates advanced elements of music recording from the recording session procedures to product manufacture. Advanced techniques in noise reduction, amplification, sound compression, and synchronization.
MUIN 3765.name: Advanced Recording Techniques

MUIN 3700.description: A general overview of the major functional areas of the music industry, with attention to the theoretical foundations and practical application of current business practices in the music industry.
MUIN 3700.prereq: Junior standing or permission of instructor.
MUIN 3700.name: Survey of Music Industry

EUT 2606.description: Discusses the operation of large utility power plants including start-up and shut-down of all major systems, disturbance response, and safe operation of plant systems. Three hours lecture per week.
EUT 2606.prereq: EUT 1503 and EUT 1503, EUT 1503L.Concurrent and EUT 2605/EUT 2605L.
EUT 2606.name: Power Plant Operator Practice

EUT 2607.description: Introduces basic principles of process instrumentation and control systems. Measurement parameters such as flow, pressure, level, temperature, and pH. Includes coverage of programmable logic controllers, and distributed control systems. Three hours lecture per week.
EUT 2607.prereq: EUT 2604, EUT 2604L and EUT 2605, EUT 2605L.Concurrent with: EUT 2607L.
EUT 2607.name: Power Plant Instrumentation and Control

EUT 2604.description: Study of three-phase power systems including motors, generators, transformers, and switchgear. NEC and NESC Code requirements, automatic and manual motor controls, variable speed drives, circuit protection. Three hours lecture per week.
EUT 2604.name: Power Plant Electrical Equipment

EUT 2605.description: Continuation of EUT 1502. Study of power plant cycles, thermodynamic properties of water and steam, and use of steam tables. Includes thermodynamic analysis of boiler system, feedwater, superheat, and reheat systems, heat transfer in pre-heaters, turbine, condensers, and pumps. Three hours lecture per week.
EUT 2605.name: Intermediate Power Plant Systems

EUT 2605L.description: Lab component to accompany EUT 2605. Provides hands-on and computational methods to dynamic analysis of boiler system, feedwater, superheat, and reheat systems, heat transfer in pre-heaters, turbine, condenser, and pumps. Three hours per week.
EUT 2605L.name: Intermediate Power Plant Systems Lab

EUT 2600.description: Applications of transformers, switchgear, regulators, overhead conductors and underground cable. Power factor correction, voltage regulation, coordination and overcurrent protection of distribution circuits.
EUT 2600.name: Electric Utility Distribution Systems

EUT 1505.description: Introduction to piping systems, basic hydraulics and pneumatics, hydraulic and pneumatic troubleshooting, rigging and equipment installation, welding principals, oxyacetylene cutting and welding. Three hours lecture, three hours lab per week.
EUT 1505.prereq: EUT 1502 and EUT 1504, concurrent or prerequisite EUT 1503.
EUT 1505.name: Maintenance Fundamentals 2

EUT 2601.description: National Electrical Code and National Electrical Safety Code as applied to overhead and underground electric utility distribution systems. Pole guying, overhead conductor sag and tension, cable pulling, and clearances. Four hours lecture per week.
EUT 2601.name: Electrical Codes and Standards

EUT 1504.description: Introduction to blueprint reading and technical diagrams, use of hand tools and power tools, safety and health, development of troubleshooting skills, chemical hazards, and material safety data sheets. Three hours lecture, and three hours lab per week.Prereq. or concurrent: ENTC 1500.
EUT 1504.name: Maintenance Fundamentals 1

EUT 1500L.description: Lab component of EUT 1500. Provides hands-on instruction in the use of electrical test equipment including digital multimeters, power supplies, oscilloscopes, etc. Three hours per week.
EUT 1500L.prereq: ENTC 1500 and MATH 1501 or at least level 3 on the Mathematics Placement Test.Concurrent with: EUT 1500.
EUT 1500L.name: Electrical Fundamentals Lab

EUT 2608L.description: Lab component to accompany EUT 2608. Provides hands-on activities related to on-line boiler control concepts, pollution control systems, gas turbines and diesel generators. Three hours per week.
EUT 2608L.prereq: EUT 2605, EUT 2605L.Concurrent with: EUT 2607, EUT 2607L and EUT 2608.
EUT 2608L.name: Advanced Power Plant Systems Lab

EUT 1500.description: Introduction to direct and alternating current circuits. Study of resistance, capacitance, inductance, Ohm's and Kirchoff's Laws applied to circuits. Three hours lecture per week.
EUT 1500.prereq: ENTC 1500 and MATH 1501 or at least level 3 on the Mathematics Placement Test.Concurrent with: EUT 1500L.
EUT 1500.name: Electrical Fundamentals

EUT 1502.description: Introduction to power plant systems including boiler, turbine, generator, condenser, pumps, and auxiliary equipment. Emphasizes use of schematics and diagrams in discussing plant systems. Includes plant safety training. Four hours lecture per week.
EUT 1502.prereq: MATH 1501 or Level 3 on MPT and eligible to enroll in ENGL 1550.Prereq. or concurrent: ENTC 1500.Concurrent: EUT 1502L.
EUT 1502.name: Power Plant Fundamentals

EUT 1503.description: Introduction to various mechanical equipment found in power plants including pumps, fans, blowers, valves, heat exchangers and power transmission equipment. Mechanical concepts of force and torque. Basic types of bearings, seals, and lubrication. Mechanical assembly drawings and diagrams. Three hours lecture per week.
EUT 1503.prereq: ENTC 1500 and EUT 1502, EUT 1502L, and MATH 1501.Concurrent with: EUT 1503L.
EUT 1503.name: Power Plant Mechanical Equipment

EUT 1503L.description: Lab component to accompany EUT 1503. Provides hands-on activities related to pumps, fans, blowers, valves, heat exchangers, bearings, seals, lubrication, and power transmission equipment. Three hours lab per week.
EUT 1503L.prereq: ENTC 1500, EUT 1502, EUT 1502L, and MATH 1501.Concurrent with: EUT 1503.
EUT 1503L.name: Power Plant Mechanical Equipment Lab

EUT 2608.description: Continuation of EUT 2605. Examines on-line boiler control concepts, including combustion, feedwater, header pressure, oxygen content, power demand, and other processes as applied to utility boilers and process heat supply boilers. Also examines pollution control systems, gas turbines and diesel generators. Three hours lecture per week.
EUT 2608.prereq: EUT 2605, EUT 2605L.Concurrent with: EUT 2607, EUT 2607L and EUT 2608L.
EUT 2608.name: Advanced Power Plant Systems

EUT 1502L.description: Lab component to accompany EUT 1502. Provides introduction to power generating plant systems and equipment including boiler, turbine, generator, condenser, pumps, and auxiliary equipment. Emphasizes the use of schematics and diagrams in discussing plant systems. Three hours laboratory per week.Concurrent with: EUT 1502.
EUT 1502L.name: Power Plant Fundamentals Lab

EUT 2699.description: Compensated and evaluated work experience with local utility company. Forty contact hours per week.
EUT 2699.name: Electric Utility Co-op

EUT 2604L.description: Lab component to accompany EUT 2604. Provides hands-on activities related to three-phase power systems, motors, generators, transformers, and switchgear. Three hours lab per week.
EUT 2604L.name: Power Plant Electrical Equipment Lab

EUT 2607L.description: Lab component to accompany EUT 2607. Provides hands-on activities related to process instrumentation and control systems. Three hours per week.
EUT 2607L.name: Power Plant Instrumentation & Control Lab

INFO 2663.description: Principles and practices of effective information systems management. Includes organization environment, leadership issues, information system types, strategic role of information technology, planning issues, managing and supporting essential technologies, system development and computing, and successful integration of people and technology.
INFO 2663.name: Information Technology Management

INFO 1575.description: Preparation of documents using information processing and standard and advanced electronic productivity tools such as templates, tables, columns, forms macros, graphics, and merging. Integration of documents with other software. Creating and maintaining hypertext documents.
INFO 1575.prereq: Knowledge of word processing or ENGL 1550.
INFO 1575.name: Document Preparation

INFO 3714.description: Includes macros, look-up tables, advanced problems, templates, and projects with emphasis on accounting and finance applications.
INFO 3714.name: Advanced Spreadsheets

INFO 4895.description: A study of special topics in information technologies. Subject matter and credit hours will be announced in advance. May be repeated multiple times if topic is different.
INFO 4895.prereq: At least 3 s.h. of upper-division departmental courses and permission of chair.
INFO 4895.name: Special Topics

INFO 5875.description: Advanced study of multimedia authoring tools. Analysis of commercial applications. Group project required. Three hours lecture and two hours lab.
INFO 5875.name: Advanced Multimedia Authoring

INFO 3704.description: Communication theory and practice. Business letter writing; oral communication. Review of English usage.
INFO 3704.name: Business Communication

INFO 3787.description: Theory and practice of designing training programs. Analyzing training needs, selecting instructional strategies, and implementing and evaluating training programs.
INFO 3787.prereq: INFO 3774 or both INFO 1575 and CSIS 1590.
INFO 3787.name: Training and Employee Development

INFO 3774.description: Technical configurations, graphic creation, manipulation, exchange, and digital asset management. Web and multimedia audio and video. Video strategies on the Internet. Fundamental Web utility tools. Storyboarding strategies, layout, and design issues. Three hours lecture, two hours lab.
INFO 3774.name: Multimedia Technology

INFO 4880.description: Information systems integration and modeling. Analysis of dynamic information flow, functional requirements, and system design in theory and practice.
INFO 4880.prereq: CSIS 3722 and either CSIS 3723 or CSIS 3782.Gen Ed: Capstone.
INFO 4880.name: Information Technology Analysis and Design

INFO 3777.description: Study of tools and technology for digital image processing. Creating and capturing still and video images for use in Web site development. Techniques used in compression and archiving of graphics files. Project required. Three hours lecture and two hours lab.
INFO 3777.name: Computer Technology for Digital Image Processing

INFO 3790.description: Students organize and operate an information center utilizing decision-making skills, and information systems procedures and components. Lab time required.
INFO 3790.name: Integrated Information Systems

INFO 2672.description: Document creation using desktop publishing software on a microcomputer. Application must be mastered on a software package used by industry. Lab time required.
INFO 2672.name: Desktop Publishing 1

INFO 2673.description: Specialized and advanced document creation using desktop publishing software used by industry. A second software package must be mastered. Lab time required.
INFO 2673.name: Desktop Publishing 2

INFO 3776.description: Foundations of web site development including e-commerce, multimedia, database integration, security, and accessibility. Use of scripting languages for interactivity. Three hours lecture and two hours lab.
INFO 3776.name: Web Site Development

INFO 2600.description: The foundation and general principles behind information technology, including data representation, encoding systems, encryption methods, database fundamentals, logic for programming, basic data analysis, and graph applications in networking.
INFO 2600.name: Concepts of Information Technologies

INFO 2698.description: An in-depth study of information technologies. Topics vary. May be repeated for different topics.
INFO 2698.name: Special Topics

INFO 3775.description: A study of multimedia authoring tools. Methods for integrating text, graphics, sound, and video. Project required. Three hours lecture and two hours lab.
INFO 3775.name: Multimedia Authoring

SPAN 3755.description: Development of oral expression through discussion of current topics in the context of worldwide Hispanic culture, politics, and economics. Expansion of vocabulary. Laboratory work according to individual needs.
SPAN 3755.name: Advanced Spanish Conversation

SPAN 3758.description: Provides an overview of the significant culture and literature of the diverse Hispanic groups in the U.S. The relationship between literature and society broached through an in-depth discussion of several representative texts and their historical and political background.
SPAN 3758.name: Culture and Literature of Spanish-Speaking Groups in the United States

SPAN 3736.description: Examines some of the basic concepts and issues of modern Spanish linguistic theory in the areas of phonology, morphology, syntax and pragmatics, with special emphasis on sociolinguistics.
SPAN 3736.name: Introduction to Spanish Linguistics

SPAN 3737.description: Study of translation techniques, and practice in translating from Spanish into English and from English into Spanish, working with a variety of texts from the social sciences, natural sciences, and technology. Emphasis on interpretation of vocabulary and idioms.
SPAN 3737.name: Translation and Composition

SPAN 3735.description: A systematic study of Spanish morphology, sentence structure, and usage applied to a variety of written discourse styles such as description, narration, and exposition. Discussion of contrasts with English discourse styles, and effective grammatical use.
SPAN 3735.name: Advanced Spanish Grammar and Composition

SPAN 5885.description: Examines the relationship between the Hispanic narrative discourse and cinema, including film adaptations of literary works. Modern social and cultural issues, as well as Hispanic self-images. May be taken three times if content is not repeated.
SPAN 5885.prereq: one of SPAN 3762, SPAN 3763, SPAN 3766, SPAN 3767.Gen Ed: Capstone, Capstone.
SPAN 5885.name: Topics in Hispanic Literature and Film

SPAN 6901.description: Arranged course for graduate students only.
SPAN 6901.prereq: Two 4800-level courses in Spanish with grade of "B" or better.
SPAN 6901.name: Special Topics in Spanish

SPAN 3798.description: A structured but individualized program of study at the Universidad del Norte in Barranquilla, Colombia. The course encompasses an orientation prior to the study abroad experience and the study abroad experience itself. A grade will not be given until the student returns from the study abroad.
SPAN 3798.name: Study Abroad in Colombia

SPAN 3799.description: An individually-arranged program of foreign study in the Spanish language. Programs can be of two general types: (1) trips or residential programs sponsored by consortial universities, and (2) independent academic coursework through institutions with which YSU does not have a consortial agreement. A written statement detailing the student's academic plan must be approved by a member of the Spanish faculty, the chair of Foreign Languages and the dean of CLASS prior to the trip. Credit toward fulfillment of requirements for the Spanish major will be determined by the chair of Foreign Languages and the Spanish faculty. May be repeated up to a total of 15 s.h., if specific course content changes. Note: study abroad generally requires about one year's advance planning.
SPAN 3799.prereq: Sophomore status and approval of the chair of Foreign Languages.
SPAN 3799.name: Study Abroad in Spanish

SPAN 3740.description: Principles of effective commercial letter and report writing and oral communication in business in the Spanish-speaking world.
SPAN 3740.name: Business Spanish

SPAN 4881.description: Capstone course emphasizing impromptu conversations and in-class essay writing. Students must achieve a level of Intermediate High on both the ACTFL Oral Proficiency Interview and the ACTFL Writing Proficiency Test.
SPAN 4881.prereq: 15 s.h. in Spanish at the 3700 level or above and permission of Chair.
SPAN 4881.name: Spanish Composition and Conversation Capstone

SPAN 4880.description: Capstone course emphasizing impromptu conversation and in-class essay writing. Student must achieve a level of Advanced Low on both the ACTFL Oral Proficiency Interview and the ACTFL Writing Proficiency Test.
SPAN 4880.prereq: 15 s.h. in Spanish at the 3700 level or above and permission of Chair.
SPAN 4880.name: Spanish Conversation and Composition Capstone

SPAN 2600.description: Intensive training in understanding, speaking, reading, and writing Spanish; geography and daily life, as well as appreciation of the cultures of Spanish speakers are studied. Assignments in the Language Learning and Resource Center (LLRC).
SPAN 2600.name: Intermediate Spanish

SPAN 3767.description: Introduction to Spanish-American literature through representative selections of key works of fiction, poetry and film. Theoretical and critical approaches to help the student interpret texts.
SPAN 3767.name: Introduction to Literature: Spanish-America

SPAN 3766.description: This course examines the cultural landscape and major issues in Spanish-American society through the study of art, history, geography, politics, music, cinema, popular culture, and cultural groups in the various regions.
SPAN 3766.name: Culture: Spanish-America

SPAN 2605.description: Review and expansion of basic Spanish language skills and cultural information. Assignments in the Language Learning and Resource Center (LLRC).
SPAN 2605.name: Advanced Intermediate Spanish

SPAN 3763.description: Introduction to Peninsular literature through representative selections of key works of fiction, poetry and film. Theoretical and critical approaches to help the student interpret texts.
SPAN 3763.name: Introduction to Literature: Spain

SPAN 3762.description: Examination of the cultural landscape and major issues in Spanish society through the study of art, history, geography, politics, music, cinema, popular culture, and cultural groups in the various regions of Spain.
SPAN 3762.name: Culture: Spain

SPAN 3702.description: Further study of the Spanish language and Hispanic cultures through oral, written, and reading activities. Focus is on contextualized vocabulary and review of grammar to help students move towards a more advanced level.
SPAN 3702.name: Intensive Spanish Review

SPAN 3701.description: Using the Spanish language to engage in community service or an internship. Completion of a journal written in Spanish and detailing the experience is required. May be repeated up to 4 s.h.
SPAN 3701.prereq: Approval of Department Chair; and SPAN 2600 or placement test.
SPAN 3701.name: Service Learning in Spanish

SPAN 5890.description: Study of an author, a genre, or a movement in Latin America from 1492 to the present. The topic will be announced each time the course is offered. May be taken three times if content is not repeated.
SPAN 5890.prereq: SPAN 3766 or SPAN 3767.Gen Ed: Capstone, Capstone.
SPAN 5890.name: Topics in Spanish Literature: Spanish-America

SPAN 1550.description: Intensive training in understanding, speaking, reading, and writing Spanish. Geography and daily life, as well as appreciation of the culture of its speakers, are studied. Assignments in the Language Learning and Resource Center (LLRC). Grading is ABC/NC.
SPAN 1550.name: Elementary Spanish

SPAN 3780.description: Review course emphasizing impromptu conversations and in-class essay writing. Intended for students who need additional coursework to achieve the level of Advanced Low on the ACTFL Oral Proficiency Interview and/or ACTFL Writing Proficiency Test. May not be counted toward the major. Grading is CR/NC.
SPAN 3780.prereq: 15 s.h. in Spanish at the 3700 level or above and permission of Chair.
SPAN 3780.name: Spanish Composition and Conversation Review

SPAN 5870.description: Study of an author, a genre, or a movement in Spanish literature from 1492 to the present. The topic will be announced each time the course is offered. May be taken three times if content is not repeated.
SPAN 5870.name: Topics in Spanish Literature: Spain

SPAN 5855.description: An introduction to the terminology, concepts, bibliography and current issues in Spanish language and linguistics. Major topics include phonology, morphology, semantics, syntax, applied linguistics, transformational grammar, and other topics related to language variation and society. May be repeated once when topic varies.
SPAN 5855.name: Topics in Spanish Language and Linguistics

SPAN 3724.description: Theory and practice of Spanish pronunciation. Description of production of Spanish speech sounds and general characteristics of Spanish pronunciation. Topics on intonation. Audio-lingual practice in class and in language laboratory.
SPAN 3724.name: Spanish Pronunciation

JUDC 3751.description: The history of the Holocaust as revealed by the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum. Requires supervised visit to the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington D.C. in addition to coursework.
JUDC 3751.name: Lessons of the Holocaust from the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum

JUDC 1500.description: A broad overview of Jewish history, culture, literature, and religion. Covers Jewish Civilization from its emergence in the Ancient Near East to its diverse worldwide expressions in the present day.
JUDC 1500.name: Introduction to Jewish Studies

MET 3720.description: Graphical and analytical solution of problems involving displacement, velocity, and acceleration in machine mechanisms. Design of linkages with drafting software to provide required motions of machine members. Two hours lecture, three hours lab per week.
MET 3720.prereq: C or better in MET 2616, "C" or better in MATH 1570 or "C" or better in MATH 1571.
MET 3720.name: Mechanisms

MET 4812L.description: A study of the programming of numerically-controlled machine tools. Students program NC machines using manual and computer-assisted techniques. Three hours lab per week. Coreq. or.
MET 4812L.name: Numerical Control Lab

MET 3705.description: Properties of ideal and real gases, first and second laws of thermodynamics, application to thermodynamic cycles involving power plants and cyclic machinery.
MET 3705.prereq: "C" or better in CHEM 1515 or CHEM 1505, "C" or better in EET 3725.
MET 3705.name: Thermodynamics

MET 3706.description: Principles of stresses and deflections, shear and moment diagrams, combined stresses, fatigue, measurement of strain, and theories of failure. Application of these principles to design of machine components. Includes a capstone experience for MET AAS degrees. 4 s.h.
MET 3706.prereq: "C" or better in CCET 2604, "C" or better in DDT 1503.
MET 3706.name: Machine Design 1

MET 3707.description: Continuation of MET 3706, progressing to the design of machine elements such as gears, belts, clutches, chains, bearings, welded and bolted joints. Two hours lecture, three hours lab per week.
MET 3707.name: Machine Design 2

MET 3737.description: This course builds upon MET 3736 Design of Solar Systems I and adds more detailed analysis to the capture and use of solar energy. The radiation spectrum is defined and integration methods presented. Further discussion of solar use in heat pumps and absorption systems is explored. Three hours lecture and 1-1 1/2 computational lab. Prereq. MATH 2670 and MET 3736.
MET 3737.name: Design of Solar Systems 2

MET 3740.description: Evaluation of wind energy as a low-impact alternative energy source. Topics include selection of an appropriate wind site, types of turbines, and capture efficiency of wind devices. The electrical and mechanical systems are reviewed in detail, along with economic calculations and discussion of related codes. Three hours lecture and 1-1 1/2 computational lab. Prereq. or.Coreq.: with EET 1502, EET 1502L.
MET 3740.name: Design of Wind Systems 1

MET 3742.description: Several methods of biodiesel production are surveyed, such as algae, palm, and soy. The chemical process of each method is explored and analyzed. Existing production systems and campus research projects are used in class demonstrations. Three hours lecture and 1-1 1/2 computational lab. Prereq. CHEM 1505, CHEM 1505L or CHEM 1515, CHEM 1515L, BIOL 2601, BIOL 2601L, and MET 3705.
MET 3742.name: Biodiesel Processes

MET 3743.description: Several methods of fuel cells are explored including Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells (PEMFC), Solid Polymer Electrolyte Fuel Cells (SPEFC) and Solid Oxide Fuel Cells (SOFC). The principles of operation existing barriers for each system will be presented, along with the current reach and economical feasibility. Three hours lecture and 1-1 1/2 computational lab.
MET 3743.prereq: MET 3705 and CHEM 1515, CHEM 1515L or CHEM 1505, CHEM 1505L.
MET 3743.name: Fuel Cell Systems

MET 4810.description: Study of manufacturing systems including manufacturing process design, analysis, selection and sequencing; value analysis, machine tool cost and functions; computer and statistical simulation of production systems. Two hours lecture and three hours of computational lab per week.
MET 4810.name: Manufacturing Systems Analysis

MET 4812.description: A study of the programming of numerically-controlled machine tools. Students program NC machines using manual and computer-assisted techniques.
MET 4812.prereq: "C" or better in DDT 2606, and "C" or better in MET 3707.
MET 4812.name: Numerical Control

MET 4850.description: The practical techniques used in the design of heating, ventilating, and air conditioning systems, including load calculations, unit selection, and duct system layout. The laboratory work includes the use of design charts and manufacturer's catalogs in a project. Two hours lecture, two hours lab per week.
MET 4850.name: Air Conditioning Principles and Practice

MET 4860L.description: Practice in the programming and application of industrial robots and associated equipment. Construction of simulated robotic workcells using actual industrial robots, programmable controllers, sensors, and grippers. Two hours lab per week.
MET 4860L.name: Robotics Technology Laboratory

MET 4870.description: Principles of the finite element method and its application to the analysis of stress, strain, and heat transfer. Computer aided solutions to two- and three-dimensional problems in structural analysis, mechanical design and heat transfer. Two hours lecture, three hours lab per week. Prereq. or.Coreq.: with MET 3707 or "C" or better in CCET 3709.
MET 4870.name: Applied Finite Element Method

MET 4890.description: New developments in Mechanical Engineering Technology. Subject matter, special prerequisites, and credit hours to be announced in advance of each offering. May be repeated with different subject matter to a maximum of 8 s.h.
MET 4890.prereq: Senior standing in MET or consent of the instructor.
MET 4890.name: Special Topics in Mechanical Engineering Technology

MET 3735.description: The methods of hydrogen production are discussed, including stem reforming, coal gasification, fermentation, and electrolysis. Storage systems are presented, along with national codes for the storage equipment, and best practices. Three hours lecture and 1-1 1/2 lab. of CHEM 1505, CHEM 1505L or CHEM 1515, CHEM 1515L.Prereq. or concurrent MET 3705 and Prereq.
MET 3735.name: Hydrogen Production and Storage

MET 1515.description: Study of forces as vector quantities; resultants of force systems; principles of mechanical equilibrium; application of principles to problems, devices and structures commonly encountered in industry. Two hours lecture, three hours lab per week.
MET 1515.prereq: "C" or better in ENTC 1505 and MATH 1513.
MET 1515.name: Mechanics 1

MET 3736.description: Use of the sun as an energy source is explored in forms of electricity or heat. Topics include regions that are best suited for solar, solar energy capture methods, energy conversion to electricity, steam or hot water. Actual systems are evaluated, including electrical and mechanical design, economic calculations, and related codes. Three hours lecture and 1-1 1/2 lab. of CHEM 1505, CHEM 1505L or CHEM 1515, CHEM 1515L.Prereq. or concurrent EET 1502/L and Prereq.
MET 3736.name: Design of Solar Systems 1

MET 3731.description: The field of Alternative Energy Technologies requires significant writing skills to prepare the many parts of a proposal. Students will learn about funding sources for grants, prepare all portions of a grant proposal including Statement of Need, Work Plans, Budgets, Outcomes and Periodic Reports.
MET 3731.name: Grant Proposal

MET 3730.description: The analysis and evaluation of financial factors that affect alternative energy systems explored in several common systems, such as soar, fuel cells, biodiesel, and wind, along with existing fuels such as coal, oil, natural gas, and nuclear.
MET 3730.name: Energy and Financial Modeling

MET 3739.description: This course provides students with basic knowledge on geothermal systems, the most-favorable areas for geothermal, principles of heat pumps and geothermal steam systems, common design principles, followed by economics, code requirements and LEED contributions. Three hours lecture and 1-1 1/2 computational lab.
MET 3739.name: Geothermal Processes

MET 3714.description: Principles of fluid statics and fluid dynamics and their application to incompressible flow in pipes and channels; Bernoulli's equation, laminar and turbulent flow; energy and momentum in fluid flow.
MET 3714.name: Fluid Mechanics

MET 3714L.description: Tests and applications of concepts covered in MET 3714. Three hours lab per week.Concurrent with: MET 3714.
MET 3714L.name: Fluid Mechanics Laboratory

MET 3711.description: A continuation of MET 3705, including the study of heat transfer, the Rankine cycle, the Otto cycle, the Diesel cycle, and the performance of pumps and heat exchangers.
MET 3711.prereq: 'C" or better in MET 3714, "C" or better in MET 3705.
MET 3711.name: Heat and Power Cycles

MET 3710.description: Design and selection of cutting tools, fixtures, bending and forming dies, inspection and gauging instruments, and material feed mechanisms. Two hours lecture, three hours lab per week.
MET 3710.name: Tool Design

MET 2616.description: Continuation of MET 1515 with further application of statics, introduction to dynamics of solids, study of various types of motion, Newton's second law, work and energy, impulse and momentum. Two hours lecture, three hours lab per week.
MET 2616.name: Mechanics 2

MET 2630.description: The study of materials and processes used in manufacturing, including casting, heat treatment, hot and cold working, plastics processing and machining, Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing.
MET 2630.name: Manufacturing Techniques

MET 4820.description: Analysis and comprehensive design of complex machine systems incorporating hydraulic and pneumatic subsystems and electrical controls as a capstone experience. Two hours lecture, three hours lab per week. "C" or better or concurrent with MET 4810.
MET 4820.name: Machine Systems

MET 4860.description: An application-oriented course on the technology and use of industrial robots, including classification, tooling, sensors, workcell design, safety, and programming.
MET 4860.name: Robotics Technology

MET 2630L.description: Practice and procedures of machine tool operation including lathes, drill presses, shapers, and milling machines. Two hours lab per week. "C" or better in MET 2630 or concurrent with MET 2630.
MET 2630L.name: Manufacturing Techniques Laboratory

PLA 1500.description: Examines the importance of learning outcomes and the ways in which faculty evaluate the achievement of those outcomes. The course walks students through the process of evaluating their own experience for the achievement of college-level learning and the demonstration of that learning through the preparation of an academic portfolio. $300 course fee assessed. Grading is CR/NC.
PLA 1500.name: Portfolio Development

PLA 2600.description: Offers credit for learning that has occurred outside the traditional academic classroom and is awarded for college-level learning (knowledge, skills, and competencies) that students have obtained as a result of their prior learning experiences. Mastery is deemed undergraduate lower-level learning. Credit may be applied to the transcript multiple times. Grading is CR/NC.
PLA 2600.name: Prior Learning Assessment Lower Division Credit

PLA 3700.description: Offers credit for learning that has occurred outside the traditional academic classroom and is awarded for college-level learning (knowledge, skills, and competencies) that students have obtained as a result of their prior learning experiences. Mastery is deemed undergraduate upper-level learning. Credit may be applied to the transcript multiple times. Grading is CR/NC.
PLA 3700.name: Prior Learning Assessment Upper Division Credit

STEM 1599.description: Introduction to the doctoral medical professions. Review of careers including allopathic medicine, osteopathic medicine, dentistry, optometry, podiatric medicine, chiropractic medicine, veterinary medicine, and pharmacy; also entrance requirements for medical programs and advising resources at YSU. Grading is CR/NC.
STEM 1599.name: Medical Professions Seminar

STEM 4891.description: Integrate theory and practice jointly supervised by working professional and College of STEM faculty mentor for 40 hours/week assignment at approved employer. Students see Coordinator of STEM Student Professional Services (SSPS) and faculty advisor, receive professional practice training, submit co-op proposal, receive co-op offer from approved employer, file weekly work logs for faculty mentor review, make public presentation, and write final project paper. May be repeated.
STEM 4891.prereq: junior or senior standing, 3.00 GPA in a STEM program, 2.75 GPA overall, and approval of Coordinator of SSPS in consultation with student's department chair.
STEM 4891.name: STEM Cooperative Education Assignment

STEM 2625.description: Guest lecture forum course designed to provide students with exposure to a broad range of topics and current research relevant to the petroleum industry and water resource issues. Course may be repeated.
STEM 2625.name: Natural Gas and Water Resources Seminar

STEM 2600.description: Student investigations in the natural sciences using a variety of laboratory approaches focused on a single theme or concept; a multidisciplinary study from two of the following science areas (biology, chemistry, physical geography, geology, physics, astronomy, environmental science) segmented in three five-week units (6 hrs/wk including 2 to 3 hours of instruction).
STEM 2600.name: Exploration in the Sciences

STEM 4895.description: Faculty-directed research for students pursuing practical research experience in a STEM-related discipline. May be repeated for up to 3 s.h.
STEM 4895.prereq: Junior status; submission of an approved thesis proposal; permission of the STEM dean.
STEM 4895.name: Senior Thesis

STEM 2601H.description: An interdisciplinary course dealing with topics appropriate to students in the BSMD program. The subjects include, but are not limited to, MCAT preparation, study skills appropriate for the accelerated curriculum, the organization and function of the university, critical thinking, current events, etc.
STEM 2601H.name: Honors BSMD Seminar

STEM 1520.description: The course is designed to enhance the transition and adjustment of first-year students in the College of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics by exploring key concepts and issues that support student motivation and academic persistence.
STEM 1520.name: STEM First Year Orientation

STEM 1505.description: Topics pertaining to safety in STEM College laboratories with applications to industry, including chemical safety, electrical safety, planning for emergencies, etc.
STEM 1505.name: Safety Principles in the STEM College

STEM 1551.description: An introduction to the career opportunities available in the different STEM majors. Designed to help students choose a STEM major field of study and understand the relationship between science and technology. To enhance student success. One hour lecture per week. Grading is ABC/NC.
STEM 1551.name: STEM Careers

STEM 1550.description: Introduction to STEM fundamentals including problem solving, data management, modeling of physical systems, and scientific communication skills. One hour lecture and 3 hours lab per week.
STEM 1550.prereq: Eligible to take Math 1513 or higher-level math course.
STEM 1550.name: Introduction to STEM

STEM 1513.description: Develops and studies connections between mathematical concepts and the empirical sciences, and applies these connections to engineering and technology.
STEM 1513.prereq: placement out of RSS 1510A and RSS 1510B (no reading placement) and concurrent registration in MATH 1510 and/or MATH 1511.
STEM 1513.name: Studies in STEM Connectivity

STEM 4890.description: Integrate theory and practice jointly supervised by working professional and STEM faculty mentor for part-time assignment at approved employer. Students see Coordinator of STEM Student Professional Services (SSPS) and faculty advisor, receive professional practice training, submit internship proposal, receive internship offer from approved employer, file weekly work logs for faculty mentor review, make public presentation, and write final project paper. May be repeated.
STEM 4890.prereq: junior or senior standing, 3.00 GPA in STEM program, 2.75 GPA overall, and special approval of the Coordinator of SSPS in consultation with student's department chair.
STEM 4890.name: STEM Internship

STEM 3700.description: A behavioral science and humanities perspective on individual and social issues which affect medical care delivery. In addition to classes, seminars, and workshops, it may include field projects, participation in health-related investigations and presentations, and personal development programs. Credit toward fulfillment of the area requirement will be determined by the dean of the College of Arts and Sciences and will be based upon the selection of courses. May be repeated once. For current students.
STEM 3700.prereq: PSYC 1560 and PHIL 2600 or consent of dean.
STEM 3700.name: Human Values in Medicine

STEM 1530.description: Cross-listed as ART 1530. Introduction to the visual and organizational components of two and three dimensional design, development of ideas and creative critical thinking as applied to tangible form. The course leads to an understanding of design as a verb and encourages inventiveness and collaboration to generate ideas.Gen Ed: Environmental Sustainability, Social and Personal Awareness, Environmental Sustainability, Social and Personal Awareness.
STEM 1530.name: Sustainable Design in Practice

STEM 1530H.description: Cross-listed as ART 1530. Introduction to the visual and organizational components of two and three dimensional design, development of ideas and creative critical thinking as applied to tangible form. The course leads to an understanding of design as a verb and encourages inventiveness and collaboration to generate ideas.Gen Ed: Environmental Sustainability, Social and Personal Awareness, Environmental Sustainability, Social and Personal Awareness.
STEM 1530H.name: Honors Sustainable Design in Practice

STEM 3789.description: Apply theory in professional practice experience overseen by appropriate working professional for employment at approved employer. Students see faculty advisor, submit professional practice proposal for approval and write final project paper. May be repeated for a maximum of 8 s.h.
STEM 3789.prereq: at least sophomore standing, 2.00 GPA in STEM program, and special approval of the STEM Professional Practice Director in consultation with student's department chair.
STEM 3789.name: STEM Professional Practice

STEM 3791.description: Apply theory in professional practice experience overseen by working professional and College of STEM faculty mentor for 40 hours/week assignment at approved employer. Students see Coordinator of STEM Student Professional Services (SSPS) and faculty advisor, receive professional practice training, submit assignment proposal for approval, file weekly work logs for faculty mentor review, make public presentation, and write final project paper. May be repeated.
STEM 3791.prereq: at least sophomore standing, 2.00 GPA in STEM program, and approval by the Coordinator of SSPS in consultation with student's department chair.
STEM 3791.name: STEM Cooperative Education Experience

STEM 3790.description: Apply theory in professional practice experience overseen by working professional and STEM faculty mentor for part-time assignment at approved employer. Students see Coordinator of STEM Student Professional Services (SSPS) and faculty advisor, receive professional practice training, submit assignment proposal for approval, file weekly work logs for faculty mentor review, make public presentation, and write final project paper. May be repeated.
STEM 3790.prereq: at least sophomore standing, 2.00 GPA in STEM program, and approval by Coordinator of SSPS in consultation with student's department chair.
STEM 3790.name: STEM Internship Experience

CIS 3741.description: This course provides an in-depth study of business programming. It includes the mastery of a high-level language suitable for business programming, such as COBOL, and the development of a large multi-step business application project. Three hours lecture, two hours lab.
CIS 3741.name: Business Programming Project

CIS 4840.description: Development of communication and written skills for the analysis and design of business systems. Utilization of project management techniques for design, development, and maintenance of a departmental level system.
CIS 4840.prereq: CSIS 3722, CSIS 3723, and 3 additional s.h. of upper-division departmental courses.Gen Ed: Capstone.
CIS 4840.name: Business System Analysis and Design

CIS 4810.description: Study of special topics in computer information systems. Subject matter and credit hours will be announced in advance. May be repeated multiple times if topic is different.
CIS 4810.prereq: At least 3 s.h. of upper-division departmental courses, and permission of chair.
CIS 4810.name: Special Topics

CIS 4820.description: The organization of a computer center, with emphasis on features and selection criteria of communication equipment, including mainframe, minicomputer, and microcomputer systems.
CIS 4820.prereq: CIS 3741 or INFO 2663, 3 s.h. of upper-division departmental courses.
CIS 4820.name: Computer Center Operations

CIS 3718.description: Concepts of computer operating systems, including memory allocation, job scheduling, process communication, and input/output processing. Examinations of operating systems on several platforms.
CIS 3718.name: Operating Systems Concepts

CIS 3735.description: Use of the UNIX operating system or similar systems, including file management utilities, editors, compilers, and communication utilities. A comprehensive examination of programming in various shells such as Bourne, C, and Korn.
CIS 3735.name: UNIX Environment

CIS 3714.description: Fundamentals of computer architecture and organization. Forms of data representation. Assembly language and machine language programming. The assembly process. Methods and protocols for subroutine linkage.
CIS 3714.name: Assembly Language and Architecture

TUBA 4802.description: Private Music Lessons.Gen Ed: Capstone, Capstone.
TUBA 4802.name: Tuba

TUBA 4806.description: Private Music Lessons.Gen Ed: Capstone, Capstone.
TUBA 4806.name: Tuba

TUBA 4804.description: Private Music Lessons.Gen Ed: Capstone, Capstone.
TUBA 4804.name: Tuba

ACCT 2602.description: Study of the accounting cycle and generally accepted accounting principles including preparation of financial statements.
ACCT 2602.prereq: Sophomore standing or "C" or better in BUS 1500 and "C" or better in MATH 1507 or level 40 on math placement test.
ACCT 2602.name: Financial Accounting

ACCT 2603.description: Study of the accounting informational needs of management. Emphasis on techniques of planning and control.
ACCT 2603.name: Managerial Accounting

ACCT 2600.description: Internship and/or cooperative education experiences in accounting. Students may be assigned to corporate, non-profit, or government entities on a semester basis. Can repeat this course once for a different field experience.
ACCT 2600.prereq: 2.5 GPA, department approval and sophomore standing.
ACCT 2600.name: Accounting Field Experience

ACCT 4809.description: This course focuses on the technology and communication infrastructure supporting electronic commerce and its impact on auditing. Encryption, public key infrastructure, digital signatures, payment schemes, and web commerce are discussed. 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 4809.name: Security and Privacy in Electronic Commerce

ACCT 4840.description: The student is given the opportunity to relate theory to practice in a career related on-site field experience with a participating organization.
ACCT 4840.prereq: Accounting major, junior standing, 2.5 overall GPA, and approval of director.
ACCT 4840.name: Accounting Internship

ACCT 3750.description: Study of occupational fraud and abuse. Topics include asset misappropriation schemes, corruption, and fraudulent statements, including fraudulent financial statements. Coverage of these topics includes implications for the fraud examiner and corporate management. 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 3750.name: Fraud Examination

ACCT 4801.description: Financial accounting and reporting related to complex and highly sophisticated business transactions. Topics include the equity method, business combinations, variable interest entities, segment and interim reporting, worldwide diversity of accounting standards, foreign currency transactions and translation, SEC reporting, legal reorganizations and liquidations, partnership accounting, and estates and trusts. 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 4801.prereq: "C" or better in ACCT 3702 and FIN 3720.
ACCT 4801.name: Advanced Accounting

ACCT 4808.description: The theory and practice of financial auditing with emphasis on fraud investigation. Topics include professional standards, audit reports, evidence, occupational fraud, data interrogation, and computer-assisted audit techniques. Students analyze actual business fraud cases. "C" or better in FIN 3720. 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 4808.prereq: "C" or better in ACCT 3702, ACCT 3709, and ACCT 3711.
ACCT 4808.name: Auditing and Fraud Investigation

ACCT 6980.description: A study of accounting systems for federal, state, and local governmental agencies and other not-for-profit organizations. (Not available for credit to students who have had ACCT 4820.).
ACCT 6980.prereq: FIN 6900 Government and Funds Accounting or equivalent.
ACCT 6980.name: Governmental and Nonprofit Accounting

ACCT 6968.description: Topics may vary from semester to semester and will be announced with prerequisites and hours. May be repeated.
ACCT 6968.name: Special Topics in Accounting

ACCT 5820.description: Generally accepted accounting principles for not-for-profit and governmental organizations as established by the appropriately recognized, standard-setting bodies. Includes state and local governments, school districts, colleges and universities, hospitals, voluntary health and welfare organizations, and others.
ACCT 5820.prereq: "C" or better in ACCT 3701 and 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 5820.name: Government and Funds Accounting

ACCT 6915.description: A study of estate and gift tax law including tax return preparation. Emphasis on the importance of estate planning and the devices available for use in such planning, and effective uses of lifetime gifts, trusts, life insurance, pension plans, profit sharing, and other fringe benefit plans. The effects of state inheritance tax and property laws upon estate planning will be included.
ACCT 6915.prereq: "C" or better in ACCT 4813 or equivalent.
ACCT 6915.name: Estate Planning

ACCT 6909.description: A study of the formalized set of interrelated methods, procedures, and equipment utilized in developing, processing, storing, and reporting business financial and statistical information. The major emphasis is on computerized systems, although some attention is also given to manual operations and/or subsystems.
ACCT 6909.name: Management Information and Control Systems

ACCT 6908.description: A study of auditing standards and procedures, use of statistical and other quantitative techniques, and auditing electronic data processing installations. Other topics include practice before the Securities and Exchange Commission, special reporting problems, current developments in auditing, professional ethics and responsibilities, and extensions of the attest function.
ACCT 6908.name: Auditing Theory and Practice

ACCT 6960.description: Specific topics selected by the staff from timely and controversial work published in the field.
ACCT 6960.prereq: All core courses, plus at least six hours (6900-level) in accounting or permission of instructor.
ACCT 6960.name: Seminar in Accounting

ACCT 6901.description: A survey of the fundamental concepts of financial accounting employed by general managers.
ACCT 6901.name: Financial Accounting Decision Making

ACCT 6925.description: A study of the accounting and taxation principles and procedures of the petroleum industry.  Topics include exploration, leasing, drilling and production problems.
ACCT 6925.prereq: "C" or better in ACCT 2603 or FIN 6902.
ACCT 6925.name: Oil and Gas Accounting

ACCT 4841.description: Students have the opportunity to relate theory to practice in a career related on-site field experience with a participating organization. Accounting Internship 2 may be done at a different or the same organization as ACCT 4840; if the same organization, higher levels of duties and performance are expected. 2.5 overall GPA, and approval of director.
ACCT 4841.name: Accounting Internship 2

ACCT 6905.description: A study of the tax planning process and how it relates to employee and employer matters including, but not limited to, the alternative minimum tax, personal holding companies, unreasonable accumulations of earnings, depreciation recapture, retirement structuring, tax credits, taxation of international persons, and estate tax issues, including both lifetime and testamentary transfers. Paper and electronic research media will be utilized along with various formats for presentation of results.
ACCT 6905.name: Business Tax Planning and Research 1

ACCT 6922.description: Capital budgeting. Product costing. Pricing. Relevant and timely accounting information associated with these is necessary to make informed decisions. To improve their managerial decision making capabilities, participants will learn to examine, prepare and interpret accounting reports from the perspective of the manager of an organization.
ACCT 6922.name: Accounting for Managerial Decisions

ACCT 3701.description: Comprehensive study of the theories and concepts underlying financial accounting. Emphasis on income determination, asset valuation, measurement of liabilities and changes in financial position.
ACCT 3701.prereq: "C" or better in ACCT 2603 and ACCT 2603L and 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 3701.name: Intermediate Accounting 1

ACCT 3702.description: Comprehensive study of the theories and concepts underlying financial accounting. Emphasis on income determination, asset valuation, measurement of liabilities and changes in financial position.
ACCT 3702.prereq: "C" or better in ACCT 3701 and 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 3702.name: Intermediate Accounting 2

ACCT 4873.description: A CPA review course focused on preparing students to take the Business Environment and Concepts sections of the CPA exam. Only ONE 2 semester hour CPA Review course may be used as an Upper Division Business elective towards the BSBA degree; cannot be used as an Accounting elective.
ACCT 4873.prereq: "C" or better in ACCT 3709, 3711 and FIN 3720 and 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 4873.name: CPA Review Business Environment and Concepts

ACCT 4872.description: A CPA review course focused on preparing students to take the Auditing and Attestation section of the CPA exam. Only ONE 2 semester hour CPA Review course may be used as an Upper Division Business elective towards the BSBA degree; cannot be used as an Accounting elective.
ACCT 4872.prereq: "C" or better in ACCT 4808, 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 4872.name: CPA Review AUDIT

ACCT 4871.description: A CPA review course focused on preparing students to take the regulation section of the CPA exam, including familiarizing students with the computer based questions and simulations found on the exam. Only ONE 2 semester hour CPA Review course may be used as an Upper Division Business elective toward the BSBA degree; cannot be used as an Accounting elective.
ACCT 4871.prereq: "C" or better in ACCT 4813, 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 4871.name: CPA Review Regulation

ACCT 4870.description: A CPA review course focused on preparing students to take the financial accounting and regulation sections of the CPA exam. Only ONE 2 semester hour CPA Review course may be used as an Upper Division Business elective towards the BSBA degree; cannot be used as an Accounting elective.
ACCT 4870.prereq: "C" or better in ACCT 4801 and 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 4870.name: CPA Review Financial Accounting and Reporting

ACCT 4835.description: This course provides useful guidance and information in conducting practical professional tax and accounting research. A broad range of case analyses allows the instructor to focus on appropriate current topics in the accounting profession. Three hours lecture and hands-on research per week. 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 4835.prereq: "C" or better in ACCT 3702 and ACCT 4813.
ACCT 4835.name: Research in Accounting and Taxation

ACCT 3721.description: Theory applicable to state and local taxation. Primary emphasis on taxation principles in current use by state and local government units located throughout the United States. Case law is studied, some representative tax returns prepared. 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 3721.name: State and Local Taxes

ACCT 4855.description: Professionals from public, private, nonprofit and governmental accounting areas are invited to speak during class. The focus is how to plan for, and what to expect when starting an accounting career, and how to conduct oneself as a professional. Ethical considerations are emphasized. The class offers a unique opportunity to interact and network with accounting professionals.
ACCT 4855.prereq: Junior standing or permission of instructor, and 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 4855.name: Careers and Professionalism in Acct

ACCT 4818.description: A continuation of ACCT 4817, Income Tax Preparation 1. Completion of an updated/current IRS training program in federal income taxation of individuals, including international student and scholar and military income tax preparation. Students also receive updated training in current income tax preparation software. Students prepare federal, state and local income tax returns for individuals using current law. Because of previous experience in ACCT 4817, students prepare more-complex tax returns and provide guidance and leadership to first-year students. May be repeated once. 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 4818.name: Income Tax Preparation 2

ACCT 4851.description: Provides students with cooperative education experiences in accounting. Students may be assigned to public, corporate, or government entities on a semester to semester basis. May be repeated. 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 4851.name: Professional Practice in Accounting

ACCT 5814.description: Study of current Federal income tax law applying to proprietorships, corporations, S corporations, and partnerships. Includes fundamentals of researching tax law and preparing business tax returns. 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 5814.name: Federal Taxation 2

ACCT 4813.description: Introduction to Federal taxation theory and concepts relating to individuals and business entities, including tax research and tax form preparation. 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 4813.prereq: "C" or better in ACCT 3701, or FIN 3720.
ACCT 4813.name: Federal Taxation 1

ACCT 4815.description: A study of estate and gift tax law including tax return preparation. Emphasis on the importance of estate planning and the devices available for use in such planning, and effective uses of lifetime gifts, trusts, life insurance, pension plans, profit sharing, and other fringe benefit plans. The effects of state inheritance tax and property laws upon estate planning will be included. 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 4815.name: Estate Planning

ACCT 4817.description: Preparation of actual federal, state and local income tax returns of people from the community. Completion of an IRS training program in federal income taxation of individuals, including international students and scholars and military personnel. Training using professional income tax preparation software is also provided. 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 4817.name: Income Tax Preparation 1

ACCT 6996.description: Special research project under the supervision of a graduate faculty member. Credit will be determined in each case in light of the nature and extent of the project.
ACCT 6996.prereq: Fifteen hours of level II MBA coursework or permission of MBA director.
ACCT 6996.name: Research Problems

ACCT 6975.description: This course continues the study of income tax laws concerning corporations generally, including Subchapter S corporations, corporate reorganizations, partnership taxation, and tax administration and practice.
ACCT 6975.name: Business Tax Planning 2

ACCT 2603L.description: The purpose of this course is to provide spreadsheet skills to business majors. The course will be taught using current software and will cover areas like spreadsheet design, formula development, pivot tables, charting basics and importing and exporting of data. This course is required for accounting and finance majors and may be taken concurrently with Accounting 2603.
ACCT 2603L.prereq: "C" or better in ACCT 2602 and concurrently with ACCT 2603 or permission of the director.
ACCT 2603L.name: Managerial Accounting Spreadsheet Lab

ACCT 6930.description: The major objective of the course is to enable students to understand both the theoretical and practical aspects of compliance and regulation. Emphasis is on financial statement regulation and standard setting, including differences in financial measurement and reporting practices that exist in the U.S. and internationally. The course will examine how effective governance systems are implemented within all forms of organizations.
ACCT 6930.name: Financial Accounting Regulation

ACCT 6935.description: A study of the practical research process, providing useful guidance and information in conducting professional accounting and tax research.  A broad range of case analyses allows a focus on current topics in the accounting profession.
ACCT 6935.prereq: "C" or better in ACCT 3702 and ACCT 4813.
ACCT 6935.name: Research Accounting and Tax

ACCT 6950.description: A study of occupational fraud and abuse.  Topics include asset misappropriation schemes, corruption, and fraudulent statements, including fraudulent financial statements.  Coverage includes implications for the fraud examiner and corporate management.
ACCT 6950.name: Fraud Examination

ACCT 6945.description: This course will include coverage of professional ethics in accounting, practice development in accounting (including services marketing), and accounting-related career success skills. The course will be a combination of personal reflection, cases, lectures, outside guests (from accounting firms and entities and those that hire them), and a project identifying a development challenge faced by accountants with recommendations on what should be done.
ACCT 6945.name: Accounting Ethics and Professionalism

ACCT 6912.description: An examination of the managerial uses of accounting information for planning and control, and an investigation of cost accounting theory and practice.
ACCT 6912.name: Advanced Management and Cost Accounting

ACCT 6910.description: Provides graduate students the opportunity to relate theory to practice through on-the-job work experience with a participating organization. The internship will serve as an elective MBA course.
ACCT 6910.prereq: Completion of level I MBA coursework and six semester hours of level II MBA coursework.
ACCT 6910.name: Business Internship

ACCT 3709.description: Study of systems analysis, design, and implementation within the context of an accounting information system. Topics include a treatment of the business computing environment, security and control of information, the accounting information system as a component of the management information system, and decision support and expert systems.
ACCT 3709.prereq: "C" or better in ACCT 3701 and 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 3709.name: Accounting Information Systems

ACCT 3712.description: In-depth study of standard and differential costing. Compilation and preparation of budget data for managerial and administrative purpose. 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 3712.name: Advanced Cost

ACCT 3711.description: Study of cost accumulation for products manufactured under job order or continuous manufacturing processes; cost behavior and profit-volume relationships; cost structures for control and motivation; relevant costs for non-routine decision making.
ACCT 3711.prereq: "C" or better in ACCT 2603 and ACCT 2603L and 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 3711.name: Cost Accounting

ACCT 3710.description: An introduction to the analysis of accounting databases. Specific emphasis is placed on the structure and use of accounting databases, particularly XBRL. 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 3710.name: Analysis and Design of Accounting Databases

ACCT 1503.description: Terminology, concepts and principles of basic financial and managerial accounting from a user perspective. Internal controls, cash controls, and payroll accounting are covered. Does not fulfill WCBA requirements and cannot substitute for ACCT 2602.
ACCT 1503.name: Elementary Accounting

ACCT 4860.description: Subject matter, credit hours, and prerequisites will be announced in advance of each topic. 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 4860.name: Special Topics in Accounting

ACCT 3730.description: Accounting and taxation principles and procedures for the petroleum industry. Topics include exploration, leasing, drilling and production problems. 2.5 overall GPA.
ACCT 3730.name: Oil and Gas Accounting

AMER 5850.description: Theories of social class structure and formation, relationships between class and culture, representations of class and work, intersections of class with other aspects of cultural identity (race, gender, sexuality, place), and theories and methods of working-class studies.
AMER 5850.name: Class and Culture

AMER 4815.description: A discussion and analysis of the use and importance of material artifacts as texts for the recovery of the American past. Emphasis on sources not traditionally utilized by historians. Examples include the contextual analysis of children's books, foodways, and sacred spaces.
AMER 4815.prereq: HIST 2605 and HIST 2606, or AMER 2601 and AMER 3701.Cross-listed: HIST 4815.
AMER 4815.name: American Material Culture

AMER 4810.description: Work with faculty advisor on senior projects. A total of 3 s.h. is required for completion of the major. May be repeated with permission of coordinator.
AMER 4810.prereq: AMER 4801 and approval of Program Coordinator.Gen Ed: Capstone.
AMER 4810.name: Independent Project in American Culture

AMER 6910.description: Introduction to developments, approaches, and issues in new working-class studies, including intersections of class with other categories of identity, disciplinary and interdisciplinary perspectives, representations of the working class in the arts and media, and political and economic constructions of class.
AMER 6910.name: Introduction to Working-Class Studies

AMER 3770.description: Poetry, prose, drama, and other forms of literary expression examined within the context of a specific aspect of American social, intellectual, and cultural history. May be repeated once with different topic.
AMER 3770.name: American Literature in Historical Perspective

AMER 6930.description: Opportunities, challenges, and strategies for developing, promoting, and implementing public humanities projects in various settings, including community development and organizing, community-based adult education, and programs in museums and other public humanities organizations.
AMER 6930.name: Humanities in the Community

AMER 6970.description: Interdisciplinary teaching strategies focused on incorporating attention to work, class, diversity, and local history and culture into K-12 and college courses.
AMER 6970.name: Teaching Working-Class Studies

AMER 2610.description: Interdisciplinary thematic exploration of work and class in American culture with emphasis on the Mahoning Valley. Includes the impact of social movements, technological developments, and new ideas and knowledge. Examines the relationship of class to such social categories as race, gender, sexuality, ethnicity, and place.
AMER 2610.prereq: Placement in ENGL 1550.Gen Ed: Social Science.
AMER 2610.name: Work and Class in American Culture

AMER 6990.description: Completion of individual project in a community or school setting. May be repeated for a maximum of three semester hours.
AMER 6990.prereq: Proposal and review meeting with committee.
AMER 6990.name: Independent Project

AMER 6975.description: Introduction to interdisciplinarity and its application in the classroom with emphasis on integration of humanities and social sciences.
AMER 6975.name: Interdisciplinary Teaching

AMER 4801.description: Capstone seminar. Focuses on development and implementation of research proposal and current American studies research related to topics chosen by students for their senior projects.
AMER 4801.prereq: AMER 3701 and approval of Program Coordinator.
AMER 4801.name: American Studies Research Seminar
